story:
Hi Everyone!

We are Saltimbuc, a theatre troupe based in France, near Versailles. We are kids from 6 to 17, meeting every Saturday to act, dance and have fun in English!

Saltimbuc has been running for five years, producing skits, full-blown shows and musicals: Alice In SIAland, Kid's Eye View, and The Treasure Of Ignoramus Wrongwrite. We've written, sang, acted, and become great friends. 

After playing a riotous pirate crew at theatres all over the region, we decided we wanted to begin a new adventure. We had ideas spilling out of our brains, and were excited for the new year... But Mirabelle Kirkland, our artistic director, had to leave us for new horizons. We decided we had to keep going: none of us could envisage a future deprived of feverish backstage whispers and stage-lights. 

We searched and searched, and found a solution: Hannah and Carla, from theatre company Drama Ties, are ready to coach and guide us into creating a great show. They know how to shape our ideas into comedy, and how to focus our energy into learning a choreography. They will also help each and everyone of us grow, learn to reach out and speak up, and develop our creativity. 

Why We Need Your Help

The thing is, Carla and Hannah do this as a job. We need to pay them, and we also have to cover expenses for costumes, props, technical equipment and a stage if we want to perform. This amounts to at least 3500€. That's why we need to raise as much as possible; the more, the better our show will be.

We know you want to see a new, exciting show, and we've been hard at work already creating it. 

With this campaign, it's easy for you to help. 

You can be part of this wonderful art-making.

You can allow a bunch of kids make their dream come true.

You can enable us to create something brand new, funny and dazzling...

And you'll get rewards for it!

We've planned exclusive perks that you get when you pledge money to us. Check them out on the right!

Our Show

You might be curious. We don't want to give too much away, but...

The new show is going to be classy. We'll be mixing comedy and musicals, singing and dancing to some classic, beautiful songs, as well as acting out hilarious bits set in the world of Awards Ceremonies. 

The show is scheduled for Saturday 10th May, in the Centre Culturel Marcel Pagnol in Bures sur Yvette. There'll be drinks too, afterwards, so you can recover from all your emotions and gawp at the actors. ;)


So, Get On Board!

Dear audience, parents, friends, teachers, strangers:

no contribution is too small.

even your love will do. :-)

spread the word!

story:
We are Apple Kissa.

Founded by NY Comic Con in 2007, Apple Kissa—a NYC-based maid cafe-- has soared to new heights, influencing thousands of fans worldwide. Unfortunately, as NYCC begins phasing anime out of their con, we’ve lost our sponsorship and a large venue to perform. However, we now have the opportunity to call Rhode Island Comic Con home! As a group, we do not receive a dime for the shows we put on-- we do what we do because we love our fans. Please help us to continue entertaining geeks across the east coast and let us spread the message of love, magic, moe and anime!

 

For fans, by fans.

The end of NY Comic Con sponsorship spelled doom for us at first. We were one of the first maid cafes to be developed in the United States. Still, even in the face of this hardship, we won't give up! Our goal has always been to put a smile on the faces of those who come to see us, dance with us, sing with us, play games with us. We have always loved each and every fan who has supported us in our journey to where we've gotten to today, and we're not about to let that end. Each of our members has worked incredibly hard, practicing dances every day, for almost 6 years now. We don't work for the promise of payment, just for the promise that we can spread moe cuteness as far as we can!

 

Why help us?

Without your help, we won't be able to continue doing what we love most. As a NYC-based group, getting all the way up to Rhode Island isn't very cheap. Since we do not receive any payment for our efforts, getting to RICC would need to come entirely out of pocket and as most of us are only still in college, the expenses are too high for our budget.

Your contribution would do the following:

- Get every available maid a bus seat to and from Rhode Island.

- Give us the opportunity to continue performing in a new home.

- Allow us to gain exposure to a new crowd, who we are sure we can win the hearts of~

- Afford us the opportunity to spearhead Rhode Island Comic Con's new venture into anime for the first time!

story:
My Story

 

My name is Alexander Komarov. I moved to the states in 2007 from Russia. I attended Santa Monica College where I graduated with my degree in Theatre. During my time in college i played roles like Lord Farquaad in Shrek, The Musical, Dr. Carrasco in Man of LaMancha and Boris Kolenkhov in You Can't Take It With You.

 I have been involved in the theatre arts since I was 14 years old. I was introduced to "Charley's Aunt, The Musical" in 2005 when I  did a production of it myself. I got the chance to meet Victor Sytnik who originated the leading role of Babbs Babberley and became friends with him. When I  was moving to the US, I promised Victor that one day I would produce this show in the States. 

By contributing to this fund you will help me achieve my dream to bring this show to life in the States. And to introduce American audiences to music composed by Oscar Feltsman and lyrics by  Robert Rozhdestvensky. These two stage readings are just the beginning. My dream goal is to bring this to Broadway. 

 

What We Are Looking For 

 

We are looking to raise $8,500. 

The money you contribute goes to The Zephyr Theatre for rehearsals, and the two stage readings. Your donations will pay for our director, musical director, actors, lighting and sound. 

If we don't reach our goal. We will still do our best to create two stage readings of Charley's Aunt with the funds that we have raised. 

 

The World Needs More Comedy

 

I've seen the audience reactions form the original production and the production I've performed in. Their reactions were priceless. This show brought them so much joy and laughter. The world needs more comedy, more fun, more farce, more laughter and Charley's Aunt, the Musical delivers that.

 

Having problems donating?

 

No problem. We could really use your help to get the word out about this campaign. Please share on social media. By word-of-mouth, or via email? If you have any friends that would be interested in this kind of theater, please let them know! Thank you

story:
My name is Anthony Bounphakhom.  I'm a dancer and choreographer located in seacoast New Hampshire.  I am passionate about community, dance, arts and giving back and my plan is to build a space that brings that all together.  A space where you are able to truly be yourself.

Check out the video above to learn more about me, my journey and why this space is so important.

Click the BACK IT button above to donate or select one of our PERKs.  Thank You!

 

 

The space is called The Block.  Offerings will include dance classes for all ages and levels as well as mentoring programs, leadership workshops and community events, just to name a few.  This space will be a place where members can be themselves, be accepted, gain confidence and grow.

Opening Fall 2020

 

 

 

We need your help to bring The Block to life. 

Click the "BACK IT" button on the top right of this page

OR

Select a PERK from the list to the right.  We compiled some exclusive offers in limited quantities.

  • The Promoter
  • Lifetime Unlimited Dance Classes
  • Premier Business Sponsor
  • Flash Mob
  • Private Dance Lessons with Anthony Bounphakhom
  • 12 Months Unlimited Dance Classes

 

All contributions will go directly to the build-out and start up of the studio space.

 

 

 

Together we are building a welcoming home for our community.  This is a place where people of all ages and backgrounds gather for the love of dance and to connect, learn and collaborate.

One last thing.  Please help us get the word out by sharing this campaign!

 

 

 

Thank you from the bottom of our hearts for the support.  We are overwhelmed by your generosity!

story:
The Geraldine M. Vitacca

Emerging Artists Fund

Vitacca Productions & Company (Vitacca P&C) is a nonprofit organization committed to the development of dance programming that serves as a foundation for individual artistic growth of dancers, choreographers, and dance educators. We offer an environment for artistic incubation from which emerging dance artists launch themselves and the art form to a heightened state through coaching, mentorship, community outreach and performance.

Under the Vitacca Productions & Company umbrella, Vitacca Community Project initiatives are designed for Houston dance artists, Texas, and national communities. We believe that every artist, regardless of financial status and demographic deserves access to the dance art-form and industry education. 

Your contribution to the Emerging Artists campaign helps create a scholarship fund, which supports aspiring artists throughout Texas.

What We Need & What Your Gift Gives Back

The Geraldine M. Vitacca Emerging Artists Fund will provide financial assistance to young artists that wish to heighten their dance education within our internal mentorship programs or external training experiences.  With your support we hope to offer the following scholarships to emerging artists to the dance community at large:

Community Scholarships/Sponsorships

  • Fusion Dance Intensive (FDI) Partial Scholarships- The FDI scholarships will cover partial tuition for the Summer Intensive which offers a time of technical growth and artistic exploration. FDI students will spend a week working with world-renowned dance professionals perfecting their craft. Audition/Application required for consideration.
  • Continued Studies Sponsorship (CSS) – The CSS will be awarded to community based dancer(s) continuing their arts education and training post high school graduation, including: college and/or pre-professional training programs. Audition/Application required for consideration.

Organization Scholarship

  • Vitacca Dance Project Season Scholarships (VDPSS) – The VDPSS will be       awarded to VDP company members for the 2014-2015 VDP season.  This award will cover a partial sum of the VDP’s monthly expenses. Audition/Application required for consideration.

We wish to raise a total of $4,500.00 for the divisions stated above.  Your donation of $25.00, $100.00, $250.00, $500.00, $1,000.00 will help us reach our goal!  In thanks of your generous, tax-deductible gift, we offer items such as performance tickets and donor events.  All perks are determined by gift level and perks will be disseminated upon campaign’s conclusion.

The Impact

Your gift will help fund the education of young artists who wish to continue their studies in dance.  During our first year of programming, involved dancers made it abundantly clear how Vitacca Productions & Company has positively developed their artistic growth as well as providing them a safe place to explore their creativity.  Your contribution will allow us to continue to inspire and motivate.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute, you can help us in many other ways!

  • Share our campaign on your blog or social media page
  • Email your friends and family and encourage them to donate

story:
This project is accepted to perform in HERE Arts Center for their Co-Op Sublet Series. We are extremely excited as a company for such an opportunity!

Who am I?

Right from the heart of Istanbul, since the age of 4, I’ve been wanting and needing the stage.

I’ve always loved expressing, reflecting, sensing, and entertaining with my being since I’ve known myself.

I realized at a very early age that, my heart beats in a very particular way when I am performing. Since then, I’ve come a long way practicing through all sorts of performance; dance, musicals and traditional theater to realize, that I am striving to be an artist who’s honored to feel responsible for exposing, and inviting people to experience human intimacy, shame, fear, and give space for the untold stories and the stories that never get a chance to be told.

What is Void?

Void is an exploration of the female body: how it occupies space and how it has been existing throughout history.

What if the women in mythology, fairy tales, tragedies, biblical texts cross paths through memories marked by blood?

Void is about unleashing the female memory: how the rigid traditions, countless rituals, shame, guilt, and fear have left their marks on our bodies and souls.

This piece will be a movement based exploration of historical female figures and their impact. We seek to expose phenomena of all cultures, both celebrating and hiding the female body, in order to reclaim, rethink, reevaluate the female energy and its impact.

Full Credits

Creator & Director// Cemre Su Salur

Choreographer // Yolette Yellow Duke

Light Design // Victoria Bain

Scenic Design // Ahmet Durust

Video Design & Graphic Design // Asli Tunaman

Sound Design // Sasha Hawkins

Performers // Delaine Dobbs, Marsha Pierre, Alexandra Montalbano, Sydney Shinnick and Jessica Crist

Why do we need this campaign?

  • $50 or more // for each performer and designer
  • $350 // Rehearsal Space Rental
  • $200 // Costume
  • $300 //Set Design 
  • $100 // Props
  • $300 // Light Design
  • $400 // Crew
  • $20 // 500 Business Cards
  • $40 // 250 Postcards

 

To get more information about my work please visit: www.cemresusalur.com

To see more videos of the previous work: voidthemovementproject.tumblr.com

story:
Help fund Rubber City Shakespeare Company's production of Macbeth!

Macbeth is Shakespeare's shortest tragedy. It tells the story of a brave Scottish general named Macbeth who receives a prophecy from a trio of witches that one day he will become King of Scotland. The play dramatizes the corrosive psychological and political effects produced when evil is chosen as a way to fulfill the ambition for power.

In our production, we take this classic tale of human nature and set it inside a Rubber Factory around the end of the Great War (WWI), and ending around the great depression. As the play progresses we will see the transformation of the Macbeths from workers, to leaders, to warriors. 

(Rubber City Shakespeare Company's Macbeth set design by Scott Crim)

See the Show:

Oct, 2, 3, 8, 10, 15, 16, 17 at 7:30 PM
Oct. 4, 11, 18 at 2pm

(Rubber City Shakespeare Company's Macbeth costume design by Michele McNeal)

Meet the Cast and Crew:

Director: Dane CT Leasure
Assistant Director: Samantha Ost
Costume Designer: Michele McNeal
Set Designer: Scott Crim 
Lighting Designer: TBA
Properties Designer: Chris Simmons
Stage Manager: Alex Briski 

Macbeth - Michael Laymon
Lady Macbeth - Cait McNeal
Banquo/Menteith - Matthew Wheeler
1 Witch/1 Murder/Lady MacDuff/Caithness - Elizabeth Allard
2 Witch/Waiting Women - Michele McNeal
3 Witch/Murder/Fleance/Macduff Son - Kate Klika
MacDuff/Captain - Scott Crim 
Duncan/Porter/Doctor/Siward - Matthew Smith 
Ross - Chris Bizub
Lennox/Murder/Young Siward - Ron Young 
Malcolm/Hecate - Alex Funk 
Donaldbain/Murder/Seyton - Samantha Ost

(Rubber City Shakespeare Company's Macbeth costume design by Michele McNeal)


What We Need:

We are looking to raise $750 to help produce this great play. 
In addition to covering direct costs of production, this fundraiser will help us purchase some much needed lighting equipment which Rubber City Shakes will be able to use in many productions for years to come. We appreciate your investment in RCSC's future!


(Rubber City Shakespeare Company's Macbeth set design by Scott Crim)


Perks For You:

In appreciation for your contribution, you will receive the following perks from Rubber City Shakespeare Company.


$10 --King Duncan
(Fully tax-deductible)

  • A shout out on our Twitter and Facebook accounts 
  • A special thank you in the Macbeth playbill
$25--The Witches
($20 tax-deductible)
  • A shout out on our Twitter and Facebook accounts 
  • A special thank you in the Macbeth playbill
  • A previous RCSC show magnet
$50--MacDuff
(Fully tax-deductible)
  • A shout out on our Twitter and Facebook accounts 
  • A special thank you in the Macbeth playbill
  • A Macbeth poster signed by the cast 
$75--Lady Macbeth
($69 tax-deductible)
  • A shout out on our Twitter and Facebook accounts 
  • A special thank you in the Macbeth playbill
  • A Macbeth script signed by the cast 
$100--Macbeth

($72 tax-deductible)

  • A shout out on our Twitter and Facebook accounts 
  • A special thank you in the Macbeth playbill
  • A Macbeth poster signed by the cast 
  • Two complementary tickets to the performance, on the night of your choice

Other Ways You Can Help:

Can't make a monetary contribution today? You can still help us fund this production of Macbeth and contribute to the future of RCSC! 

  • Help get the word out! Share this campaign with all your friends and followers on your social media or email lists.
  • Email Casey@RubberCityShakes.com for information about upcoming volunteer opportunities.

story:
Not Your Stepmother's Cinderella...

You know the fairy tale: A beautiful young woman put to task by her wicked stepmother, true love discovered at a Royal Ball, a handsome prince to the rescue... but you've NEVER seen it like this. Curtain Call Performing Arts brings the science and fantasy of "Steampunk" to the classic Rodgers and Hammerstein coming-of-age story, resulting in a feast for the eyes and ears in this highly-anticipated show.

The show is being directed by Misty Megia and produced by Andrea Gorham. Performances will be on August 24, 25, 26, 30 31 at the Center for the Arts in Castro Valley, CA.

"In Our Own Little Corner"

A little about Curtain Call Performing Arts: founded in 2008 by Andrea Gorham and Catherine Heck, CCPA brings the magic of Broadway to the San Francisco Bay Area. Our mainstage performances have included Aida (2009-Best Cast In The Bay San Francisco Examiner), Into the Woods (2010-Most Visually Stunning and Best Cast, San Francisco Examiner) and Seussical (2011), as well as an annual performance of A Christmas Carol. Our mission: to produce exceptional theater. Our vision: to ensure that performance-based arts are accessible to everyone who desires to participate by keeping ticket prices low and offering affordable classes and workshops. We pride ourselves on being able to offer free showings of our mainstage productions to the San Leandro School District and putting on classroom workshops for students and teachers. As of May 2012, we've introduced 8000 students to the magic and wonder of musical theater through our Gift of Broadway program.

Help Us Get to the Ball!

We’re looking to raise $5500 that will be put toward venue rental, royalties, and costumes - every little bit helps! (And it can’t hurt that each sponsorship comes with a perk!) We know the power of word of mouth, so simply spreading our campaign around to your friends would be a tremendous benefit!

story:
Matter Dance Company is Proud to present our upcoming Summer Show: inJOY!  

Matter Dance has always tried to present audiences with a show that will excite and thrill them. We are not your average dance company - We create peices for the audiences. We want to make sure that every patron has a unique, interactive and outside of the box experience. 

Our new show inJOY will take all of the concepts MDC has become known for and smush them all into one unbelievable show. 

 

But we can't do it alone.... We need YOUR help!

Did you know putting up a show is EXPENSIVE?  Holy Cow! There are a lot of costs! 

Here is how you can help us:

Donate - $15 to pay for water for the Dancers backstage

Donate - $30 to pay for one day of rehearsal 

Donate - $50 to pay for shoes for one of our dancers

Donate - $75 to pay for an Assistant Stage Manager

Donate - $150 to pay for Costumes for an entire piece. 

Donate - $300 to pay for our Lighting Designer

Donate - $500 to pay for one night of rental in the theater. 

Donate - $1000 to pay for Props... we like props. 

 

Help us put on the best show we can. We want to make you smile!

story:
BUY TICKETS HERE!!

The Laramie Project

By Moises Kaufman and the Tectonic Theater Project

Directed & Produced by Erin Bigelow

8pm Fri/Sat & 2pm Sundays - $15

Oct 28th - 30th: 4th Universalist Society
76th & Central Park West

Nov 4th - 6th & Nov 12th + 13th:
Democracy Prep Charter School
207 W. 133rd St., NYC

Starring: Galway McCullough, Chris Lowe, Linda Blackstock, Pangia Macri, Felicia Masias, 
Chase Burnett, Lisa Kowalski, Brett Sears, and Janice Vavallo.

A benefit production for Interweave and The Matthew Shepard Foundation
'Like' us on Facebook or follow us on Twitter!!

You can buy tickets for the shows HERE!

Our Story

We are putting on a benefit production of The Laramie Project, the story of Matthew Shepard. He was a 21-year-old college student who was beaten and left for dead tied to a fence in Laramie, Wyoming on October 6, 1998 all because he was gay. This production is one of the most powerful plays ever written and has the greatest effect on everyone who experiences it.

The organization presenting this specific performance is Interweave, the LGBT committee with The 4th Universalist Society of New York on 76th and Central Park West. The proceeds of the production are being split between Interweave and The Matthew Shepard Foundation.

Our production will run for 3 weekends (on 76th & Central Park West on the Upper West Side of Manhattan and in Harlem at The Democracy Charter Prep School on 133rd St.)



The Impact

This play has been performed for more than 50 million people around the country over the last decade. The message of the play not only raises awareness, it teaches tolerance, acceptance, anti-hate mentality and changes lives around the world. Ignorance breeds hate. If one specific group of people are allowed to be targeted in a community, the door is open for all other groups to become victims of hate crimes. This play shows the impact one hate crime had on one community which can be multiplied by hundreds of thousands, though the intention of this production is to diminish those numbers, dramatically.

Ultimately, to bring the number of hate crimes reported around the country to zero.



What We Need & What You Get

We are working to raise $3,000 to cover our basic production costs for the play. The money will cover building a stage-in-the-round, and muti-use bar set piece, chairs, renting sound/lighting equipment for the 3 weekends and printing costs as well as refreshments for the nights of the performances.

We have been doing our best to get donations, provide our own costumes/props, and keep all costs low. We artists know how to get creative! :)


If we are not able to meet our goal of $3,000 we will have to use the proceed money collected from ticket sales to cover these production costs. Of course this is not ideal since this is a benefit performance and we want to raise as much money as possible for our 2 beneficiaries, The Matthew Shepard Foundation and Interweave (the church's LGBT organization).



We'd like to show our appreciation with some great PERKS for your generosity!!

THANK YOU! THANK YOU! THANK YOU!



Other Ways You Can Help

And if you just can't spend a dime right now, we understand. You can still help us in a BIG way!! Please 'Like' us on Facebook or follow us on Twitter!! If you can help spread the word about this amazing show to everyone you know, we'll be forever grateful! THANK YOU!! <3

story:
Our Story

Movement Lifestyle is a lifestyle brand which provides various components including choreography management, merchandise, studio, film/production, and now creating a dance tour.  We are a Los Angeles based company that has expanded beyond our office into a premier dance studio.  We not only provide a place for artists to create and learn, but also a place for them to network and provide support for them in their development as an artists. 

 mL has touched dancers all across the world.  Our choreographers have taught workshops to thousands of dancers in every major continent.  Many of our artists began dancing as a positive outlet growing up.  Through dance, they cultivated their own friends, communities, and artistic ventures.  Within the past few years, dance has propelled itself into the limelight of main stream culture.  Combined with the powers of social media, we have become a network of teachers that are influencing our up and coming youth generation.

The mL studio has unfolded to be a new and thriving studio in Los Angeles. During the summer time, students from all over the world fill our classes.  In addition, dancers/instructors all across the country are continually asking our choreographers to come teach at their studios.  However, the costs of hosting conventions, domestically or international, is financially accessible for only a few event organizers.  This is why our artists videos have over 4 million YouTube views. The students have the drive to learn, but lack the financial means to access our teachers. TheTour is our opportunity to bring the Movement Lifestyle experience to these dancers.  If we are able to bring this tour domestically and internationally, each event will generate enough funding to produce the following effect.  Each tour event is designed to be a weekend full of dance classes and sessions to educate our students on the ways to utilize dance to propel them further in their careers. In addition, students are rewarded with scholarships for outstanding attitude and effort.  We believe that allowing ourselves to be a prototype for them to follow at these conventions, will give them the tools they need to help establish, and/or continue to build upon, a great foundation to be successful. 

With our IndieGogo funding we will be able to help generate the costs we need to fund our tour. Our goals are simple, but our visions and work are constantly evolving.  We want to incorporate dancers, studios, and other communities that are beyond our immediate network.  The support and development of our artists has helped to inspire so many other artists, not just limited to dance.  We hope that you will believe in us and help support our vision! 

What We Need

We are proposing $25,000 as our initial investment for the tour.  
$10,000- Weekend [2-Day] Space Rental
$9,000- Choreographer Fee/Travel
$4,000- Staff Travel
$2,000- Equipment Rental [Lights, stage, floor, projector, audio]

Our Tour directors are all volunteering their time to make this event happen.  

Other Ways You Can Help

www.themovementlifestyle.com

Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/pages/Movement-Lifestyl...

Twitter: http://twitter.com/#!/whatmovesu

Tumblr: http://movementlifestyle.tumblr.com/


Help us network & fundraise by sharing our project!


Charity

Part of the proceeds will be donated to ANCOP Foundation (USA) Inc. 

For more information regarding ANCOP please visit www.ancopusa.org

"Answering the cry of the poor"

story:
What is Wilderness?

 

Wilderness is a play that takes place late at night, in a dark and remote forest, where two men find themselves alone with only the stars and a telescope to keep them company.  As they watch the stars above, they discuss the things that friends often discuss: life, actions and consequences , the reasons people do the things they do.

 

But as one sentence connects to another, and as the sky above continues to darken, the words spoken by the two begin to take on sinister meanings.  And as the light completely fades away, the words themselves dissipate, leaving only the animal instincts of the two to guide them through the night.  

 

Where can you see Wilderness?

 

Wilderness will be produced on stage by Ya Bird? Productions at the Players’ Ring Theatre in Portsmouth, New Hampshire, from June 21st to June 30th, to kick off the Ring’s Late Night Summer Series.

 

What is Ya Bird? Productions?

 

Ya Bird? Productions is the production company founded by Greg Hovanesian in 2016.  This will be its second full production; it has also put up readings of plays written by Greg around Boston.  

 

Who is Greg Hovanesian?

 

Greg Hovanesian is a playwright, actor and theatre producer based in Boston, MA. His works have been produced and/or developed by Boston Actors Theater, Playwrights' Platform, Image Theater, Hovey Players, UAE Theatre Festival, the One-Minute Play Festival, Jacklyn Thrapp LLC, Centastage, River's Edge Arts Alliance, Generic Theater, and Ya Bird? Productions. In 2016 his play one-act play Water won Best Play at the Playwrights' Platform's Annual Festival of New Plays.

 

Greg is also an actor who was awarded Best Actor at the 2016 Playwrights’ Platform Festival of New Plays.  He has acted in several short play festivals around Boston. His plays have been published by New World Theatre and Playwrights' Platform Publishing.  His short play The Most Beautiful Story was part of the Huntington Theatre Company's 2019 ‘Romeo and Juliet’ themed Playwright Bake-Off.   He is President of Playwrights' Platform and he belongs to StageSource and the Dramatists Guild of America.  Learn more about Greg at greghovanesian.com.

 

What does Ya Bird? Productions need to produce Wilderness?  

 

The biggest challenge facing Ya Bird? Productions is funding.  There are a lot of people involved with a theatre production, and we do our best to pay all of them a fair and professional rate.  We are proud to be working with an actor represented by Actors’ Equity Association for this production of Wilderness.  This will ensure that we pay both of our actors commercial rates for rehearsals and stage time.  

 

Ya Bird? Productions has already worked with and paid a graphic designer and photographer to put together our posters, and we will be working with a lighting designer and/or technician, a stage manager, and quite possibly a fight choreographer.  Just like our actors, we will pay them a fair and professional rate.

 

For these reasons, Ya Bird? Productions is looking to raise $2,800 for this campaign.  This amount will not cover the costs for the entire production: we like to think of it as a 'boost' to help us get to where we need to go.  Realistically, this ‘boost’ will help us make sure the show that people see is as good as it can be.  

 

Why help Ya Bird? Productions?

 

In this day and age, Ya Bird? Productions firmly believes that the local theatre produced by small companies is incredibly important not just to the ecosystem of new plays and works of art, but also to society as a whole.  Going to the theatre is a way to see stories unfold in a live, interactive environment that simply isn’t available on a computer or smartphone screen.

 

When you give to the Wilderness campaign, whether it’s for $1 or $50, you’re helping us to bring something unique to the stage that we hope will impact our audience, and perhaps society, in a positive way.  We want to inspire and change.

 

As a token of our appreciation, if you decide to donate $200 or more to our campaign, you will have the chance to sit in on one of our rehearsals, where you can meet our director and actors and get a behind-the-scenes look at how a play comes to life.  

 

We truly treasure our fans and advocates. We hope you will join us on our journey.

story:
Short Summary

Our original musical, The Incredible Six Thousand-Foot Ladder to Heaven, was selected by a panel of judges to receive its world premiere production at Underscore Theatre's 2019 Chicago Musical Theatre Festival, running at The Edge Theatre February 4-24th. We've raised funds for the production and hired a first-rate cast and creative team. Now all that's left is to get our show up in front of an audience. That's where you come in.

We hope that our show is for everybody. But some people have a harder time getting to the theatre than others. Will you buy a ticket to our show so that a Chicago-area student can see this world premiere musical for free? Since this is an original pop/rock musical, younger people (such as...for example...Chicago-area students!) make up a crucial portion of our target audience. Getting more students in the audience gives us the opportunity to get valuable feedback on our show, while giving them an opportunity to see a production they might not have been able to see otherwise!

How It All Works

It's a simple idea with a simple execution! You make a donation to this campaign, which we'll use to purchase and distribute tickets to Chicago-area students on a first-come-first-served basis. To spread the word, we'll advertise the exchange on college campuses and reach out to area high schools. Sign ups will be posted online so that everyone has fair and equal access to the tickets. Our producer will pay the platform and banking fees incurred by this campaign, which means that 100% of every dollar you spend goes toward buying a ticket for a Chicago-area student. 

The Impact

Here are some of the key ways your donation will make a difference:  

  • A Chicago-area student gets to see our show at absolutely no cost to them! 
  • Exposure to a broader cross section of people, especially this key portion of our target audience, helps us to develop our show for future productions. 
  • All tickets bought before January 1st get us closer to unlocking additional performances for our run at the Chicago Musical Theatre Festival! More performances mean greater exposure for our show, as well as more funds we can raise towards producing a cast album! That cast album will in turn mean greater exposure for our show, and will form the basis of future submissions to theatre companies around the country. The best way to help us unlock these additional performances is by making your donation today!

Suggested Giving Levels

Any amount helps! Here are some helpful tiers to consider:

  • $12.50 -- half a ticket. That may not sound like a lot, but consider this: it only takes 25 people giving at this level for us to reach a quarter of our goal! That's about 13 students in our audience who likely couldn't or wouldn't have been able to attended the show otherwise––that's awesome.
  • $25 -- one ticket. This is our suggested donation. All it takes is 50 people giving at this level for us to completely reach our goal. That means 50 Chicago-area students getting a chance to see this show at absolutely no cost to them!
  • $100 -- Four tickets. If you're able and ~feeling the spirit~ then this is a really amazing tier at which to consider giving. A large gift like this helps get us closer to our overall goal, which could help to inspire more people to get involved with our campaign! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Maybe you aren't in a position where you can make a monetary contribution to our ticket exchange. We totally get that! Here are some other ways you can help us out!

  • Liking/favoriting our campaign on social media! Before people can give to our campaign, they need to be aware that it's happening! All it takes is one little "like" to increase our visibility online! 
  • Sharing our campaign and encouraging others to get involved. Maybe you can't give, but chances are you know somebody who can! Encouraging other people to give even a modest amount is a huge help––every little bit adds up. 

Thank you so much for taking the time to read about this project!
story_txt:
Short Summary
Our original musical, The Incredible Six Thousand-Foot Ladder to Heaven, was selected by a panel of judges to receive its world premiere production at Underscore Theatre's 2019 Chicago Musical Theatre Festival, running at The Edge Theatre February 4-24th. We've raised funds for the production and hired a first-rate cast and creative team. Now all that's left is to get our show up in front of an audience. That's where you come in.
We hope that our show is for everybody. But some people have a harder time getting to the theatre than others. Will you buy a ticket to our show so that a Chicago-area student can see this world premiere musical for free? Since this is an original pop/rock musical, younger people (such as...for example...Chicago-area students!) make up a crucial portion of our target audience. Getting more students in the audience gives us the opportunity to get valuable feedback on our show, while giving them an opportunity to see a production they might not have been able to see otherwise!

How It All Works
It's a simple idea with a simple execution! You make a donation to this campaign, which we'll use to purchase and distribute tickets to Chicago-area students on a first-come-first-served basis. To spread the word, we'll advertise the exchange on college campuses and reach out to area high schools. Sign ups will be posted online so that everyone has fair and equal access to the tickets. Our producer will pay the platform and banking fees incurred by this campaign, which means that 100% of every dollar you spend goes toward buying a ticket for a Chicago-area student. 

The Impact
Here are some of the key ways your donation will make a difference:  

A Chicago-area student gets to see our show at absolutely no cost to them! 
Exposure to a broader cross section of people, especially this key portion of our target audience, helps us to develop our show for future productions. 
All tickets bought before January 1st get us closer to unlocking additional performances for our run at the Chicago Musical Theatre Festival! More performances mean greater exposure for our show, as well as more funds we can raise towards producing a cast album! That cast album will in turn mean greater exposure for our show, and will form the basis of future submissions to theatre companies around the country. The best way to help us unlock these additional performances is by making your donation today!


Suggested Giving Levels
Any amount helps! Here are some helpful tiers to consider:


$12.50 -- half a ticket. That may not sound like a lot, but consider this: it only takes 25 people giving at this level for us to reach a quarter of our goal! That's about 13 students in our audience who likely couldn't or wouldn't have been able to attended the show otherwise––that's awesome.

$25 -- one ticket. This is our suggested donation. All it takes is 50 people giving at this level for us to completely reach our goal. That means 50 Chicago-area students getting a chance to see this show at absolutely no cost to them!

$100 -- Four tickets. If you're able and ~feeling the spirit~ then this is a really amazing tier at which to consider giving. A large gift like this helps get us closer to our overall goal, which could help to inspire more people to get involved with our campaign! 


Other Ways You Can Help
Maybe you aren't in a position where you can make a monetary contribution to our ticket exchange. We totally get that! Here are some other ways you can help us out!

Liking/favoriting our campaign on social media! Before people can give to our campaign, they need to be aware that it's happening! All it takes is one little "like" to increase our visibility online! 
Sharing our campaign and encouraging others to get involved. Maybe you can't give, but chances are you know somebody who can! Encouraging other people to give even a modest amount is a huge help––every little bit adds up. 

Thank you so much for taking the time to read about this project!

story:
SHOW ME THE LOVE

Del Cielo is a performing arts company that uses music, theater and pracpic art to teach children and youth about community and culture. The current campaign is a musical performance called "Show Me The Love." Our youth were inspiered to spread a message of "peace"after all the recent mass shootings. Especially in the schools. Your contributions will help youth spread this much needed message of peace in schools and community.

 

We need $16,0000.00 to produce the "Show Me The Love"musical presentation.

$1,000.00 - Perks

$2,000.00 - Instruments

$1,000.00 - Costumes

$2,000.00 - Advertisement and Programs

$4,000.00 - Salaries and Overhead

The funds we receive will go to presenting "Show Me The Love" to community. If we are unable to achieve our Indiegogo goal, we will find other fundraising strategies, until we can complete our goal. Perks will be boxes of Southwestern landscape greeting cards which are prints of paintings by famous local artist Patricia Pitts.

 

The project is very valuable to our community and the world. if we can use the news clips of mass shootings, current affairs and  music that gives a message of peace and tolerance, we can positively affect our community. then the goal would be to continue to spread this message to other communities.

We have performed other plays with a social message which were huge successes. one show was "La Victima" and another was "Who Killed Don Jose", written by famed author, Rudolfo Anaya.

 

 

 

Risks and challenges we may encounter would be that the youth we are working with are primarily from very low income schools and neighborhoods. They do not have their own band and orchestra instruments. We intend to buy second hand instruments. Their parents cannot afford to by them costumes either. We have solved these issues in the past with team work and dedication to fund raising.

* Del Cielo would like to ask you help to get the word out by using Indiegogo share goals.*

Thank you for your support

story:
INTERPAUL (Samedi 30 mai)

Pour célébrer mes 50 balais, je prends un mandat à Interpaul pour organiser une grande fête!  Allez-y, toutes les raisons sont bonnes de venir danser la Paul Ka. 

Mais qui dit Paul Ka, dit Paul Cash pour faire des passeports à tout le monde. Un , deux, dix, 20, ça va... mais c'est Paul l'nombre que je veux inviter pour célébrer mes 50 tours autour du soleil. Moi,quand je commence, j'ai Paul don de m'arrêter. Faque, je va Paul l'expliquer 3 fois.  J'entends Paulariser vos forces pour organiser un truc qui va être plus grand que Manquez Paul'Piknic. Certains pourraient me traiter de mégaloPaul, je suis sûr que c'est Paul'intention qui manque, mais je veux Paul l'entendre.

Police de la moralité et du bon goût, INTERPAUL recherche des recrues prêtes à s'investir pour le bien public. J'peux Paul faire avec seulement Paul... Voici le topo :

- Réservez dès maintenant la date du SAMEDI 30 MAI, à vos agendas!

- comme j'adore organiser des fêtes, je m'occupe de la mienne pour vous.

Votre contribution : 

Vous appuyez le projet par une contribution de 25 $ minimum (par personne) - cela se fait Paypal ou carte de crédit via Paypal via le bouton "Contribuer maintenant" situé en haut dans la marge de droite et en bas de la présente page, pas besoin de compte Paypal (ils vous incitent à vous inscrire, mais allez directement à "Paiement par carte de crédit". Voir plus bas ce que vous avez en retour.

 Évidemment, vous pouvez donner plus... plus vous contribuez, plus ce sera extravagant!

- On mangera en début de soirée, à l'extérieur si le temps le permet. Si vous prévoyez manger sur place, vous ajoutez 20 $ de plus (par personne) au 25 $ de base. Ce ne sera pas des bouchées, mais quelque chose de consistant et bon.

Résumé :

25 $ - accès au party, au lieu et à l'entertainment (band, DJ) + une partie de l'alcool offerte gracieusement selon le budget final

45 $ - accès au party, au lieu et à l'entertainment  (band, DJ)  + bouffe incluse

En retour :

- je trouve  et réserve un lieu formidable_ Done! Ce sera à la Tour de Lévis sur l'Île Ste-Hélène, entrée par le Pont Jacques-Cartier, accessible par métro, retour à pied ou en taxi...ou à vélo, mais ça me fait peur un petit peu...



- je booke l'entertainment (only the best!)_C'est fait :

Live : le formidable duo rock'n'roll  Les Deuxluxe 

DJ : L'éclectique et excellent Kobal 


- je vous nourris généreusement, dans le sens de manger à sa faim (pour ceux  et celles qui veulent - avec le 20 $ extra)

- j'offre une partie de ce qui sera à boire selon le résultats de cette passionnante expérience de financement participatif.

Le paiement se fait par Paypal. Vous pouvez utiliser votre compte Paypal, ou votre carte de crédit si vous n'avez pas de compte Paypal (vous n'avez pas à vous abonner à Paypal). Vous aurez alors à entrer le no de carte, votre nom et votre adresse.

Important : pour effectuer le paiement, vous n'avez pas à vous inscrire via Facebook ou avoir un compte dans Indiegogo, seul votre courriel est requis. L'interface peut susciter une certaine confusion... voir ci-dessous.

Si vous cherchez un hébergement, n'hésitez pas à me contacter, je pourrai vous en suggérer.

Faites comme Svitlana (elle sera des nôtres!), engagez-vous sans penser au lendemain. 


Votre réponse rapide sera grandement appréciée, car je dois commencer à planifier tout de suite.

Notes : si jamais ça ne se faisait pas (croyez-moi, ça va se faire...), vous êtes remboursés automatiquement. 

La date de fin du projet est fixée  à 60 jours (10 avril) car c'est le maximum permis, mais vous pouvez contribuer après.

Vous avez Paul le loisir de laisser passer une occasion comme ça! Vous ne voudriez Paul le regretter toute votre vie, n'est-ce Paul?

Sans oublier que je ne suis Paul le seul dont c'est l'anniversaire en en forme de L (pensez romain) durant cette période bamboulesque. , , ,   Gémeaux have more fun! 

Venez accompagnés évidemment et n'hésitez pas à passer l'invitation à des gens qui me connaissent, que je n'aurais pas mis sur liste et qui voudraient venir.

Votre humble serviteur,

story:
We reached our goal! What now?


One of the tricky things about the Fringe festival is that you are subject to any number of variables, from the space they put you in to the times your curtain goes up. 

We had an unexpected twist when Fringe gave us a wonderful space at Gallaudet University. We are so excited to have use of their captioning system and the opportunity to be accessible to the deaf community. Did you know that DC has the largest deaf community in the nation? 

With this boon, however, comes new challenges. When Doorway Arts does something, we do it right. We want to be able to offer an ASL interpreter at multiple performances. This is an unexpected cost but we believe that it is worth every penny. 

Any amount donated will go towards a new goal of providing an ASL interpreter for Out of Sync. If we go above and beyond that goal or do not quite reach it,  the proceeds will go towards paying a much deserved bonus to our artists. 

We are so grateful to everyone who has donated, shared, and liked. Each and every one of you is responsible for our success. 

Please continue to spread the word, we still have lots of neat perks and amazing set sculptures available and we aren't done yet!

Who Are We?

I’m Mary Cat Gill,  the associate artistic director of Doorway Arts Theatre Company as well as a local artist with many other  hats. 

I started this campaign to fund the production of an incredible new play, Out of Sync, as part of the 2015 Capital Fringe Festival. Our goal is to motivate a larger conversation about mental illness and encourage our audience to reconsider the secret lives of the people around them.


What We Need & What You Get

By donating to this project, you will be aiding in the creation of a beautiful and relevant piece of art with a crucial message, supporting the mission of Doorway Arts to engage with local artists, including up-and-coming playwright Katie Woods and furthering the conversation about mental illness.

In order to mount this production, we will need your support. The financial costs of renting the theater space, mounting staging, and paying for the production of the play are large to a company of our size, but even one dollar adds up when many have pulled together.  Your donation will bring this play to reality.


Why this play?

Last summer I had been tackling some of the questions around society and mental illness. Why do we embrace it as a media sensation, share in the tragedy of celebrity suicide or violent incident, then sweep it under rug when the mourning period had passed? Why do we keep skirting an issue that affects not just celebrities, but 1 in 5 Americans? It was around this time that I discovered Katie Woods’ play, Out of Sync, and was offered the challenge of a script that tackles the issues of depression and anxiety in a new way. A way that highlights the quiet struggles of one average person and how they create a ripple effect that shapes us all.


What is it about?

Out of Sync follows Nathan and Petra, a young couple just beginning their relationship. But when the memories of his ex-girlfriend Amy start to bleed into the present, Nathan struggles to move forward. Amy’s crippling depression – and the devastation it eventually caused in their relationship – begins to splinter the fragile new bonds forming between Nathan and Petra. This beautiful new work explores the fragile intersection between love and mental illness through text and movement. 


Where does the money go?

Even small donations go a long way. Here’s how we break down the budget. Our largest and most important expense is paying our staff. This show requires 3 actors, a dance choreographer, two designers, and a stage manager on top of the director and producer. To be able to pay everyone, that totals out to $900. Our second largest expense is renting the space through the Capital Fringe Festival. The festival charges $585 for use of space, but also provides the lighting and sound equipment we require. Another $500 will be used for administrative needs such as royalties, photography, advertising, and printing. The final $250 goes towards technical and design needs including set, props, and costumes. These last two categories are where the little things add up. $5 buys us a box of screws. $15 buys a roll of Gaff tape. $20 buys a can of paint. $50 pays for postcards and fliers. $60 pays for online advertising. All of these small things build the foundation for a successful show and an informed audience to support it.

  • In Summary:

  • Space = $585

  • Staff pay = $900

  • Administrative needs = $500

  • Technical needs = $250

  • Total = 2,235


Why does it matter?

Theater has the particular ability to invite the audience to partake in and continue a dialogue long after the curtain has gone down.  By supporting the theater, you are supporting the conversation. By donating to this show, you are supporting a conversation about depression and anxiety in everyday life.


Where and when?

Eastman Studio Theatre at Gallaudet University

800 Florida Avenue, NE Washington, DC 20002

Saturday July 11th - 9:15 pm

Sunday July 12th - 4:15 pm

Friday July 17th - 9:45 pm

Saturday July 18th - 4:00 pm

Thursday July 23rd - 7:30 pm

Saturday July 25th - 4:00pm

All performances will be captioned and/or have an ASL interpreter, 


Other Ways You Can Help

There are many ways to contribute other than a financial donation.


Follow our work on the Doorway Arts website: www.doorwayarts.org

Visit us on facebook at: https://www.facebook.com/doorwayarts

Tweet us @doorwayarts #outofsyncDC

No amount of money can pay for the success of good buzz.
Please spread the word and share the links!

story:
No Feedback - the story so far

I am Nina Feldman, the founding member of No Feedback, a collective of performance artists working towards making engaging performance about issues that matter to us.

After visiting Cambodia a few years ago and seeing the destruction that genocide unleashes, I started this project to explore the nature of being human by considering what genocide can mean to an audience in London today.

                                   


Why the show is so important

Our current performance 'No Feedback' is the story all genocides, looking at the process of discrimination and the politics of fear. It is not concerned with huge atrocities, but rather the small details, the gentle pull of group belonging and the seemingly innocent games of everyday life. The project is supported by a number of partners including The Anne Frank Trust, The Wiener Library and Genocide Watch as well as Arts Council England. We will be premiering the show at Theatre Delicatessen in London in May 2015.


              


Why we need your help

Our show was made to get people talking and we want to share this opportunity with groups who otherwise might not have the opportunity to see it. The cost of such a performance often makes it impossible for schools and community groups to take part in opportunities of this kind, which is why we would like to offer it to them for free. Being successful in this campaign would allow us to run performances specifically for school and community groups by covering the cost of £500 per show including:

Performers wages

Making and assembling props

Travelling expenses

This would extend the reach of the show and initiate a conversation about discrimination and prejudice with younger audiences. We believe this is important and valuable in the context of London today.

Become a part of the No Feedback legacy

There are some unique perks that come with supporting our project, including free tickets to the show, show memorabilia and dinner with the creative team.

We are an experienced team who has carried out similar activities before. This puts us in an ideal position to deliver this project successfully.

If you can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help. Please pass this campaign on to other people who may be able to contribute and let us know on our blog if you would like to help in some other way.
story_txt:
No Feedback - the story so farI am Nina Feldman, the founding member of No Feedback, a collective of performance artists working towards making engaging performance about issues that matter to us.After
visiting Cambodia a few years ago and seeing the destruction that
genocide unleashes,  I started this project to explore the nature of
being human by considering what genocide can mean to an
audience in London today. 
                                   Why the show is so importantOur
current performance 'No Feedback' is the story all genocides, looking at the process of discrimination and the politics of fear. It is not concerned with huge
atrocities, but rather the small details, the gentle pull of group
belonging and the seemingly innocent games of everyday life. The
project is supported by a number of partners including The Anne Frank Trust, The Wiener Library and Genocide Watch as well as Arts Council England. We will be premiering the show at Theatre Delicatessen in
London in May 2015.              Why we need your help

Our
show was made to get people talking and we want to share this
opportunity with groups who otherwise might not have the opportunity
to see it. The cost of such a performance often makes it
impossible for schools and community groups to take part in
opportunities of this kind, which is why we would like to offer it to
them for free. Being successful in this campaign would allow us to

story:
THE PROJECT

All Thomas wants is to be like his cousin David. As these boys begin to grow into men, it becomes clear that there may be more to self-acceptance than fitting in. Presented by Snapper Theatre, Thomas by Robbie Curran explores the experiences of living with Asperger’s syndrome, and the challenges it poses both in life’s milestones and in the everyday.

Thomas will premiere at VAULT Festival 2019, which will give us an opportunity to showcase this production to future collaborators for a regional tour in late 2019/20. We strive for Thomas to be accessible to a wide range of audiences to ensure the broadest possible reach for the conversation about neurodiversity and representation.


AIMS

  • To respectfully challenge people’s expectations of the capabilities of those with autism.
  • To raise awareness on what being on the spectrum can feel like.
  • To tell a story that is hopefully equally funny and moving, to help anyone watching who is diagnosed feel less alone.

Our goal is to present Thomas, both to audiences without first-hand experience of autism, in order to dispel stereotypes, as well as to people who either have Asperger’s or loved ones who do, to help them see themselves on stage. This is paramount to helping us achieve our three core aims.

Your support will enable us to develop Thomas into a full-scale production. We will achieve this through collaboration with a creative team, and local and national charities which support those with autism. With your support, we will be able to bring Thomas to life and raise awareness of what growing up with autism is like. Please donate to help us hit the target and make all of this possible.
 

SNAPPER THEATRE

Snapper Theatre formed in 2017. Our mission is to tell stories that are underrepresented or misrepresented in theatre. We aim to amplify unheard stories, finding the ordinary in the extraordinary, and the extraordinary in the ordinary. Snapper Theatre’s debut production was Lobster, which was presented as ‘work in progress’ as part of Mountview’s Catalyst Festival and premiered at Theatre503 in January 2018.

When Robbie brought Thomas to us, we recognised that this play fell into both categories. It's rare to find a play that presents growing up on the autistic spectrum, and when you do, it often follows into more commonly perceived stereotypes. In a theatre industry that is seeking greater representation across the board, we often find that neurodiversity does not get the same attention as other inclusive groups, and we want to be able to support these voices. Robbie brought us a story that is honest and hilarious, and above all meaningful.

We're so excited to bring Thomas to VAULT Festival, and we need your support to make it happen.


HOW ELSE YOU CAN HELP

We know that not everyone can contribute financially, but there are other ways in which you can support Thomas. Anything you can do to help promote the production would mean the world to us. If you know anyone who would be interested in the production, please email us on: snappertheatre@gmail.com

story:
Who We Are

Elysium Conservatory Theatre grows fearless artistic expression within our community of emerging artists, guest artists and resident teaching artists - all invested in each other's success.

The mainstage theatre experience at ECT is just that - an experience. Productions redefine the relationship between audience and performer, offering soaring, human stories with immersive, imaginative staging. Performances are filled with passion, texture, raw humanity and a formidable ensemble spirit. 

ECT breeds artists with heart, who hunger to explore, to rehearse, to journey into the creative unknown and follow that lighting bolt of inspiration - whenever it strikes.

We believe theatre and art is about getting there vs. starting there. About falling in love with training, with rehearsal and with the crafting of story and character. We see a playground of Wonder and Exploration and opportunity to Adventure into the Artistic Unknown. 

Formed by professionals of multiple performing disciplines, Elysium Conservatory Theatre offers performing artists a creative Eden committed to fueling the next generation of American art, creating fearless, visionary work that rattles the foundations of modern performance.

Fearlessly.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Your generous contribution will help "Raise The Curtain" on ECT's inaugural production of ROMEO AND JULIET- opening March 31st, 2017!

The Goal: $1,800 for the show's inspired costuming + lighting + set!

ECTis giving all supporters of our production a Community, Ensemble, or Elysium Angel credit - each with it's own perks and levels of recognition.

 

The Production

Elysium Conservatory Theatre inaugurates our new company and home with a wondrous and fantastical reawakening of the greatest love story ever told, William Shakespeare's Romeo & Juliet. Artistic Director Aaron Ganz has chosen to dive fearlessly into the very essence of love - weaving stunning choreography, poetry, and music into a theatrical adventure that pushes the very Boundaries of Possible. ECT's Romeo & Juliet presents audiences with an opportunity to feel one of Shakespeare's finest works as it was intended; raw, human and capable of revealing the very harmony of love.   

 

Other Ways You Can Help

The success of this project lies in the sense of community it inspires. We believe in the power of community. It is an ever increasing force, a will that can do things that no single person - no matter their talents - can achieve on their own. Put simply, we are Believers. Optimists. Enthusiasts. We invite you to share in our dream - that together we can build an artistic paradise of devoted, passionate, and FEARLESS artists, boldly pushing the boundaries of performance throughout the world!

story:
You've heard of New Yiddish Rep . . .

We're the non-profit theater company that since 2007 has staged contemporary treatments of Yiddish classics, and Yiddish interpretations of modern/post-modern stage masterworks like "Waiting for Godot". This year, we were nominated for a 2016 Drama Desk award for our Yiddish-language production of Arthur Miller's classic tragedy, "Death of a Salesman".  NYR's Off-Broadway productions feature a new generation of Yiddish actors revitalizing cutting-edge dramas in mame-loshn with easily-understood English supertitles.

But have you heard about our Yiddish "God of Vengeance"?

More than one hundred years after it rocked Second Avenue and Broadway with its whores, pimps, and first onstage lesbian kiss, Sholem Asch’s indecent play, “God of Vengeance”, is returning to the New York stage in its original Yiddish in New Yiddish Repertory Theater's Off-Broadway production (Dec. 22nd, 2016 to Jan. 22nd, 2017) at La MaMa (74A East 4th Street, NYC). 

Directed by legendary actress/director Eleanor Reissa, the production will feature performances by Reissa and New Yiddish Rep members Shane Baker, David Mandelbaum, Caraid O'Brien, Shayna Schmidt, and Melissa Weisz, with new young Yiddish actors filling out the 11-member cast.

After two SRO readings in June 2016 at NYC’s OPEN: Festival of New Jewish Theatre, New Yiddish Rep is reviving "Got Fun Nekome" as Asch wrote it in 1906 and as it was performed in Second Avenue's Yiddish theater.  Set in a Warsaw bordello, the play's struggle between godliness and worldliness, and the tenderness of the lesbian scenes, seem even more fresh and relevant today.

But as Paula Vogel’s recent play “Indecent” at the Vineyard Theatre strikingly depicted, when “Got Fun Nekome“ moved uptown to Broadway in 1923 as the English-language“God of Vengeance”, the scandalous play was closed by police, and its entire cast and producer arrested and convicted on charges of giving "an obscene, indecent, immoral, and impure theatrical performance."   

Since its tumultuous American debut, "God of Vengeance" has been performed continually over the past century throughout Europe and the US in a variety of languages - but never again in Yiddish.  Asch’s earthy language in “Got Fun Nekome” – a people’s Yiddish born in the streets and slums – is at the same time filled with poetry and symbolism.  The play’s mame-loshn is rich, raw, and modern, despite being more than one hundred years old.

Asch's "God of Vengeance" also ranks in world theater on a par with classics like Strindberg's "Ghosts" and Ibsen's "A Doll's House".  Its open depiction of lesbian love, condemnation of religious hypocrisy, and feeling portrayals of deeply flawed humanity place "Got Fun Nekome" in the pantheon of important LGBTQ theater as well as modern social drama.

But we need your help to bring back "Got Fun Nekome"!

New Yiddish Rep's one-month run of "Got Fun Nekome" at LaMama will cost us an estimated $135,000 - for our actors, director, designers, crew, sets, costumes, lighting, sound, space rental, ticket service, marketing, printing, and insurance.  

You know that no theater company can cover its production costs by ticket sales alone.  At $36 a ticket for a 100-seat Off-Broadway theater, we'll realistically bring in only about $60,000 from those 32 performances.  That would leave us $75,000 in the red, and limit New Yiddish Rep's future opportunities to present even more vital Yiddish theater.

That's why we need your help to successfully bring "Got Fun Nekome" to Off-Broadway in December!  With your gift - from $36 to $5,000 - New Yiddish Rep can present this ground-breaking play in its original Yiddish as it should be seen and heard - vital, challenging, and deeply moving.  

We've received some grants and are talking to other "angels" who can help make up the difference.  But your gift is crucial.  And rest assured - whatever donation you can make will go directly to pay for New Yiddish Rep's production costs.

So please donate today!  

If you're one of the 110 wonderful people who helped us successfully raise more than $10,000 through IndieGoGo in March 2016 to send our "Waiting For Godot" ("Vartn af Godot") to Paris, we hope you'll step up again and make whatever donation you can for "Got Fun Nekome".

And if you've never given to us through IndieGoGo, let this be your chance!  Our "God Of Vengeance" IndieGoGo campaign ends on Opening Night - Dec. 22nd, 2016. 

Perks, Shmerks!  So that your donation to New Yiddish Rep can be totally tax-deductible, we're not offering perks for this fundraising campaign. That also means that 100% of your gift will go to support "God of Vengeance".  So donate today - and please share our IndieGoGo campaign with your friends!

And don't forget to buy your tickets!

Tickets to New Yiddish Rep's "Got Fun Nekome" at LaMama (Dec. 22nd - Jan 22nd) are now available at Brown Paper Tickets at this link:

http://nyrep.bpt.me

or by calling 800-838-3006.  Come watch New Yiddish Rep make theatrical history!

Thank you in advance for supporting New Yiddish Repertory Theater!

story:
Movement is Life.

Life is movement.

Dance connects me to myself. Dance connects me to the others. It connects me to the universe.

My name is Sofie, I grew up in Austria and I am dancing since as a child, but I also like singing and many other disciplines in Art.

I have studied social and cultural anthropology and linguistics and I have travelled and lived in different countries and love different cultures.

I do different dance styles, like urban dances, traditional african and afro-descendant dances like for instance brazilian or traditional haitian dances and contemporary dance.

I live in Haiti and there is this huge international dance festival in Austria that is called IMPULSTANZ.

They have a project called BIBLIOTECA DO CORPO (the body library) where they chose a group of only 30 young dancers from all over the world for an intense 5 week lasting experience of learning, exchanging and creating while being mentored by brazilian choreographer Ismael Ivo and many other great choreographers.

My philosophy is that all humans are made of the same essence, are part of the same body. Dance is a universal language, just as for instance music. Anybody can be touched by a sound or a mouvement, that reminds us that everything is connected.

This Body Library program works in that logic. Each participant comes with his her individual history, personal message to tell, and still we want to create something new together, a collective experience. Its about fluidity, its magic.

Please help me find the 5000 Dollars I need to be able to pay the program fees and the flight so as to be able to travel and join the program that already starts this sunday.

There is not much time left, so if you can help me, if I manage to participate I will keep you updated about my evolution and I will a nice dance video for all af you as a little present ! Help me move !! J

I already say thank you for listening and have a great day,

peace!

Sofie

story:
Brelby's Story

The Brelby Theatre Company is still a relatively young group on the Arizona theatre scene. Now in their third year of producing, the group was founded by fellow NAU alumni Brian Maticic and his now wife, Shelby Maticic. They united under a common vision, along with many other creative minds, to create an organization that allowed for more than just the production of great theatre, but as a resource for artists (both experienced and novice) to shape their abilities and fine tune their skills while pursuing various projects that not only challenge but also entertain.

 

The Ultimate Goal

Brelby's dream is to bring their skills to the communities that helped shape them as artists. Headed by a young, but determined duo, this production will take place no matter what kind of funds we raise. Our last season was entirely funded out of our own pockets, so if we have to eat ramen noodles for a month...this production will take place. However, we are working towards the ultimate goal of obtaining our own producing space. We want a steady location, where we can create entertaining shows, as well as provide enriching classes and workshops to our surrounding Phoenix community.

"God's Favorite"

By Neil Simon

 

This entertaining piece, loosely based on the biblical story of Job, is a perfect fit for the skills of our agile and energetic group.

 

Successful Long Island businessman Joe Benjamin is a modern-day 'Job' with a high-maintenance wife, ungrateful children and wise-cracking household help. Just when it seems things couldn't get any worse, he is visited by Sidney Lipton aka A Messenger from God (and compulsive film buff) with a mission: test Joe's faith and report back to "the Boss". The jokes and Tests of Faith fly fast and furious as Neil Simon spins a contemporary morality tale like no other in this hilarious comedy.

Breaking It Down

Our rental fees for this production will range anywhere between $2000 and $2400, depending on ticket sales.

We would like to raise enough to cover the facilities fees, production costs, as well as some funding to use towards advertising costs. In the miraculous instance that we raise more than our goal, the money will go directly towards funding our own location.

 

Are You Excited Now?

If you want to scope out some more details about us, you can find our official web site at www.brelby.com.

 

You can also check us out on Facebook, at www.facebook.com/BrelbyTheatreCompany.

 

If you want to join in the fun and get involved with the gang at Brelby, drop us an e-mail at BrelbyTheatreCompany@gmail.com.

Brelby's dream is to bring their skills to the communities that helped shape them as artists. Headed by a young, but determined duo, this production will take place no matter what kind of funds we raise. Our last season was entirely funded out of our own pockets, so if we have to eat ramen noodles for a month...this production will take place. However, we are working towards the ultimate goal of obtaining our own producing space. We want a steady location, where we can create entertaining shows, as well as provide enriching classes and workshops to our surrounding Phoenix community. 

"God's Favorite"
By Neil Simon
 
This entertaining piece, loosely based on the biblical story of Job, is a perfect fit for the skills of our agile and energetic group. 
 
Successful Long Island businessman Joe Benjamin is a modern-day 'Job' with a high-maintenance wife, ungrateful children and wise-cracking household help. Just when it seems things couldn't get any worse, he is visited by Sidney Lipton aka A Messenger from God (and compulsive film buff) with a mission: test Joe's faith and report back to "the Boss". The jokes and Tests of Faith fly fast and furious as Neil Simon spins a contemporary morality tale like no other in this hilarious comedy. 


Breaking It Down
Our rental fees for this production will range anywhere between $2000 and $2400, depending on ticket sales. 
We would like to raise enough to cover the facilities fees, production costs, as well as some funding to use towards advertising costs. In the miraculous instance that we raise more than our goal, the money will go directly towards funding our own location.
 


Are You Excited Now?
If you want to scope out some more details about us, you can find our official web site at www.brelby.com. 
 
You can also check us out on Facebook, at www.facebook.com/BrelbyTheatreCompany.
 
If you want to join in the fun and get involved with the gang at Brelby, drop us an e-mail at BrelbyTheatreCompany@gmail.com.

story:
Our Story

Hazel Street Productions believes in producing quality entertainment while giving back.


Five Women Wearing the Same Dress is an audacious comedy by Alan Ball, writer of the Academy Award-winning American Beauty and the hit HBO series Six Feet Under and True Blood. Taking refuge from a wedding reception in an upstairs bedroom, the reluctant bridesmaids learn that despite their many differences, they all share a common bond that runs much deeper than their identical dresses.


Little Mountain Gallery

26th at Main Street

Vancouver, B.C.


March 15-19 8PM

March 24-26 8PM

Matinee March 19 & 26 at 2pm

Tickets $15

www.fivewomenwearingthesamedress.com


The Impact

We will donate $1 from each ticket sold to Sanctuary for Kids in the hope of raising at least $500. They are a not for profit foundation that serves to provide sanctuary for children who do not live with the right of safety in their lives. Check out their website www.sanctuaryforkids.org


What We Need & What You Get

What we need:

We are pooling our resources to have as much donated as possible. Everyone is donating their time, talent and energy to this project. We hope to pay for our costumes, set, props and marketing costs with the funds raised on INDIEGOGO. Every dollar counts. Thank you for supporting the arts in Vancouver! 


What you get:


$10 = Good Karma knowing that you're helping us reach our goal

$20 = 1 front row seat and bottled water

$50 = MEET THE CAST (after the show), 2 front row seats, bottled water

$100 = VIP PACKAGE - recognition on our website and facebook, meet the cast, 4 front row seats, and bottled water


Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word about our play via Facebook:

http://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=63622530...


If you specify that you want your donation to go towards Sanctuary for Kids we will make sure it gets to them. We really believe in this foundation and are closely attached to it. 

www.sanctuaryforkids.org

story:
What We're Up To

 We aim to run the Bard On Bower- a three week Shakespeare in the Park festival on the outdoor stage in Red Deer's lovely Bower Ponds. We aim to produce a contemporary themed version of Taming of the Shrew and Macbeth- set in Northern Ireland in the 1970s during 'the troubles'.  

The Bard On Bower is an artist co-op. All of the actors, designers and technicians are doing this for the love of it- and no one gets paid unless we cover all of our expenses and then some! If we do recover all of our costs everyone involved has a share in the 'profit'. The cast and crew will work full time hours for 6 weeks before the shows even open- and we think their time, talent and skills are valuable- and we hope you do too!

But here's the catch- we want the shows we create to be accessible to EVERYONE. We do not want anyone to give a second thought to taking in these shows because they can't afford the ticket price- and so every performance is going to be PAY-WHAT-YOU-WILL! People can pay as much or a little as they can afford to come see these shows!

What We're Lacking

Some of the funding we receive will be allocated to:

Rental of Equipment, Barricades and a port-a-potty for our cast

Costume construction/dry cleaning

Props & Set building materials

Event/Beer tent licenses

Advertising- posters, handbills, radio and newspaper ads

MANPOWER! Actors, crew, designers, directors, stage managers- these people only get paid after we recover all costs of producing the festival!

Why We're Doing it

Because everyone needs more culture. We are trying to show that Red Deer has both the means and the interest to become a real center for artistic happenings. We hope to be at the center of this, developing this festival year by year into a major city event- something that everyone in Central Alberta can look forward to. For now, of course, we're just getting the festival on its feet, and that's why we need your support!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're a little strapped for cash, or interested in other ways you can help out, beyond just spreading the word or attending, we have several positions we are seeking volunteers for, including costumers, front of house and technical roles, assistance with venue preparation and construction, and hospitality for our sponsors. If cash isn't the route you can support us then just e-mail info@primestocktheatre.com to get involved in these other departments!

Corporate Sponsorship packages are also available! For full package details, please email us at info@primestocktheatre.com!

story:
Short Summary

After a great run in the Cork Midsummer Festival, No Kissin' Ensemble are bringing SLSD and it's raving rebels to the big smoke this coming September.

We here at No Kissin' Ensemble have been working tirelessly since 2014 to create new, innovative and stunning theatre in Cork city. Well we created it and now we want to bring it up to Dublin to show them how we do things down south. 

To bring the full rave experience up the country is proving to be quite costly and we are humbly asking for your help and support to get it there!

What We Need & What You Get

So what does your help and support (money) do, you ask??

All donations will go towards covering the following production costs:

  • Transport of set and lighting equipment from Cork to Dublin (and sadly it won't all fit on the Aircoach)
  • Venue Hire (and some extra cash to transform a theatre into a rave cave)
  • Sound Equipment to make "the beat so loud you can feel it in your chest."
  • Transport of cast and crew to Dublin (we're hoping they'll fit on the Aircoach)

Not only will we be eternally grateful for your donation but you'll be entitled to some "Perks" based on the amount you can donate.

The Impact

This is the first time we at No Kissin' Ensemble have been given the opportunity to tour our work. Your donations will help make sure that SLSD is the best it can be as it faces a brand new audience in a brand new city.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word - Just by sharing this link you're helping us build an audience and potentially fund SLSD.

Come see the show - If you don't have the spare cash now, save up your coppers and come see SLSD this September!
