story:
Britney The Brain Tumour

At the beginning of the year Charly was diagnosed with a large Pituitary Brain Tumour. It was a huge shock and naturally was a very scary and uncertain time. It was decided that the Brain Tumour's name would be Britney, and Britney had to go. 

Shortly after the tumour was diagnosed and a date for surgery was arranged, Ellen and Charly decided that a good way to come to terms with what was going on would be to write it down. In the form of a show, a comedy show! 

Throughout the various waiting periods and the recovery time and since, they have been writing BRITNEY: A show with a lot of heart. And a brain tumour. 

We are so excited and fortunate that the show was accepted into a fantastic venue at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival and now we need one final push to get us there and to get BRITNEY on stage!


Who We Are

Ellen Robertson- Writer/Performer

Ellen graduated from Cambridge last year and moved back to Abingdon-on-Thames which she is fine with. While at Uni, she wrote and performed in the Footlights Spring Revue: A Whole Lot of Bother, the Footlights Pantomime: The Emperor's New Clothes, as well as other comedies and plays and anything that involved avoiding hard work. This year, she has written her debut play, 'Nesting', and a short film 'Mia', which she hopes will happen at some point.  


Charly Clive - Writer/ Performer

Charly is a recent Graduate of The American Academy of Dramatic Arts who has lived in New York for the last four years and in her time their she has been fortunate enough to have her US writing debut with the play On Prosperity as well as work as Associate Playwright on Douglas Carter-Beane's Shows For Days at The Lincoln Center. Winner of the Breaking Ground award for new writing at the Origin Theatre Company for her short comedy Safety Dance, Charly also recently co-wrote the sketch show What's Your Fracking Problem? which premiered in Brooklyn, New York and was also in aid of The Pituitary Foundation.


Alex Cartlidge - Producer

Alex has just graduated from Cambridge University. Currently he is producing Lagoon, the 2016 Cambridge Footlights International Tour Show, which will play to an audience of over twenty thousand people across two continents. In 2015 he was the President of the Marlowe Society, and also produced the Cambridge American Stage Tour production of Taming of the Shrew, a project established in 2000 under the patronage of Dame Judi Dench.



What We're Asking

We are asking for £2,500. Here's our breakdown:

  • Props, Costume, Set- 150
  • Advertising- 500
  • Accommodation and Transport- 1,000
  • Payment of Creatives- 650
  • Contingency- 200
We are planning to make a contribution to the charity The Pituitary Foundation. Whatever surpluss we have from out Crowdfunding as well as a portion of our overall ticket sales will go towards the Foundation. 


About The Pituitary Foundation 

The Pituitary Foundation is a national support and information organisation for pituitary patients, their families, friends and carers. They are the UK's leading charity providing support to people affected by disorders of the pituitary gland.

The Pituitary Foundation's Objectives are to:

  • To promote the relief and treatment of persons suffering from pituitary disorders and related conditions and diseases, and their families, friends and carers, and to provide information and support;
  • To promote and support research and to disseminate for the public benefit the results of any such research.


Come And See The Show!

Our tickets are currently on sale! We could not be more excited to share this show with you! 
https://www.assemblyfestival.com/event/304/

story:
GRIT Dance: Storytelling in Concert 

It is important to see diverse dancers on stage. We believe each person has a unique story to tell and we want to share ours with you! Small and tall, young and old, we come together to create compelling stories, movement and partnering. We hope that by witnessing our stories as audience members, you can relate to our art in some way. 

We need your help! 

Where your support goes:

  • Hamlin Park Theater Rental
  • Choreographer and Dancer Salaries 
  • Lighting Designer and Sound Board Operator Salaries
  • Program fees 
  • If we don't reach our goal, we will still use your support! No amount is too small. 
  • Your support goes directly to us through Choreospace, which makes your donation tax-deductible. 

The Impact

  • We will be able to produce our concert!
  • You will be investing in our creative process and valuing art. 
  • We have produced on a small scale, but with your help we will reach a larger audience and the Chicago area. 
  • You get to see fun and thought-provoking dance. Who doesn't want giggles and introspection in one night?! 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word about our campaign on social media! Tell your friends! Tell your mother!

story:
Short Summary

Broken Beauty represents a unique way to experience original music in Los Angeles. Hand picked local songwriters gave their music to a creative team to envision using costumes, staging, choreography, and lighting.  No writer is allowed to perform in their own piece. The cast was personally selected per the need and vision of the individual song. The evening features a live band, 15 songs of kinds of musical genres (from a string trio to a Zombie burlesque), and a collection of the most INCREDIBLE SINGERS AND DANCERS. It's one night only and not to be missed!

What We Need & What You Get

I'd love to just cover my costs and feed my artists!

story:
In celebration of Grande Prairie’s 100th Anniversary in 2014, the GP Century Play will explore Grande Prairie’s past, present and future with the unifying theme: Grande Prairie Century Play—Celebrating 100 years of Myths, Realities, and Journeys.

What is a Community Play? Our technique follows the legacy of community plays held in Vancouver, the U.K., and many places worldwide. We aim to tell our community’s compelling story through fact and fiction, and to involve any and all residents who want to participate.

What is the timeline? We will host the play on Muskoseepi Park's Borstad Hill (the sliding hill near the museum) June 12-15, 2014. All performances are free.

How will Grande Prairie’s story be told? Through extensively interviewing residents and researching local history, a storyline has emerged. Our play will be led by director Annie Smith, GPRC drama professor.

What kind of support are we seeking? We have an IndieGoGo Fundraising goal of $2,000. These funds will go to support the costs of the production.

story:
Book by Hunter Bell and Lee Overtree

Music and Original Lyrics by Eli Bolin

An original new musical, and you can help take it to the next level! Get an exclusive insider's experience bringing a new work to the NYC stage!


ANNOUNCEMENT:

We are thrilled to announce that FOUND THE MUSICAL will have its NYC debut at the Atlantic Theater Company in the fall! The Atlantic has been a huge supporter of the show, and we're honored to be opening their 2014-15 season.

There's still time to join us on this exciting journey. Our Indiegogo campaign is ending at midnight tonight — don't miss the chance to be a part of this show!


What is FOUND THE MUSICAL?

FOUND THE MUSICAL is based on scores of outrageous and eccentric discarded notes and letters that have been "found" in the real world by every-day people. Inspired by actual events, the show follows FOUND MAGAZINE creator Davy Rothbart from his discovery of a shocking note mistakenly left on his car, through his unlikely adventure creating a cult favorite indie magazine with his friends. Finding success sharing other people's embarrassing, hilarious or harrowing private thoughts, Davy uncovers the secret we've all forgotten: the things we hide are often the very things we have in common.

FOUND weaves together Davy's story with those of countless other real people, through the notes they've lost that others have found. FOUND THE MUSICAL isn't just based on a true story, it's based on hundreds of them.

Every dollar we raise with this campaign will go towards further developing the show and getting it in front of an audience in New York City!

How it All Started

Join Our Team

FOUND is at a crucial stage in its development. We have had successful readings and workshops at prestigious festivals and theaters. And now, due to the show's success and escalating popularity, we are preparing the show for a production!

Now what we need is your generous financial support to make launching a production a reality. With your pledge, you will be joining us in this exciting next step for FOUND.  Your contribution will go towards developing the creative aspects of the show such as choreography, projections, demo recordings, and musical arrangements which are such important aspects to mounting a production of FOUND.

This really is your chance to be on the inside of a show’s creation.  To show our appreciation for your generous support, we have come up with some awesome rewards for your contribution that will make you part of the FOUND team and a true industry insider!

Where has FOUND been?

Ars Nova – New York, 2009 - 2010 – Four Performances of FOUND ensued over several months, each time honing the material and drawing enthusiastic audiences.

Williamstown Theatre Festival – Massachusetts, summer 2011 – A two-week workshop transitioning the show from sketches to a narrative book musical takes place and culminates in a reading.

Running Deer Musical Lab – Washington State, 2012 – A week-long workshop allowing the authors to polish the material in preparation for an upcoming production at the Berkshire Theatre Group.

Berkshire Theatre Group – Massachusetts, September 2012 – A two-week rehearsal period culminates in two staged public performances at the Colonial Theatre of the full book musical.

American Music Theatre Project at Northwestern University - Illinois, May 2013 - FOUND is invited to further develop the script in a two-week workshop that concludes in three public presentations.

New York Stage & Film/Powerhouse Season – The Inside Look – New York, July 2013 – A two-week workshop with Broadway performers culminates in three sold-out presentations!

Atlantic Theater Company – New York, December 2013 – A two-week staged reading takes place with Broadway performers, a choreographer and musicians.

WHO ARE WE? The Creative Team Behind FOUND THE MUSICAL

HUNTER BELL (Book) earned an OBIE Award, a Drama League nomination, and a Tony nomination for Best Book of a Musical all for the original Broadway musical [title of show]. Other credits include Silence! The Musical, Bellobration! (Ringling Bros. Circus), Villains Tonight! (Disney Cruise Lines), Now. Here. This. (Vineyard Theatre) and the Great American Mousical (Goodspeed). He is a co-creator of the web series [title of show] show and recently developed for ABC Studios/Television and Cherry-Wind Productions.

LEE OVERTREE (Director, Book) has served as artistic director of Story Pirates since he co-founded the group in 2003 and oversees performances and media in New York City, Los Angeles and on national tours. His productions have been presented at the Kennedy Center in Washington D.C., The Geffen Playhouse in Los Angeles, Solid Sound Festival (curated by the band Wilco), Bumbershoot Music and Arts Festival in Seattle, and at dozens of theaters in New York, including at Symphony Space and Ars Nova.  Other directing credits include Brilliance! (Geffen Playhouse), John Grisham’s Theodore Boone and the Thrill of Rights (Penguin Books Natl. Tour), Found (Actor’s Playhouse, Ars Nova and Berkshire Theater Group), He is an alumnus of Northwestern University.

ELI BOLIN (Music, Original Lyrics) is the music director/songwriter for Story Pirates, an arts education organization with branches in NYC and L.A. that performs songs and sketches adapted from the creative writing of children all over the country. Eli has been writing music for Sesame Street since 2010, and has also written just for Fuses’ Billy on the Street and two Kristen Schaal specials for Comedy Central. His musical Volleygirls was part of the 2013 New York Musical Theater Festival and his Lucille Lortel-nominated musical Skippyjon Jones begins its third year of touring in fall 2013. Eli also composed scores for off-Broadway’s I Sing! Roller Disco! (ART), Schmoozy Togetherness (Williamstown) and Fringical! (NYMF).

DAVY ROTHBART (Creator, Found Magazine) Davy’s magazine Found is dedicated to discarded notes, letters, flyers, photos, lists, and drawings found and sent in by readers. The magazine spawned a best-selling book, Found: The Best Lost, Tossed, and Forgotten Items from Around the World, published in April 2004. A second collection was published in May 2006, a third in May 2009. The magazine is published annually. He directs the Found Magazine Prison Pen-Pal Program, connecting Found readers on the outside with those behind bars, and is also active with the youth writing programs 826 National, 826michigan, and 826LA.

Spread the Word

Please help us go viral with this campaign by spreading the word about this groundbreaking new musical via email, Facebook, Twitter, phone, and good ol' word of mouth. Post this campaign on your social media sites. Email a campaign link to your friends! 

Meeting our goal:  AMAZING! We will be able to produce our intended premiere of FOUND THE MUSICAL in New York City.

Exceeding our goal:  FANTASTIC! FOUND THE MUSICAL will have an even more outstanding production with higher quality design in sets, lights and costumes.

Doubling our goal:     INCREDIBLE! Our production will have increased marketing resources to spread the word on this great show! 

                    Let everyone know that you found FOUND first!

Click the gallery tab above...

To check out Davy Rothbart on the David Letterman show talking about how it all started.  

Also listen to a few demo tracks from the songs in the show! (these are just demos-but will give you a sampling of the music)

 Stuff You Should Know

•  Please read the rewards carefully to determine those that are location or date specific, or subject to limited quantities. Specific event information will be posted on www.FoundTheMusical.com and you will contacted personally via email. We will not be able to change any date/time to fit individual schedules.

•  Travel, lodging and transportation are not included in any award.

•  Must be over 18 or accompanied by a parent or legal guardian to attend all events.

•  Some rewards may require that you (and your guest, if applicable) sign a                                           non-disclosure agreement upon your arrival.

                           

*All production photos were taken at the Berkshire Theatre Group workshop presentation in 2012.
story_txt:
Book by Hunter Bell and Lee Overtree
Music and Original Lyrics by Eli Bolin

An original new musical, and you can help take it to the next level! Get an exclusive insider's experience bringing a new work to the NYC stage!

ANNOUNCEMENT:We are thrilled to announce that FOUND THE MUSICAL will have its NYC debut at the Atlantic Theater Company in the fall! The Atlantic has been a huge supporter of the show, and we're honored to be opening their 2014-15 season.There's still time to join us on this exciting journey. Our Indiegogo campaign is ending at midnight tonight — don't miss the chance to be a part of this show!What is FOUND THE MUSICAL?

FOUND THE MUSICAL is based on scores of outrageous and eccentric discarded notes and letters that have been "found" in the real world by every-day people. Inspired by actual events, the show follows FOUND MAGAZINE creator Davy Rothbart from his discovery of a shocking note mistakenly left on his car, through his unlikely adventure creating a cult favorite indie magazine with his friends. Finding success sharing other people's embarrassing, hilarious or harrowing private thoughts, Davy uncovers the secret we've all forgotten: the things we hide are often the very things we have in common. 
FOUND weaves together Davy's story with those of countless other real people, through the notes they've lost that others have found. FOUND THE MUSICAL isn't just based on a true story, it's based on hundreds of them.
Every dollar we raise with this campaign will go towards further developing the show and getting it in front of an audience in New York City!



How it All Started







Join Our Team



FOUND is at a crucial stage in its development. We have had successful readings and workshops at prestigious festivals and theaters. And now, due to the show's success and escalating popularity, we are preparing the show for a production! 
Now what we need is your generous financial support to make launching a production a reality. With your pledge, you will be joining us in this exciting next step for FOUND.  Your contribution will go towards developing the creative aspects of the show such as choreography, projections, demo recordings, and musical arrangements which are such important aspects to mounting a production of FOUND. 
This really is your chance to be on the inside of a show’s creation.  To show our appreciation for your generous support, we have come up with some awesome rewards for your contribution that will make you part of the FOUND team and a true industry insider!






Where has FOUND been?

Ars Nova – New York, 2009 - 2010 – Four Performances of FOUND ensued over several months, each time honing the material and drawing enthusiastic audiences. 
Williamstown Theatre Festival – Massachusetts, summer 2011 – A two-week workshop transitioning the show from sketches to a narrative book musical takes place and culminates in a reading. 
Running Deer Musical Lab – Washington State, 2012 – A week-long workshop allowing the authors to polish the material in preparation for an upcoming production at the Berkshire Theatre Group.
Berkshire Theatre Group – Massachusetts, September 2012 – A two-week rehearsal period culminates in two staged public performances at the Colonial Theatre of the full book musical.
American Music Theatre Project at Northwestern University - Illinois, May 2013 - FOUND is invited to further develop the script in a two-week workshop that concludes in three public presentations. 
New York Stage & Film/Powerhouse Season – The Inside Look – New York, July 2013 – A two-week workshop with Broadway performers culminates in three sold-out presentations! 
Atlantic Theater Company – New York, December 2013 – A two-week staged reading takes place with Broadway performers, a choreographer and musicians.

WHO ARE WE? The Creative Team Behind FOUND THE MUSICAL




HUNTER BELL (Book) earned an OBIE Award, a Drama League nomination, and a Tony nomination for Best Book of a Musical all for the original Broadway musical [title of show]. Other credits include Silence! The Musical, Bellobration! (Ringling Bros. Circus), Villains Tonight! (Disney Cruise Lines), Now. Here. This. (Vineyard Theatre) and the Great American Mousical (Goodspeed). He is a co-creator of the web series [title of show] show and recently developed for ABC Studios/Television and Cherry-Wind Productions.
LEE OVERTREE (Director, Book) has served as artistic director of Story Pirates since he co-founded the group in 2003 and oversees performances and media in New York City, Los Angeles and on national tours. His productions have been presented at the Kennedy Center in Washington D.C., The Geffen Playhouse in Los Angeles, Solid Sound Festival (curated by the band Wilco), Bumbershoot Music and Arts Festival in Seattle, and at dozens of theaters in New York, including at Symphony Space and Ars Nova.  Other directing credits include Brilliance! (Geffen Playhouse), John Grisham’s Theodore Boone and the Thrill of Rights (Penguin Books Natl. Tour), Found (Actor’s Playhouse, Ars Nova and Berkshire Theater Group), He is an alumnus of Northwestern University.


ELI BOLIN (Music, Original Lyrics) is the music director/songwriter for Story Pirates, an arts education organization with branches in NYC and L.A. that performs songs and sketches adapted from the creative writing of children all over the country. Eli has been writing music for Sesame Street since 2010, and has also written just for Fuses’ Billy on the Street and two Kristen Schaal specials for Comedy Central. His musical Volleygirls was part of the 2013 New York Musical Theater Festival and his Lucille Lortel-nominated musical Skippyjon Jones begins its third year of touring in fall 2013. Eli also composed scores for off-Broadway’s I Sing! Roller Disco! (ART), Schmoozy Togetherness (Williamstown) and Fringical! (NYMF).

DAVY ROTHBART (Creator, Found Magazine) Davy’s magazine Found is dedicated to discarded notes, letters, flyers, photos, lists, and drawings found and sent in by readers. The magazine spawned a best-selling book, Found: The Best Lost, Tossed, and Forgotten Items from Around the World, published in April 2004. A second collection was published in May 2006, a third in May 2009. The magazine is published annually. He directs the Found Magazine Prison Pen-Pal Program, connecting Found readers on the outside with those behind bars, and is also active with the youth writing programs 826 National, 826michigan, and 826LA. 





Spread the Word

Please help us go viral with this campaign by spreading the word about this groundbreaking new musical via email, Facebook, Twitter, phone, and good ol' word of mouth. Post this campaign on your social media sites. Email a campaign link to your friends!  
Meeting our goal:  AMAZING! We will be able to produce our intended premiere of FOUND THE MUSICAL in New York City.
Exceeding our goal:  FANTASTIC! FOUND THE MUSICAL will have an even more outstanding production with higher quality design in sets, lights and costumes. 
Doubling our goal:     INCREDIBLE! Our production will have increased marketing resources to spread the word on this great show! 
                    Let everyone know that you found FOUND first!
Click the gallery tab above... 
To check out Davy Rothbart on the David Letterman show talking about how it all started.  
Also listen to a few demo tracks from the songs in the show! (these are just demos-but will give you a sampling of the music)

•  Please read the rewards carefully to determine those that are location or date specific, or subject to limited quantities. Specific event information will be posted on www.FoundTheMusical.com and you will contacted personally via email. We will not be able to change any date/time to fit individual schedules. 
•  Travel, lodging and transportation are not included in any award.
•  Must be over 18 or accompanied by a parent or legal guardian to attend all events.

story:
VECTOR:  a physical quantity that has both magnitude and direction; an agent that transmits an infectious pathogen into another living organism. VECTOR: a company that integrates motion-tracking technology with irreverent movement. VECTOR is immersive. VECTOR is unsettling. VECTOR makes space for vulnerability. We do what scares us.

Hello. We are VECTOR. Nice to meet you.

VECTOR is a Durham-based multi-media dance company creating work that questions the rules and societal norms that shape our daily lives.  Directed by visual artist Jon Haas and choreographer Leah Wilks, the company uses highly physical, detail-oriented movement in combination with video, audio documentary, motion-tracking, and projections to create participatory installations, evening-length performances and dance films.  Their recent projects include Secrets I Never Told My Mother (2012), Stitch (2013), Still Point (2013), Mess (2014) and the upcoming Habitus (2015).

Jon and Leah met in 2011 working on the production Mau A Malawi: Stories of AIDS Through Music at Memorial Hall in Chapel Hill. Through the craziness of mounting a cross-disciplinary show in a very short period of time they decided they liked working together. From 2011-2013 they collaborated on projects as their own separate companies LeahWilksDance and HaaStudios, and then finally decided to join forces under the moniker VECTOR in 2014.

We are in the process of making this kick-ass work called Habitus.

Habitus is a multi-media dance project exploring the intersections of anger, education, and identity.

What is the role of aggression and violence in our lives and how does that influence the world around us? What is it that we consider to be “normal”? How far must we be pushed before we begin to question what we have always taken for granted?

Using highly physical, detail-oriented movement in combination with cutting-edge motion-tracking technology, and audio-documentary, the full evening-length version of Habitus will premiere in Durham, NC in March 2015.  An interactive installation version of the piece will premiere as a part of the “Other Voices” series at Manbites Dog Theater in Durham, NC in January 2015.

We have launched this campaign to raise some money to help fund the premiere of Habitus. Here  are some biz-ness-y numbers for you:

This show costs a lot of money to produce because we're embarking on an ambitious project that involves so many talented people and new technologies.  We have already raised a majority of our costs to cover space and rehearsal fees for our performers.  We still need to cover the costs of equipment rentals and performance stipends.  Four very generous donors have offered to support us at the $1,000 level or higher if we are able to raise at least another $5,000 by the end of this campaign.  Every dollar you give helps us reach that goal.

This show will happen no matter what, but our ability to produce it to the fullest extent of our technical and artistic vision is dependent on raising these last funds.

MONEY RAISED SO FAR:  $13,600

(through Grants and In-kind donations)

MONEY LEFT TO RAISE: $10,000
(through individual donors like you and our already committed donors)


    Why should you donate, you ask?

    * Your money goes directly to artists and producing work that is ambitious
    * Your money is local and sustains Durham's burgeoning art community
    * This particular piece is extremely relevant to conversations happening in our community and around the nation.  Your support allows this conversation to reach more people.

    If you don't have dough to spare, that's cool. We understand. There are other ways you can help support Habitus.

    • Help us spread the word about our campaign!
    • Donate your time - we need volunteers for all sorts of things:
      -help building our installation sets and props
      -food during production weeks
      -house managing or flyering
    • Know someone who has marley? We need marley
    • Come See the Show!


    Living Installation at Manbites Dog Theater
    Jan. 8-10th, 15-17th

    Evening Length Performance
    March 5-7th, 12-14th

    This project is supported in part by the Durham Arts Council’s Annual Arts Fund and the N.C. Arts Council, a division of the Department of Cultural Resources. VECTOR is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of VECTOR must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
We are asking our community to support our efforts to fund:

·      Dance production

·      Documentary production

The Sutradhar Institute of Dance and Related Arts is coordinating the efforts of the many talented dancers, scholars and artists collaborating on this project.

The Character of Sita

Sita is one of the most famous characters in Indian classical literature. In the Ramayana, Sita undergoes the agonies of war and exile, yet is traditionally depicted as a docile princess, obedient daughter, and ideal wife. This monochromatic  depiction misses the fact that a woman who survived such adversity must be very strong. It also misses the meaning of the textual references to Sita’s divine ancestry as daughter of Mother Earth. 

Correctly perceived, Sita is a powerful, divine woman, who withstood fourteen years of forest exile and sexual harassment by the demon king Ravana. Once billed as a submissive character, Sita is being reclaimed by women scholars, farming villagers, and artists, both in India and here in the United States.

The Dance Production

The production will involve classical dance, masks, martial arts, poetry and an original music score. The focus is artistic; to awaken an audience through an unforgettable experience. The final work will be staged on at one of Washington D.C.’s finest avant garde dance theaters — Dance Place (www.danceplace.org) 202-269-1600.

Coordinated by the Sutradhar Institute of Dance and Related Arts, the dance companies involved will be SIDRA’s own Devi Dance Theater, Santi Budaya Indonesian Performing Arts, and Samapa Thai Dance Company.

Funds are needed to support the following:

·      Score creation and production at Asparagus Studios in Silver Spring, Maryland

·      Light design

·      Costume design

·      Stage props: masks, pillars, costumes, Madhubani tree cut out

·      Shadow puppetry powerpoint production

Documentary Production

A documentary will capture the introspection that emerges side by side with the choreography. Teenage dancers raise the debate to an intergenerational level. By filming it, this project identifies a global milieu which enables us to share beyond the staged presentation.

Funds are also requested to cover the expenses of:

·      Videographer

·      Folklorist

·      Script writer

·      Editor

Outstanding artists and scholars are enthusiastic about sharing their distinct talents with this project. We are hoping that our supportive community will join with all of us to bring this project to completion.

This project Sita: Gentle Warrior allows Sita to claim her voice. Through theatrical composition and multi-media presentation, Sita emerges beyond gender, culture, and time.

story:
Welcome to Greece...

Lascivious Something takes you on a journey to a secluded Greek Island in November 1980 on the evening of Reagan's inauguration.  Here you will meet August, whose passions are winemaking, and his luscious young wife, Daphne.  With the celebratory tasting of August's first 'rare varietal' wine upon them, the festivities are interrupted by the unexpected arrival of August's former lover, Liza.

Who we are...

In September of 2012, Sarah Rose and Lori Watt had the great honour of meeting and working on the award nominated Fringe Onsite Show Lost in Twine:  the Untold Stories of the Netloft by Kelsey Blair. They partnered up again for the UBC Production of The Vagina Monologues at the Frederich Wood Theatre in February of 2013.  Now TBA Theatre Company (founded by Sarah Rose) and the Frolicking Divas (founded by Lisa Beth Dery & Lori Watt) have joined forces to bring you Sheila Callaghan's Lascivious Something, coming to the Vancouver International Fringe Festival's inaugural Dramatic Work Series at the Cultch Lab.  We are thrilled to participate in this new category of the Festival along with the other 5 companies  which provides mentorship from Director Scott Bellis (founding member and Artistic Associate at Bard on the Beach).

    Our Cast 

    Sean Bygrave - August  
    Mersiha Musovic - Daphne
    Lori Watt - Liza
    Crystal Weltzin - Boy

    Our Crew

    Sarah Rose - Director 

    Scott Bellis - Directing Mentor

    Karin Atkinson - Stage Manager

    Angie Holubowich - Casting Director

    Scott Zechner - Set Designer

    Michael Methot - Lighting Designer

    Ryan Campbell - Sound Designer

    Colin Ivor Mills - Stills Photographer 

    Gina Leon - Graphic Artist

    Greek Consultant - Natasha Schinas

    Here's where you come in...

    We would really appreciate your assistance in bringing this project to the Fringe in September.  There are numerous costs involved in putting up a show and while we are a small, talented and dedicated team, with a great deal of resources in many areas, we could used your help in funding this project.  Monies raised will be used to offset the costs of:

    • Fringe Dramatic Work Series - fees
    • Play rights from Samuel French 
    • Set Design
    • Lighting Design
    • Sound Design
    • Costumes
    • Props
    • Still Photography
    • Graphic Design
    • Poster Printing
    • Advertising/marketing of the show
    Risks & Challenges...

    Well, it's always risky to put up a project you are passionate about!  What if the audience doesn't like it?  What if people don't come see it?  What if we sell out EVERY NIGHT and still at the end of the day, don't even cover our costs to put up the show?   While none of us involved in this project are in it to MAKE money, the truth is that most independent Theatre Companies in Vancouver do our best just to cover our costs and put up great work that we are proud of.  With your help, we can continue to do that!  Every little bit helps.  Just think, if every one of your facebook friends flipped you a toonie for a project you were working on - how close to your goal would you be?  We are tremendously grateful for any contribution at all. 

    Other Ways You Can Help...

    Don't have no cash, but want to help us out?  Well, of course you can!!!  Please feel free to share our campaign, facebook, tweet, text your little hearts out.  What a FANTASTIC idea!  

    THANK YOU! THANK YOU! THANK YOU!

story:
We are the Reno World Dance Collective.  Our seasoned dancers blend Belly Dance, African, African Hip-Hop, Hip Hop, Reggaeton, Polynesian, and Salsa for a uniquely expressive experience. This blend is enjoyed by mass audience members, students, and members of the dance troupe.

On July 11th in collaboration with River School Farm,

"a venue for year-round farming, special events, and educational opportunities that demonstrate a holistic approach to sustainable living, bioregional design, and creative expression," Reno World Dance Collective is hosting an event for Artown ("Diverse; Unique; Powerful; Innovative."  These are words that are used to describe Artown’s presentations during the July Festival.)  Many think they know Artown, but each year is unique.  However, we remain committed to our Mission Statement:  “To strengthen Reno’s arts industry, foster its civic identity and enhance its national image, thereby creating a climate for the cultural and economic rebirth of the region.” 

River Lights is a multicultural extravaganza.  This event will host dance performances based in the following countries, cultures, and dance disciplines:

Russian, Polynesian, African, Hip-Hop, Belly Dance (traditional and tribal fusion), Aerial Arts, Acro-yoga. 


The dance extravaganza will host and end the show with the internationally recognized and revered tribal belly dance group Gold Star ( " an innovative dance company rooted in Tribal Fusion Belly Dance directed by Kami Liddle and based out of San Francisco, CA.").

Your funding will support Reno World Dance Collective, River School Farm, Artown, and people of Reno in the following ways:

*Allow us to pay our very hard working dancers and performers for participating in River Lights.  

*Allow us to pay for a new dance floor at the River School Farm.  River School Farm is the sight of 80 plus percent of rehearsals and classes for Reno World Dance Collective, and on going community yoga classes, outreach programs for youth in the areas of dance, music, and yoga.

*Fund rehearsals for Reno World Dance Collective through the payment of studio rental for one year, which allows us the opportunity to study our wide variety of dance disciplines.

*Fund costuming for the Reno World Dance Collective for our 2014/2015 venues

*Help to cover workshop costs, allowing Gold Star to benefit the Reno dance community at large by hosting a workshop.

*Fund costs of lighting, stage, and technical equipment as this show takes place during sundown and early evening.  Proper lighting in River Lights is crucial.

Most importantly this will allow us to keep and share the gift of multicultural dance with the Reno community at large.
story_txt:
We are the Reno World Dance Collective.  Our seasoned dancers blend Belly Dance, African, African Hip-Hop, Hip Hop, Reggaeton, Polynesian, and Salsa for a uniquely expressive experience. This blend is enjoyed by mass audience members, students, and members of the dance troupe.
On July 11th in collaboration with River School Farm,
"a venue for year-round farming, special events, and educational opportunities that demonstrate a holistic approach to sustainable living, bioregional design, and creative expression," Reno World Dance Collective is hosting an event for Artown ("Diverse; Unique; Powerful; Innovative."  These are words that are used to describe Artown’s presentations during the July Festival.)  Many think they know Artown, but each year is unique.  However, we remain committed to our Mission Statement:  “To strengthen Reno’s arts industry, foster its civic identity and enhance its national image, thereby creating a climate for the cultural and economic rebirth of the region.” 
River Lights is a multicultural extravaganza.  This event will host dance performances based in the following countries, cultures, and dance disciplines:
Russian, Polynesian, African, Hip-Hop, Belly Dance (traditional and tribal fusion), Aerial Arts, Acro-yoga. The dance extravaganza will host and end the show with the internationally recognized and revered tribal belly dance group Gold Star ( " an innovative dance company rooted in Tribal Fusion Belly Dance directed by Kami Liddle and based out of San Francisco, CA.").
Your funding will support Reno World Dance Collective, River School Farm, Artown, and people of Reno in the following ways:
*Allow us to pay our very hard working dancers and performers for participating in River Lights.  
*Allow us to pay for a new dance floor at the River School Farm.  River School Farm is the sight of 80 plus percent of rehearsals and classes for Reno World Dance Collective, and on going community yoga classes, outreach programs for youth in the areas of dance, music, and yoga.
*Fund rehearsals for Reno World Dance Collective through the payment of studio rental for one year, which allows us the opportunity to study our wide variety of dance disciplines.
*Fund costuming for the Reno World Dance Collective for our 2014/2015 venues
*Help to cover workshop costs, allowing Gold Star to benefit the Reno dance community at large by hosting a workshop.
*Fund costs of lighting, stage, and technical equipment as this show takes place during sundown and early evening.  Proper lighting in River Lights is crucial.
Most importantly this will allow us to keep and share the gift of multicultural dance with the Reno community at large.

story:
Update! 

WOW!  I am extremely touched and blown away by the incredible amount of support I have received.  In just 17 hours, you have helped me surpass my goal!  However, you can still donate!  Any additional donations will allow me to delve deeper into the creative production of this show.  My $1000 goal covered the necessities, your continued support will help me to take more creative agency and make my visions a reality! 

About the show:

We Carry the Ocean Inside Us is an evening length dance concert that will bring the ocean to the Missoula Valley.  It explores how the ocean can serve as a source of comfort and a metaphor for fear amid the tranquility and turbulence of life.  We Carry the Ocean Inside Us will be presented at the Downtown Dance Collective in Missoula, MT on May 15.  This concert delves into the deep emotions of loneliness, frustration, and fear.  The vastness and mystery of the ocean is mesmerizing, comforting, and terrifying.  The work uses human interaction, representation of natural elements, and personal connection to explore the depths of circulating emotion.  With a crashing force, eight dancers personify inherent human struggle and find support in the rippling of the waves.  Choreographer, Emily Jay Vascimini, is intrigued by the strong presence of the ocean and how it can relate to the human experience.  

The concert presents the ocean through an inspired and novel lens that will tug on your heart strings and make you want to dip your toes in the waves.  It portrays a journey of loneliness, fight for control, frustration, anger, support, and solace.  We Carry the Ocean Inside Us is enlivening, personal, dynamic, textured, poignant, and heartwarming.  



Who we are:

Emily Jay Vascimini is a senior at the University of Montana working toward her BFA in Dance, choreography and performance.  This project is both the culmination of her college career and the beginning of her professional career as a dancer.  She is interested in the relationship and connection between the ocean and human emotion.  Vascimini grew up on the New Jersey shore and with the ocean running through her veins, she dives into an exploration of struggle, frustration, and growth through the ocean and its elements, such as sand, wind, currents, and storms.  Her choreographic works delve into honesty, vulnerability, emotion, and experience.  She is working with lighting designers, costume designers, and technical crew, as well as 8 dancers from the University of Montana to create this concert.

What we need and what you get:

Producing a dance concert requires a lot of money, time, and heart.  Your donations will go toward:
  • Space rental
  • Costume design
  • Publicity: posters, programs, flyers
  • Video documentation
  • Technical needs: equipment rental
  • Paying technicians: designers, stage manager
  • Paying dancers
Our first priority will be to pay for space rental, publicity, and design and technical needs.  With your support we can also compensate our technicians and dancers.  To thank you for your generous support, we provide incentives ranging from shout outs to signed pictures to a DVD of the performance.  Your donations are greatly appreciated and never taken for granted.  Don't forget, every penny counts!

The Impact

We Carry the Ocean Inside Us is Vascimini's first step into the world of professional dance as she culminates her collegiate experience and prepares to enter the professional dance world.  This concert provides a glimpse into human emotion and to Emily's deep connection to the ocean.  Your support will help propel one choreographer deeper into her work and to contribute to the spread of dance in the Missoula community.  

Other Ways You Can Help:

Every penny counts and we appreciate any amount that you can give!  Be sure to share the link to this campaign and help us tell the world about this project!  Also, mark your calendars for May 15, and bring your friends and family to come see the show!

story:
VERTIGO PRODUCTIONS: 

Vertigo Productions at Northwestern University gives undergraduate playwrights the opportunity to have their original scripts realized into full-fledged productions. By producing student-written theatre, Vertigo hopes to be a creative and dynamic presence on campus, encouraging students to take artistic risk. Vertigo is the only student theatre organization on campus that produces entirely student-written work.

ABOUT THE PLAY: 

Written by senior theatre student Sam Mueller, Moon & Back is an original play set to go up at Northwestern University on April 23rd through 25th. 

Moon & Back is the story of the Rose family, starting from the moment their patriarch, Gregory, writes home to say he is taking another tour overseas, rocking the foundation of the family. The play tracks the unraveling of each family member as they begin having visions of Gregory - the ghost of a man who is still alive but very much so out of reach - as his absence in their family is felt. Based on a true story, Moon & Back is the dissection of a family hitting rock bottom and being forced to keep going.

We cannot reach this goal without your help. The production is entirely student produced and funded, independent of the University, so only with your financial support can we get this play successfully across the finish line. All donations, no matter how small, are greatly appreciated and are tax deductible! With your help, the possibilities for this show are endless.

THE MOON & BACK TEAM:

Cast:

  • Gregory Rose: Matthew Kestenbaum
  • Marie Rose: Lucy Ahlborn
  • Jackson Rose: Ryan Martin
  • Stella Rose: Sophie Neff
  • Finn Rose: Sam Garrott

Crew:

  • Playwright: Sam Mueller
  • Producer: Hale McSharry
    • Assistant Artistic Producer: Allison Towbes
    • Assistant Business Producer: Yianni Kinnas
  • Director: Sean Gundersen
    • Assistant Director: Jason Clark
  • Stage Manager: Josh Light
    • Assistant Stage Manager: Becca Ehlers
  • Set Designer: Joseph Entenman
    • Assistant Set Designer: Axel Mark
  • Scenic Painter: Maya Siu
    • Assistant Scenic Painter: Nathan Villa
  • Props Designer: Bit Meehan
  • Costume Co-Designers: Rachel Holtzman, Jamieson Werling
  • Lighting Designer: Dylan Reyno
    • Assistant Lighting Designer: Ryan Miller
  • Master Electrician: Raphael Grimes
  • Sound Designer: Cecilia Pappalardo
    • Assistant Sound Designer: Alexandra Dayton
  • Dramaturge: Leah Platt
  • Publicity Director: Sam Shankman
  • Fundraising Director: Lena Elmeligy

HOW YOUR DONATION HELPS:

We are putting our money towards elements of the show including:

• Set: We're building a real home in Shanley Pavilion, where the Rose family experiences all of the ups and downs of the play. Also necessary are all the props needed to bring the Rose household to life.

• Lights: Our lighting designers are working hard to bring contrast to the natural realism of the plays events and the hardcore rock concert style of the play's choreographed transitions.

• Costumes: Costume challenges include a real Marines uniform for Gregory!

• Publicity: We are bringing this production to as wide an audience as possible, including other artists in the Chicago area.

OTHER WAYS TO CONTRIBUTE:

 You can support our show in a variety of ways:

• Share the Indiegogo link on social networking sites and with family and friends.

• Come see the show! We'd love to have as many people as possible see this incredible new work.

story:
Slim Bob Slim--Seth Reichgott's ukulele-playing vaudevillian alter ego--has been accepted to the exclusive Fellows Program of the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center's 2015 Cabaret and Performance Conference. It's a chance for Slim to work with top cabaret and theater artists to explore the cabaret form in more depth, to develop additional material, and to begin to craft a new show. This will be an amazing networking opportunity, opening myriad creative doors and providing a wealth of potential performance options.

But Slim can't do it without your help.

The cost of the program, lodging, and food for two weeks is a pretty penny, but if we work together we can do it.

Here's a quote from the Conference website that explains a bit more about this incredible program:

"The Conference is a dynamic opportunity for performers to work on new projects with the guidance of an accomplished team of professional directors, music directors, and guest artists. The Conference reexamines, redefines, and revitalizes the cabaret art form for the 21st century, using a definition of cabaret as 'any kind of live performance in an intimate space that often breaks the fourth wall.' During an intense two-week period, this Conference provides hands-on artistic guidance and instruction to a select group of participants chosen by application and invitation, featuring some of the top names in theater today."

Please help Slim to fully take advantage of this amazing opportunity.

Thanks!

P.S. Here's a look at Slim's audition video!

[Photo courtesy J.J. Tizou; Video courtesy Larry Loebell]

story:
Performing at the Edinburgh fringe festival has always been a dream of mine, and things came together this year to provide that opportunity.

People talked me up to several theater owners, and I managed to get a decent theater at a pretty good rate.  I look forward to doing the shows, and believe my comedy and my choice of variety acts will do pretty well, and I have been receiving a lot of encouragement.  Performing, and running the show I can handle. However, as a performer who runs a show here in California that is not profit oriented, I am amazed by how much it will cost to produce this show in Edinburgh, not including airfare, lodging, and promotion (there are 2300 shows!).

That is why, for the first time, I am using this necessary form of fund raising.  I was never keen on asking others for money this way, but I understand it now.  Basically, creative people do not always have the money to do what they love.

For those who don't know me, I am now going to talk about myself in the third person:  Ron Lynch has been producing and hosting the show called, "Tomorrow!" for over nine years now, and is excited to finally (with your help) take it on the road to Edinburgh!                 

Ron Lynch has been doing comedy for over 30 years.  He has appeared on many television programs including: Conan, Happy Endings, and The Sarah Silverman Program (he played all the doctors!).  Recent movies include "Smashed", and has appeared in many short films including a few directed by Louie C. K.  Ron is known for his voice-over work, which includes the animations: Bob's Burgers, Family Guy, American Dad, Adventure Time, and as "Mr. Lynch" on the cult classic, Home Movies.  

http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0528438/?ref_=nv_sr_1

With your contribution, I will be able to go to Scotland and do what I do.   Otherwise, I may have to forfeit my entrance fee, and theater booking fee, and keep dreaming.  

What We Need 

  • Flights: at least $1,821
  • ¼ page EdFringe Program Ad - $2,850
  • Mandatory Festival Registration Fee - $662
  • Edinburgh Technician - $1,026 (20GBP/show; 27 shows)
  • Housing $2000+
  • 15,000 flyers and 300 posters. $1080 
  • flyering Team to flyer potential audiences at the festival. $2290 
  • also, if we raise enough, we will bring more acts from the USA
  • eating.

    • If we don't raise all the money, there will just be less publicity.

    & What You Get

    $25   A social media thank you, and a comp to "Tomorrow!" in LA.  

    $50   A personal postcard from Edinburgh, and all of the above.

    $120  A Tomorrow! T-Shirt and all of the above.

    $1000  Ron will make a video specifically for you.  You write it (under 10 pages).  

    $1500 Ron will hang out with you for 1500 minutes.

    $2500  The complete "Home Movies" Box Set on DVD signed, and a Lifetime Pass to the "Tomorrow!" show, T-Shirt, postcard, and thank you.  (and probably any request you have).

    The Impact

    What impact does comedy have on the world?  Can a bunch of different acts come together on one show to make it one of the most interesting shows to ever happen at The Edinburgh Fringe Festival?  Will I do the best stuff I've done in years?  Will your money be the magic wand to make this happen?  Have you thought, "Can I stop reading this if I just donate money right away?"

    The answer is yes.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    I know a lot of you are in the same financial boat that I am in, and I wish you would help me row.   PLEASE spread the word by simply linking to this page.  If I ever performed for free for one of your videos, or did a voice-over that you really appreciated, or directed your show for free, you should contribute SOMETHING, but if you can't, please Link it up on the Twitter, Facebook, or Pinterest.  See the Indiegoogoo share tools.


    And that’s all there is to it.

    And I thank you for your time.

story:
UPDATE: May 17, 2014

The world premiere production of Corpus received tremendous audience feedback and terrific reviews! Although we closed last week, we are still fundraising for the project. This campaign still makes up a crucial part of our budget, and we need your help to be able to cover our costs and continue to make excellent theatre. We have just 2 weeks left to work towards our goal -- please share the link to this campaign to any and all arts supporters you know!

NEW PERKS

We are launching some limited edition perks to thank you for your support! 

  • An e-book created by Bronwyn from her research trip to Eastern Europe, with photos, discoveries, and reflections. This personal exploration of her cultural history is a special insight into the preparation and hands-on research phase of a theatre artist's work. 
  • Advertising space in the TACTICS 2014-2015 season brochure. Corpus was the pilot production for TACTICS, the exciting new collaborative theatre series that will officially launch at Arts Court Theatre this fall. This series brings together innovative new productions from 4 different Ottawa theatre companies.
  • And we are still offering Counterpoint Players t-shirts, original art photography by Wes Kline, and of course, our sincerest thanks and recognition on the Counterpoint Players website!

Thanks for your support, please help us continue to make excellent home-grown, professional independent theatre!


Counterpoint Players is proud to present the World Premiere of

Corpus

Written by Darrah Teitel

Directed by Bronwyn Steinberg

Starring: Sascha Cole, Eric Craig, Laurie Fyffe, John Koensgen, Daniel Sadavoy and Colleen Sutton

Production & Design team: Nicolas Alain, Sean Green, Patrice-Ann Forbes, Leeza Gulliver, Wes Kline and Ashley Proulx

May 1-10, Arts Court Theatre, Ottawa, ON

About Corpus:

A young and ambitious genocide scholar stumbles across the mysterious relationship between the wife of a Nazi officer and a Polish Jewish prisoner in Auschwitz. As she investigates a dark history, Megan is torn between her quest for academic fame and the unexpected charms of her online lover, the seductive Heinrich. A tale about history and memory told with humour and compassion.

Corpus has received several workshops, table-readings and awards, and was published in Canadian Theatre Review. And now, Counterpoint Players is proud to bring you its WORLD PREMIERE.

Counterpoint Players productions are exciting, provocative, independent theatre that make you laugh, think and feel something. Support brave independent artists in the telling of a story that needs to be heard -- and join us in making it happen! 


Corpus is a big show for an independent theatre company. It has a large cast and requires some sophisticated technology as part of the story. We have already received some support from the Canada Council for the Arts and the Jewish Federation of Ottawa, but those grants add up to only about a quarter of our budget!

What We Need & What You Get

So what do we still need? We need you to help us build the world of Corpus.  

When you come to see the show you'll be sitting in a space that you transformed into the world of the play, by helping us with:

  • The 2-week rental of Arts Court Theatre ($2,000)
  • Set materials including paint, projection screens, furniture, and computers ($800)
  • Rental and/or purchase of video equipment, including 2 live-streaming cameras, a video switcher, and software to run it all ($600)
  • Paying our technician for 80 hours of work that will make it all happen ($1,600)

With $5000 we can build a whole world!

And if we exceed our fundraising goal, then your contributions will go toward our other expenses, which include:

  • Rehearsal venue rental
  • Print and social media advertising 
  • Printing posters, postcards and programs
  • And most importantly: paying our amazing team of professional artists fairly for their talent and their work!

By contributing to our campaign and helping us bring this project to life, there are a variety of PERKS you could receive, including tickets to the show,  Counterpoint Players t-shirts, signed show posters, or a limited edition signed photography print from photographer and Corpus designer Wes Kline. (Take a look at his work here: www.weskline.com)

And of course with every contribution you will receive our sincerest ever-loving thanks!

The Impact

Counterpoint Players develop, produce, and play with theatre that provides a counterpoint. We are passionate about creating a theatrical space that brings people together to engage directly in theatre that challenges artists and audiences to examine their own connection to humanity.

Corpus presents a fresh approach to the dark and all-too-familiar subject matter of Holocaust literature. The script bravely explores the dangerous territory of fictionalizing – and sensationalizing – dark chapters in history. Despite the fact that our own life experiences have been so safely removed from the horrors of the Holocaust, we have been haunted by a third generation version of survivor’s guilt that compels us to want to tell this story. 

In conjunction with the production, we will offer a special preview performance in honour of Holocaust Remembrance Week on April 30th. We are excited to connect with our audiences and discuss the ideas, themes, and questions presented in the play through talkbacks after the performance.

In the works for a decade before this world premiere, Corpus has developed with workshops and readings at the National Theatre School, by the Banff Playwrights and a staged reading by The Travelling Jewish Theatre Company in San Francisco. In 2007, Corpus won the Calgary Peace Play Prize and was further developed with a workshop and staged reading at the University of Calgary. In 2010 it won the In The Beginning Jewish Playwrights Contest, the same year Darrah won the Canadian Jewish Playwrighting Award for Corpus. The play was published in the winter 2012 edition of The Canadian Theatre Review, which is where Bronwyn discovered the script last year.

Founded by Bronwyn in 2009, Counterpoint Players has created five original productions and collaborated on two co-productions. Sarah Ruhl's In the Next Room (or the vibrator play) at the Gladstone (May 2013), a co-production with Same Day Theatre and Plosive Productions, was recently nominated for 5 Prix Rideau Awards, including Outstanding Direction (Bronwyn Steinberg) and Outstanding Production. Projects under Bronwyn's leadership created work for more than 20 Ottawa-based theatre professionals in 2013 alone, as well as many others over the past 5 years. She was also recently recognized for her contribution to Ottawa's arts scene by being named as a finalist for the RBC Emerging Artist Award in Ottawa.

Other Ways You Can Help

HELP SPREAD THE WORD about our campaign by sharing, posting, tweeting, and shouting about it from the mountaintops!

Find us here:

Website: www.counterpointplayers.com

Facebook: facebook.com/CounterpointPlayers

Twitter: @CounterPtPlyrs.

And of course, don't forget the Indiegogo share tools!

And we're always looking for volunteers! If you'd like to lend us a hand by offering some of your time in person, please send us an email at counterpointplayers@gmail.com.
story_txt:
UPDATE: May 17, 2014The world premiere production of Corpus received tremendous audience feedback and terrific reviews! Although we closed last week, we are still fundraising for the project. This campaign still makes up a crucial part of our budget, and we need your help to be able to cover our costs and continue to make excellent theatre. We have just 2 weeks left to work towards our goal -- please share the link to this campaign to any and all arts supporters you know!NEW PERKSWe are launching some limited edition perks to thank you for your support! An e-book created by Bronwyn from her research trip to Eastern Europe, with photos, discoveries, and reflections. This personal exploration of her cultural history is a special insight into the preparation and hands-on research phase of a theatre artist's work. 
Advertising space in the TACTICS 2014-2015 season brochure. Corpus was the pilot production for TACTICS, the exciting new collaborative theatre series that will officially launch at Arts Court Theatre this fall. This series brings together innovative new productions from 4 different Ottawa theatre companies.
And we are still offering Counterpoint Players t-shirts, original art photography by Wes Kline, and of course, our sincerest thanks and recognition on the Counterpoint Players website!Thanks for your support, please help us continue to make excellent home-grown, professional independent theatre!Counterpoint Players is proud to present the
World Premiere of
Corpus

Written by Darrah Teitel

Directed by Bronwyn
Steinberg

Starring: Sascha Cole, Eric
Craig, Laurie Fyffe, John Koensgen, Daniel Sadavoy and Colleen SuttonProduction & Design team: Nicolas Alain, Sean Green, Patrice-Ann Forbes, Leeza Gulliver, Wes Kline and Ashley Proulx

May
1-10, Arts Court Theatre, Ottawa, ON

About Corpus:
A young and ambitious genocide scholar
stumbles across the mysterious relationship between the wife of a Nazi officer
and a Polish Jewish prisoner in Auschwitz. As she investigates a dark history,
Megan is torn between her quest for academic fame and the unexpected charms of
her online lover, the seductive Heinrich. A tale about history and memory told
with humour and compassion.Corpus has received several workshops, table-readings and awards, and was
published in Canadian Theatre Review. And now, Counterpoint Players is proud to bring you its
WORLD PREMIERE.Counterpoint Players productions are 
exciting, provocative,
independent theatre that make you laugh, think and feel something. Support
brave independent artists in the telling of a story that needs to be heard -- and join us in making it happen! Corpus is a big show for an independent theatre company. It has a large cast and requires some sophisticated technology as part of the story. We have already received some support from the Canada Council for the Arts and the Jewish Federation of Ottawa, but those grants add up to only about a quarter of our budget!What We Need & What You GetSo what do we still need? We need you to help us build the world of Corpus.  When you come to see the show you'll be sitting in a space that you transformed into the world of the play, by helping us with:
The 2-week rental of Arts Court Theatre ($2,000)
Set materials including paint, projection screens, furniture, and computers ($800)
Rental and/or purchase of video equipment, including 2 live-streaming cameras, a video switcher, and software to run it all ($600)
Paying our technician for 80 hours of work that will make it all happen ($1,600)
With $5000 we can build a whole world!And if we exceed our fundraising goal, then your contributions will go toward our other expenses, which include:
Rehearsal venue rental
Print and social media advertising 
Printing posters, postcards and programs
And most importantly: paying our amazing team of professional artists fairly for their talent and their work!
By contributing to our campaign and helping us bring this project to life, there are a variety of PERKS you could receive, including tickets to the show,  Counterpoint Players t-shirts, signed show posters, or a limited edition signed photography print from photographer and Corpus designer Wes Kline. (Take a look at his work here: www.weskline.com)And of course with every contribution you will receive our sincerest ever-loving thanks!The Impact

literature. The script

sensationalizing – dark chapters in history. Despite the fact that our own life
experiences have been so safely removed from the horrors of the Holocaust, we have been haunted by a third generation version of survivor’s guilt that compels us to want to
tell this story.

audiences and discuss the ideas, themes, and
questions presented in the play through talkbacks
after the performance. 
In the works for a decade before this world premiere, Corpus has developed with workshops and readings at the National Theatre School, by the Banff Playwrights and a staged reading by The Travelling Jewish Theatre Company in San Francisco. recently nominated for 5 Prix Rideau Awards, including Outstanding Direction

story:
Short Summary

Michael Garber Dance Collective is a group of contemporary dancers under the artistic direction of Michael Garber.  Michael is Artist in Residence at SugarSpace in Salt Lake City, UT.  The company is in rehearsal currently and will perform the new work titled "One"  on May 15th and 16th, 2014 at SugarSpace in SLC. 

The Impact

  • With the help of funding, MGDC will be able to deepen research and develop their collaborative process, creating opportunities for artists to learn from one another.
  • Supporting local art communities
  • Dance has an amazing ability to create a wholesome and heart-centered community.  Through dance we learn to MOVE TOGETHER!


What We Need  

  • Commission a local musician to compose an original sound score
  • Commision a local Videographer and  Digital Media Artist for visual collaboration
  • Costuming by local Costume Designer
  • Professional Fees for Dancers and Choreographer 
  • Production and Materials for Set Design  


Donation Opportunities 

Even a dollar is appreciated!

First Sphere

$25 

Your name will be listed with a special "Thank You" in the MGDC performance program

Second Sphere

$50

Your name will be listed with a special "Thank You"  in the MGDC performance program and you will receive a personalized Gratitude Card from the company members

Third Sphere

$100 

Your name will be listed with a special "Thank You" in MGDC performance program

(1) personalized Gratitude Card from the company members 

(1) Autographed Poster of the MGDC Company Members

Fourth Sphere

$150+

Your name will be listed with a special "Thank You" in the MGDC performance program

(1) personalized Gratitude Card from the company members 

(1) Autographed Poster of the MGDC Company Members

Your choice of either:

(1) 45-minute private yoga lesson or 

(1) Reiki session-Long Distance Available


Other Ways You Can Help

Cannot donate today?

  • Please pass this campaign to any and all who may be interested in donating and helping us on our mission
  • Come to the show! May 15th and 16th at SugarSpace
  • Please contribute to the world by committing 3 acts of Random Kindness today!
  • Create your own heart-centered community!
  • Love. When you are done with that...LOVE some more!!!
  • email: info@garberflow.com to express your support!

story:
Introductory note:

Check out our accompanying video with Dean Walsh, choreographer / performer, explaining the project. Judith McDonald, director Parramatta Scuba Warehouse, has also offered up some really great reward incentives.

PRIME: ORDERLY -

Parramatta Riverside Theatres, Sydney, 25th-27th October, 2012.

Bookings: http://www.riversideparramatta.com.au/performan...

Who?

Dean Walsh has been involved in dance for the past 21 years as choreographer, dancer / performer, educator, workshop facilitator and is a current Australia Council Dance Fellow (2011-2012).

Throughout his career he has wrestled scocial themes that have resonated with the real life situations he inhabits or has stemmed from. Through choreographic treatments, he has crafted performances that inspire, provoke, entertain, challenge, partake in community outreach, attracting a very diverse audience range.

Dancers / collaborators, Kathryn Puie and Natalie Ayton are both exceptionally instinctive and skilled dancers with a wealth of performance experience.

A new beginning: multiple transformations:

Why?

Words from Dean...

PRIME: ORDERLY is two things...

Firstly, it's the name of an upcoming dance work (the subject of this campaign), which will distil specific elements of my two-year Fellowship research into marine sub-scapes and human-animal movement studies.

Secondly, it's the name I've given my developing choreographic system comprising multifarious modes, embodiments (physical language) that is referenced when composing works, used as an education tool and to bring diverse physical disciplines and research together.

The eclectic choreographic disciplines of my twenty-year performance making are the foundation of this system. The next task was to infuse this with insights from my marine studies and through much practical experimentation - solo and with others - in venues across Sydney, notably, Macquarie University and Performance Space.

In 2005, after years working abroad, I returned to Sydney keen to shift my conceptual focus from only refelecting themes such as: domestic violence, homophobia, social-familial identity and the more 'monstrous' masculinities - things I'd encountered myself from a young age. Those works were physically based, often with a good serving of text, raw ironic humour and a lot of truth-telling. Stemming from a childhood rife with much male volatilty (including underworld figures), finding dance was pure chance and life-changing. I decided it was time for another major change...

In 2008 I finally commenced scuba diving (it had been an interest for many years as had marine environments). This immersive enviro-physical experience immediately secured my interest to find ways to bring the natural realm into my dance practice – both choreographically and conceptually.

I also saw it as a way to bring two inexplicably captivating physical practices (dance and diving) together to inspire creative, personal and artform transformations. To do it properly I needed an extended time-frame to descend deep into my inquiries, hence the Australia Council Fellowship.

Prime: Orderly, as a movement system, is helping me organise my eclectic and idiosyncratic dance embodiments, of the past two decades - influenced by many past and present practitioners / pioneers - into a language-defining template now inspired by new environmental territoires larger than my own.

Point of research: I've been interested to see if there might be ways to choreographically 'score' elemental functions of the myriad eco-systems, habitats and marine species physiology found in that vast space around us. Not outer space but inner space - the ocean, our genetic and ancestral home. I didn't want to do it solely through theoretical study - hence the scuba start up. I'm using this template of modes and codes as point of clarity to further inspire theoretical and practical exchange between artists, divers and other marine experts.

PRIME: ORDERLY, the performance event is broken up into two sections.

Section 1: is called AnEnemy - our perceptions of predator. What constitutes a predator...what do we see? Is it their appearance, behaviour or both? What are the primordial markers of our fear? Who or what is a predator? Is it through action or inaction that we ourselves predate?

Section 2: is called Under Pressure and takes an hour scuba dive timeline as structural, choreographic inspiration to make a thirty-minute trio that also reflects on other aspects of marine concern and physiological suspension.

'Wild' dancing will occur and stories will be told...

Your contribution:

We seek your financial assistance (large or small) to help present PRIME: ORDERLY in its best possible realisation. FORM Dance Projects and Riverside have invested significantly in the production. This is a great opportunity to get the work presented without jumping on the government grant funding cycle for presentation. Your contribution will help make a work that can attract potential partners, to support our future choreographic research throughout 2013 and 2014. We need another $4,000 to do this properly.

Campaign contributions for the production will also go towards production manager / rigger Simon for helping to make the technical aspects run smoothly and let Dean 'off the hook'!  A fee for our excellent video mixer and documentor Martin Fox for his artistry and work load.

story:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
OK now the cool stuff!

WHY SHOULD SCAMMERS HAVE ALL THE FUN?

Performers Under Stress present SCAMORAMALAND !

"Dear Sir, My father the Minister of Oil died in a Ghastly Motor Accident. He left me Two Trunk Boxes full of money which I need your help to reclaim..."

Freddy, a young Nigerian with artistic dreams, turns to email scamming to get school money - but most of his intended victims are pranksters who write back just to wind him up. He is a flop in the world of email fraud.

Who hasn't received an email promising untold riches?

This crime - centuries old and international, but known as the Nigerian scam - rakes in billions of dollars, ruining many of its victims.

"Scamoramaland" takes you into the world of the scammers and the people who delight in wasting their time - the scambaiters.

Under pressure from his thuggish boss to score, Freddy takes increasing risks and must finally decide what kind of man he will be. Meanwhile, the international ring of tormenters who humiliate Freddy form a bond - but if they met in the flesh, could they stand each other? or can they only be friends in Scamoramaland?

Rising star, Nigerian-born actor James Udom, 2012 winner of the Irene Ryan award, heads a bang-up cast who take you around the world in an evening - to a London police station, a Parisian cemetery, a tailor shop in Lagos, a Virginia home crammed with surveillance gear - and into that dreamscape known as cyberspace.

This comic drama has important things to say about class, race, identity and friendship in a world gone internet wild.

SO WHAT DO WE WANT? AND WHEN DO WE WANT IT?

We need your tax-deductible donation - any amount helps - and we want you to come and see us!

Performers Under Stress Theatre has been producing edgy, brave new works for over twenty years.
We never turn people away for lack of funds. It’s how we roll.
That being said - great new theater needs you, and it needs you now!

"Scamoramaland" previews October 26, 2013, opens November 1, and runs through November 17.

There are no frills -- donations go straight into the show. Production costs include rent, stipends for a cast of eight, a director, a talented crew, a dialect coach, a multimedia designer, and author's royalties. Ticket sales, even for well-attended shows, do not come near covering our costs, because we keep our ticket prices low.

Your TAX-DEDUCTIBLE DONATION will help make Scamoramaland all it can be. 

And - 

Your BUMS IN SEATS will help make the show's energy go through the roof!

So COME SEE IT!  and BRING YOUR FRIENDS!

Get yourself to Bindlestiff Studio in San Francisco and tell everyone who loves cutting-edge indie work (Facebook, Twitter, blah blah blah).
And if your grandmother thinks she's won a lottery she didn't enter, bring her too!

Keep coming back for updates, interviews and more about our wonderful cast and the world of Scamoramaland.


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

SCAMORAMALAND is a fiscally sponsored project of CounterPULSE. CounterPULSE provides support and low cost resources for emerging artists and cultural innovators, serving as an incubator for the creation of socially relevant, community-based art and culture.  CounterPULSE acts as a catalyst for art and action; creating a forum for the open exchange of art and ideas, catalzying transformation in our communities and our society.  They work towards a world that celebrates the diversity of race, class, cultural heritage, artistic expression, ability, gender identity and sexual orientation. www.counterpulse.org

story:
Mistletoe, Music & Mayhem!

                                                       Book By

                        Phil Johnson, Rayme Sciaroni & Matt Thompson

                                                       Music By

                                                Rayme Sciaroni

                                                     Lyrcis By

                                  Phil Johnson & Rayme Sciaroni

                       Directed by Rayme Sciaroni & Matt Thompson


Mistletoe, Music and Mayhem! is the best holiday show in town! Originally produced by North Coast Rep in 2010 & 2011 we are back and better than ever!   It's an exploration of holiday traditions (real and hilariously fictional) from around the world. Comedy sketches and musical numbers make up this 85 minute comedy romp


This co-production between Enterprise Theatre and The Ocean Beach Playhouse is running Dec 5-15, 2013 at the Ocean Beach Playhouse - 4944 Newport Avenue, San Diego, 92107.   We want to see you there!


What We Need & What You Get

Here's why we're indiegogo-ing it.

  • We would love to supplement the stipend for the cast and crew. Of course, we always do theater for the love of theater, but a couple extra bucks makes it that much more loveable! Actors and crew spend countless hours in rehearsal and show preparation. They all also have "day jobs." It's a labor of love that we are happy to be able to do in the San Diego theater scene. All donations will go directly to the actors on stage and the people behind the scenes making it all run smooth like buttah!

Listed below is our cast & crew.  All monies raised on this site will be divided equally among the full cast & crew listed below:

story_txt:
Mistletoe, Music & Mayhem!
                                                       Book By
                        Phil Johnson, Rayme Sciaroni & Matt Thompson
                                                       Music By
                                                Rayme Sciaroni
                                                     Lyrcis By
                                  Phil Johnson & Rayme Sciaroni
                       Directed by Rayme Sciaroni & Matt ThompsonMistletoe, Music and Mayhem! is the best holiday show in town! Originally produced by North Coast Rep in 2010 & 2011 we are back and better than ever!   It's an exploration of holiday traditions (real and hilariously fictional) from around the world. Comedy sketches and musical numbers make up this 85 minute comedy rompThis co-production between Enterprise Theatre and The Ocean Beach Playhouse is running Dec 5-15, 2013 at the Ocean Beach Playhouse - 4944 Newport Avenue, San Diego, 92107.   We want to see you there!
What We Need & What You Get
Here's why we're indiegogo-ing it.We would love to supplement the stipend for the cast and crew. Of course, we always do theater for the love of theater, but a couple extra bucks makes it that much more loveable! Actors and crew spend countless hours in rehearsal and show preparation. They all also have "day jobs." It's a labor of love that we are happy to be able to do in the San Diego theater scene. All donations will go directly to the actors on stage and the people behind the scenes making it all run smooth like buttah!Listed below is our cast & crew.  All monies raised on this site will be divided equally among the full cast & crew listed below:
