story:
About Trio:

TrioDance Collective was founded in New York City in 2010 by Barbie Diewald and Emily Jeffries, and has since produced five seasons of new work!  One main tenet of our mission as a company is to foster individual development within the structure of a fiercely supportive group, and we are so proud of the artists who have grown alongside us over the course of the last two years.  

TrioDance Collective is currently built on the work of:

Two choreographers: Barbie Diewald and Emily Jeffries

and eleven wonderfully intelligent and articulate dancers: Sarah Moore, Cara McGaughey, Allison Beler, Carly Fox-Horton, Sachiko Takimura, Britney Falcon, Susan Philipp, Alyssa Forte, Emily Craver, Colleen Hoelscher, Carmella Ollero.

We all strive to create richly creative, non-competitive, humble processes within which to work.  

Trio's newest repertory works Rooms and Here will premiere at the venerable 92nd Street Y Harkness Dance Center's Buttenwieser Hall on May 25th and May 26th, 2012, and we are getting very excited!

 

Why we need your help now:

Though our Spring performance is only a couple of weeks away, and the entire proccess is nearing completion, producing one's own work in New York is a mammoth task, and one that is very costly. Through fundraising events, ticket sales from our Spring series "Green Line," and fees from our Spring workshop series, we were able to raise a significant amount of funds to Produce our own work in New York, but we still need your help.  

We need to raise thousands of dollars each season to cover costs associated with bringing these works from studio to stage.  This covers: rehearsal space, performers' salaries and collaborator's expenses, video documentation, costuming, marketing materials, and programs.

We are looking to you, people who are interested in our artists, our efforts, and the dance community that we care for so deeply, to collectively contribute $3,000.  Please become a part of TrioDance Collective's work.  We cannot wait to share it with you.  

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not in a position to make a donation today, you can help us by telling people about TrioDance Collective and what we do!  Please share this with the dance lovers in your life, and help us to develop new opportunities for dancers.

Join our Facebook Page: http://www.facebook.com/pages/TrioDance-Collective/112437095438430

Email us to subscribe to our monthly newsletter at triodancecollective@gmail.com

story:
The Gist

The Great American Road Trip... Help me make a documentary dance film of my trip from New York to California. 

Follow the wind will be a collection of site specific dances in various city and landscapes across the country. Each dance will be a reaction and interaction with the local setting. The final work will highlight the diversity of the American experience. 

This is where you come in...

 

Update May 17:

96% Funded!!! I can’t thank everyone enough for their generosity!

We now have gas covered, and we are close to having food money! Next step is to start covering hotel costs ($700-1000) for the trip.

 

The Cost

This is a breakdown of the estimated costs: 

Gas money: $509.64    4,247  miles divided by  30 mpg =  141.6 gallons x $3.6/gallon =     $509.64 (http://www.eia.gov/petroleum/gasdiesel/)

Tolls: $15 for NY/NJ

Food: $25 per person/day x 11 days = 550

Hotels: estimate $100/night x 7 nights (we are hoping to crash on as many couches as possible) 

Park Admission: $25 for Grand Canyon and  $25 for Zion

Unanticipated expenses: $200

Expected cost = $2,024.64

I'm hoping to raise at least enough for gas, tolls and food, but any help no matter how much would mean a lot. 

Rewards

The main gift for your donation will be the collector's box made of a wooden printed tea box from New York that will be filled with seashells collected from the east and west coast as well as miscellaneous items I collect and create along the way (from doodles or mini poems to rocks from the grand canyon)

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't help monetarily that's ok, because there are many other ways to help out.  The biggest is if you have a place to crash along our route and can donate a couch or meal, we would be eternally grateful! 

You can also help by spreading the word to friends, family, co-workers and the local press. Any little bit helps!  

The Impact

America has some of the most diverse geography, each state is like a cultural and geographic world of it's own. As an artist I want to experience and traslate each location on my journey into movement as an interaction with my surroundings. Dance films allow site specific work like this to be composed in a way that an audience can view from thousnads of miles away. 

This will be a unique project that will create a true collection of the american experience through dance and imagery. As an artist I am always striving for new ways to create work that reflects the world around me in the most honest way possible. 

Below is the link to my vimeo page, where you can find a few short dance films and other videos of my choreographic work. Bookmark this page to check back for updates on Follow the wind...!

https://vimeo.com/chertudidance 

 

About me:

My name is Lauren Chertudi I am a chreographer, performer and filmmaker. For the last two years I have been working on my MFA in Dance at Sarah Lawrence College. I have now completed my MFA in Dance creating work of my own and  performing in a vast range of works from Renowned choreographers Martha Graham to Yvonne Rainer. After performing in world class venues like the Joyce and Danspace I think it's time to dance outside again and celebrate dance outside of the stage.

Since I haven't seen most of the United States I will be approaching each location with fresh eyes allowing me to create true site specific work. For the trip Ross will be joining me as Co-Pilot and videographer. 

 

Rough Draft Itinerary:

Washington DC

Hartsville SC

Nashville TN

New Orleans LA

Austin TX

Santa Fe NM

Grand Canyon AZ

Zion UT

San Luis Obispo CA

story:
Hello there!
 
Our show, Lil' Women-a rap musical made its debut in the 2012 Orlando Fringe Theatre Festival! This show mashes up 1800's literature from the book "Little Women" with rap music.  This show took the Fringe by storm, and we hoping to continue to expand it to a larger audience.
 
Awards we have won!
-Sold out Shows at Orlando Fringe!
-Best in Green Venue awarded by the Daily City! (voted by our fans!)
-New Producer Award
-Best New Musical in Orlando awarded by the Daily City (voted by our fans!)
 
We recently got accepted into the 2013 Chicago Fringe Festival, but we need some help getting there. This project has been such a labor of love for all the cast members involved, and we want to be able to produce the best show possible when we take it to the next stage. 
 
What We Need:

The money you contribute will assist in getting the cast to Chicago with travel expenses, (airfare, hotel) along with marketing, costumes and set pieces. Your good deeds will not go unrecoginzed, as we have lots of great perks to thank you for your generous donation!

 
Thank you.

Our show would never have been the success in Orlando that it was without our fans spreading the word about shows, voting for us to win awards, and just consistently showering us with love everyday. We truly appreciate anything you are able to give to us, and even spreading the word about this campaign is amazing.

 

Thank you. Thank you. Thank you.

story:
Short Summary

Hi, I am Valerie Tutson and I am writing on behalf of the Rhode Island Black Storytellers (RIBS) and our annual event: FUNDA FEST: A Celebration of Black Storytelling. I am one of the founders of both the organization and our Festival, and both are near and dear to my heart.

It is hard to believe that this coming January marks our 15th FUNDA FEST! We are passionate about the power of storytelling to help people know who they are, and who their neighbors are! We are committed to bringing great storytelling to our wonderfully diverse community. We know, now, more than ever, that the storytelling programs we offer are great for children and families---AND adults!

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise $3000.

YOUR CONTRIBUTION WILL BE A HUGE HELP and help us meet the overall Festival Budget so we can

*Bring family storytelling concerts to Westerly, Providence, Woonsocket and Newport

*Present a FAMILY FUNDAY at the Southside Cultural Center, including storytelling workshops with Eshu Bumpus and Victoria Burnett, vendors, and digital storytelling

*Present the 2nd Annual Liar’s Contest and Night of Spoken Word at the ROOTS Cultural Center*Underwrite tellers in schools that cannot afford a storytelling program.

*Support (ie PAY) local and national artists for their work

*Cover all the costs of running this event, including design and marketing, printing, hotel, travel, rent, administrative costs, lights, heat.

*Any money that exceeds our goal will ensure that we do not have a deficit and be used to get started on FUNDA FEST 16!

If we don’t reach our entire goal, all funds raised will go toward the FUNDA FEST budget.

For your support we offer the following perks:

$1-25-You will be listed in our Adbook and on our website as a FUNDA FEST booster or Friend

$50--we will send you a FUNDA FEST program, autographed by all the artists

$100-- we will send you an autographed storytelling CD, donated by one of our artists.

$250- Tickets to Liar's Contest and Saturday night concerts PLUS logo listing as FUNDA Sponsor on RIBS website

The Impact

FUNDA means “to teach and to learn” in the African languages of Zulu and KiSwahili. The founding RIBS members, including Rochel Coleman, Ramona Bass Kolobe, Len Cabral, Abigail Jefferson, Melodie Thompson Thomas and Raffini, decided we wanted to create a statewide storytelling event that would celebrate and showcase the beautiful diversity of the African oral art and tradition by bringing a wide range of Black storytellers to Rhode Island. We chose the week around the Martin Luther King Holiday, intentionally, to help highlight the story, and to lead our community to Black History Month in February.

Our first year, in 1999, we had 8 tellers in 4 schools and three public performances over 3 days. Last year we had 10 tellers in 41 school performances and public performances across the state, reaching over 6000 people! We now present public performances from Westerly, to Woonsocket, Providence to Newport, and school and community shows all across the region. This year’s festival will take place from January 19-27, 2013.

In the words of one of our 2012 attendees:

First, the Saturday line up at Funda was exceptional...the kids who went to the Woonsocket performance started saying Z-Ca-Mo instead of thank you...now the entire class uses that term, I was wondering if you knew the words for you're welcome? We used the Story Corp idea and had parents record a memory from their childhood. We play it throughout the day and at rest...their expressions are priceless when they hear their parent's voice, very heartwarming. Their stories are from the heart. So thanks for keeping the stories alive and sharing your creativity...

Other Ways You Can Help

Send this to everyone you know, and invite them to help present FUNDA FEST 15!

Be sure to use the indiegogo share tools.

We don’t have a lot of time, but we have enough: Many hands make light work! We can do this with your help.

Siyabonga! (We thank you, in Zulu)

story:
The Silver Stage Players are an education outreach program from The Wild Thyme Players, a non-profit, all-volunteer organization based in Knoxville, TN, and they are Tennessee’s only theatre group for senior actors. The Silver Stage Players produce original plays written by and for seniors that tackle a wide variety of senior issues with humor and insight, such as post-retirement depression, loss of a spouse, elder discrimination and the aging workforce. We have published several of our original scripts through ArtAge Publications and senior theatre companies across the country are now producing our plays.

The Silver Stage motto is, “Imagination Never Grows Old.” To us, this means there are no limits on how seniors can express themselves on stage – they can present any story they want, even Shakespeare! This June, we hope to send twelve artists from The Silver Stage Players to New Orleans, LA to participate in the Senior Theatre USA Performance Festival, where they will present a workshop on senior roles in Shakespearean plays, and perform our latest original work, “Move Over Romeo & Juliet, Here Come the Greybeards!”

Please consider supporting us in our drive to the Crescent City, where these creative seniors can share their talents and experience, and perform on stage in a national forum. We are seeking financial contributions to help pay for our travel expenses. Thank you so much for your time and for any support you are able to offer. Give what you can, and help us spread the word!

story:
My name is Sara Head, and I am a senior in the Residential College at the University of Michigan. In my final semester, I have the delight and the honor of directing a production of David Adjmi's brilliant play Marie Antoinette with the RC Players, a completely student-run organization on campus. I feel very fortunate to have found a piece of theatre that satisfies the wildest extents of my imagination. Marie Antoinette is dramatic, funny, and superbly bizarre. It is a director's dream, as is the incredible cast and crew of people I have working alongside me. 

The script has allowed me dream big in a million different ways, and I would love to be able to craft an experience for the audience that surpasses the typical boundaries of our venue and budget. Our beloved Marie never stood for anything less than over-the-top, and I hope to capture that spirit in my production. With some financial support, I will be able to achieve costumes, sets, and effects worthy of the Butterfly Queen.

In order to help fund our production, we are looking to raise $500. This will make a huge dent in covering the costs of hand-made costumes and wigs for the entire cast, an immersive and dream-like set, and promotional materials to spread the word. Every little bit counts in making this play a truly special piece of theatre. Even the smallest contributions can have a huge impact in what we are able to achieve!

 I think that this piece has the power to have a profound impact on the communities both on campus and in the world at large. Above all else, we will seek to entertain. Marie Antoinette is a production that is quirky, fun, and visually rich. It will provide an enchanting respite from the state of the world outside of the theatre. I think this is a key aspect of art’s larger purpose—it enriches the lives of those who witness it. However, I think that there are critical opportunities in the script to send a larger message to the audience, and perhaps offer insight into relevant current affairs. It is my hope that the production will inspire both its participants and its audience to exit the theater changed from the way they came in, moved to go out into the world and make a difference. Seeing what has come before in such a descriptive, accessible way can offer a world of clarity to where to begin working in the present.

This production will be only the most recent in a long line of RCP productions that have provided an outlet to students for expressing their creativity making change in the world. I could not ask for a more supportive and encouraging organization to back my project, and I wholeheartedly believe that this project will turn into something that will continue to nourish and grow a student group that has been making theatre on campus for over forty years.

If you cannot make a financial contribution to Marie Antoinette, we would love your support in other forms, whether that be sharing this page with your friends and family or coming out to the Keene Theater on March 17th or 18th to join us for our performances!
story_txt:
My name is Sara Head, and I am a senior in the Residential College at the University of Michigan. In my final semester, I have the delight and the honor of directing a production of David Adjmi's brilliant play Marie Antoinette with the RC Players, a completely student-run organization on campus. I feel very fortunate to have found a piece of theatre that satisfies the wildest extents of my imagination. Marie Antoinette is dramatic, funny, and superbly bizarre. It is a director's dream, as is the incredible cast and crew of people I have working alongside me. 
The script has allowed me dream big in a million different ways, and I would love to be able to craft an experience for the audience that surpasses the typical boundaries of our venue and budget. Our beloved Marie never stood for anything less than over-the-top, and I hope to capture that spirit in my production. With some financial support, I will be able to achieve costumes, sets, and effects worthy of the Butterfly Queen.
In order to help fund our production, we are looking to raise $500. This will make a huge dent in covering the costs of hand-made costumes and wigs for the entire cast, an immersive and dream-like set, and promotional materials to spread the word. Every little bit counts in making this play a truly special piece of theatre. Even the smallest contributions can have a huge impact in what we are able to achieve!
 I think that this piece has the power to have a profound impact on the communities both on campus and in the world at large. Above all else, we will seek to entertain. Marie Antoinette is a production that is quirky, fun, and visually rich. It will provide an enchanting respite from the state of the world outside of the theatre. I think this is a key aspect of art’s larger purpose—it enriches the lives of those who witness it. However, I think that there are critical opportunities in the script to send a larger message to the audience, and perhaps offer insight into relevant current affairs. It is my hope that the production will inspire both its participants and its audience to exit the theater changed from the way they came in, moved to go out into the world and make a difference. Seeing what has come before in such a descriptive, accessible way can offer a world of clarity to where to begin working in the present.
This production will be only the most recent in a long line of RCP productions that have provided an outlet to students for expressing their creativity making change in the world. I could not ask for a more supportive and encouraging organization to back my project, and I wholeheartedly believe that this project will turn into something that will continue to nourish and grow a student group that has been making theatre on campus for over forty years.
If you cannot make a financial contribution to Marie Antoinette, we would love your support in other forms, whether that be sharing this page with your friends and family or coming out to the Keene Theater on March 17th or 18th to join us for our performances!

story:
Short Summary

In May 2012, a young group of international actors was put together by an Italian girl willing to create something good and cultural in the city of Berlin. After a few months the group doubled its size and the faith and enthusiasm for the project grew and grew.
We are now 2 organizers and 8 actors. A great group!

The project is called Theater am Tisch, an entirely new way of consuming theatre– at the table. We tear down the famous fourth wall and actors are no longer separated by the stage, but rather come to your table and perform right there over a dinner or an aperitif- just for you! Sometimes theatre is an elite and exclusive world which a lot of people cannot enjoy: Theater am Tisch is open to all comers making it affordable for everybody, and there is no need to buy tickets (but better reserve a seat ;)!

A menu of monologues and dialogues will be handed out to the guests in bars and restaurants: they can choose to taste which and as many acts they want to see in a very personal atmosphere.

So here is how it works:

-you go to the cafè where we perform
-you have a LOOK AT OUR THEATRICAL MENU
-you discuss YOUR OPTIONS WITH YOUR FRIENDS OR TABLE MATES
-you ORDER YOUR CHOICES TO THE THEATRE WAITER
-just wait and the actor WILL ENTERTAIN YOU AT YOUR TABLE!

yes, an unique experience!

Since the beginning we have done 20 events in just 3 months, moving from bars to restaurants, from area to area. We act in 4 different languages - German, English, Spanish, Italian - in order to make it more accessible and have a wider range of audience in this international city.

We also want to further develop our project creating different big performances connected to our concept.

Since now we have been working from our personal expenses trying to give always the best to our audience.

We want even more of you to be able to experience our shows and enjoy our events, and that's why we need your support!

Your contributions are going directly towards helping us RENT A SPACE for our rehearsals and performances, and a bit for letting us take a breath for the full time administration job.

When we act as Theater am Tisch we don't need tickets and we want to offer the public what they would like to enjoy for very reasonable prices.  Because of this, we need also to ask your help so that we have coverage for the next few months for our new weekly, monthly and one shot shows as well as team training programs.

We're breaking it down this way:

Rent/Utilities for 3 months: €2500
Breath for the whole team for 3 months: €4500
Administration help: €1000

Which gives us a grand total of €8000 (10170 $).

 

So why are we asking for your support

Art, theatre should be accessible to all. We aren't selling tickets for our events and we keep really low prices to make it affordable. But this doesnt mean that our actors should not be paid to share their talents, transport themselves to and from rehearsal and maybe buy a drink after the show. We would like to provide our audience (that it is you!!) with food during the performance, as we act at the table!

In order to provide such sustenance to our actors and for better performances to our audiences, we need your financial support.

And if you donate what do you get?

A lot of nice perks and the knowledge that you are supporting a locally grown international group of professional actors that want to share their passion to everybody through this new concept.

Dont worry, if you are not Berlin based we have ready nice perks just for you!

Other Ways You Can Help

In addition to a donation, you can also help us spread the word!  

If you cant contribute we'd still like you to help us sharing our campaign on your many interweb social networking sites and try to come to one of our next events.

story:
Ο στόχος μας είναι 2000 ευρώ τα οποία θα καλύψουν:

  • μέρος των εξόδων ενοικίασης του θεάτρου
  • μέρος των εξόδων παραγωγής
  • σκηνικά & κοστούμια
  • μέρος πληρωμών των συντελεστών.


Άλλοι τρόποι που μπορείς να βοηθήσεις:

Kάνε like στη σελίδα μας στο facebook:

https://www.facebook.com/matomenosgamos/?view_p...


Προηγούμενες σκηνοθεσίες του Κωνσταντίνου Ντέλλα:

INSOMNIA GRECA (2016, Δημοτικό Θέατρο Πειραιά)

Ηλέκτρα του Σοφοκλή [το τελευταίο αίμα] (Φεστιβάλ Αθηνών 2015, με την Όλια Λαζαρίδου και τη συμμετοχή του Γιάννη Αγγελάκα)

Ο Έλλην Βρυκόλαξ (Μουσείο Μπενάκη, Δημοτικό Θέατρο Πειραιά, 2013-2015)

 

Our goal is 2000 euros which will cover:    

  • part of the theater rental costs    
  • part of production costs     
  • props & costumes    
  • part of crew payment.

Other ways you can help us:

Like us on facebook:
https://www.facebook.com/matomenosgamos/?view_p...

Previous work by Konstantinos Ntellas:

INSOMNIA GRECA (2016, Piraeus Municipal Theater)

Electra Sophocles  [last blood] (Athens Festival 2015)

The Greek Vampire (Benaki Museum, the Municipal Theatre of Piraeus, 2013-2015)

story:
PER LA DESCRIZIONE ITALIANA VAI PIU' GIU'

Who We Really Are

We are The Three Dots, a visual comedy company based in Turin.

Without the make-up we are: Mauro Groppo (Casale Monferrato ITA), Paolo Scaglia (Milan ITA) and Samuel Toye (London UK).

We are three actors that have trained together at Atelier Teatro Fisico Philip Radice, a school that teaches through the pedagogy of Jaques Le Coq (commedia dell’ arte, mime, clown, bouffon.)

Why We Need Your Help

MIMES (Most Imbecilic Mimes Ensemble Show) is our companies first production. We are excited to announce that we will perform at The Camden Fringe Festival from the 16th to the 20th of August at the Etcetera Theatre. We are seeking the support from backers and crowd funders to help us give our show the platform it deserves: an International festival in the theatre capitol of the world.

But, while on the stage, with mime we can create everything from nothing. In reality, we discovered  that the imagination is not enough ( you can not go to London with an imaginery plane).

In order to create everything from nothing we actually need something. We need your support to help us cover some essential costs. We aim to raise £2,000.

 Here is a breakdown of the costs:

  • £650   Accomodation
  • £450   Flight tickets
  • £300   Venue hire
  • £270   Technician and technical hire
  • £120   Travel (in London for a week)
  • £100   Promotion
  • £99     Camden Fringe Festival registration
  • £11     Contingency (we are optimistic)

It’s not easy for a young and independent company producing its own show, but the thing that we discovered after spending years doing devised theatre is that expressing your own creativity with freedom and passion is the real purpose of life.

Our Way To Say THANK YOU

And this is the best part. For your support we will do things that nobody has done for you before...in your entire life. The biggest prize is our entire show in your house! (yes, nobody has done OUR show in your house). We will make personalized videos and pictures of us doing anything you want ( stuff like riding an elephant or floating around the moon). We will say your name in the show (even if we are mimes) and yes we will also give you free tickets.

Thank you for taking your time to read till here. We understand that not everyone is able to support us financially but there is another way you can help us: share this campaign with all your contacts and spread the word: THE MIMES ARE COMING TO LONDON!

 

ITALIANO

Chi Siamo Veramente

Noi siamo The Three Dots, una compagnia di teatro fisico comico con base a Torino.

Senza il trucco siamo: Mauro Groppo (Casale Monferrato ITA), Paolo Scaglia (Milano ITA) e Samuel Toye (Londra UK).

Ci siamo conosciuti studiando e creando insieme all' Atelier Teatro Fisico Philip Radice, una scuola che insegna la pedagogia teatrale di Jaques Le Coq (commedia dell’ arte, mimo, clown, buffone...).

Perché Ci Serve Il Tuo Aiuto

MIMES (Most Imbecilic Mimes Ensemble Show), tradotto “il più stupido spettacolo di mimo” è la prima produzione della compagnia. Siamo eccitati di annunciare che ci esibiremo al Camden Fringe Festival di Londra dal 16 al 20 Agosto. Stiamo cercando il supporto di sostenitori e finanziatori per aiutarci a dare al nostro spettacolo il palco che si merita: un festival internazionale nella capitale mondiale del teatro.

Sul palco, con il mimo possiamo creare tutto da niente. Nella realtà però, abbiamo scoperto che l’ immaginazione non è abbastanza (non puoi andare a Londra con un aereo immaginario).

Per poter creare tutto dal niente, effettivamente ci serve qualcosa. Ci serve il tuo supporto per aiutarci a coprire alcune spese essenziali. Puntiamo a raccogliere duemila sterlina cioè circa 2300 Euro.

Qui di seguito una lista delle spese:

  • 750€ Sistemazione

  • 519€ Biglietti aerei

  • 345€ Affitto teatro

  • 310€ Tecnico e affitto tecnico

  • 140€ Trasporto (metro e bus a Londra per una settimana)

  • 110€ Promozione

  • 114€ Quota di iscrizione al Camden Fringe

  • 12€   Spese di emergenza (siamo ottimisti)

 

Non è facile per una giovane compagnia indipendente produrre il proprio spettacolo, ma quello che abbiamo imparato dopo anni passati a fare devised theatre (teatro in creazione di gruppo) è che esprimere la propria creatività con libertà e passione è il vero scopo della vita.

Il Nostro Modo Di Dire GRAZIE

E questa è la parte migliore. Per il tuo supporto noi faremo per te, cose che nessun altro ha mai fatto…nella tua intera vita. Il premio più grande è il nostro intero spettacolo a casa tua! (sì, nessuno ha mai fatto il NOSTRO spettacolo a casa tua). Ti spediremo video e foto personalizzati di noi che facciamo qualsiasi cosa tu voglia (cose come cavalcare un elefante o galleggiare attorno alla luna). Diremo il tuo nome nello spettacolo (anche se siamo mimi) e sì, ti daremo anche dei biglietti omaggio.

Grazie per aver speso il tuo tempo a leggere sino a qui. Noi capiamo che non tutti hanno la possibilità di aiutarci economicamente ma c’è anche un altro modo di aiutarci: condividi questa campagna di raccolta fondi con tutti i tuoi contatti e diffondi il verbo: I MIMI VANNO A LONDRA!

story:
The Idle Playthings have been accepted into PBH's Free Fringe (as part of the Edinburgh Fringe Festival in Scotland in August). This costs a lot of money (Just over £8000 in fact!) and we need as much help as we can get in order to make this an easier feat.

We've been raising money for two years and we're almost at a place where the costs are manageable with our performers paying a contribution each but we want to reduce this as much as possible so that the opportunity to go to the Fringe is not dictated by who can afford it.

That's where you guys come in! Any donation, no matter how big or small, makes all the difference to the Playthings. We can't wait to represent our society, our Students' Union and our University at an International level again - but we need your help to do it!

story:
Who are you?

We are Not Quite... a London-based production company co-founded by Richard Swann & Jamie Scott-Smith. 

For those who know 'the industry' well (and even for those of you who don't) there is a saying that floats around quite regularly:

"You must create your own opportunities!!"

So with that said, that is what we intend to do... we have taken a play text we love and we have decided to take it to the masses in a short run at the Leicester Square Theatre this summer.


Why did you decide to produce The Sisterhood? 

After forming Not Quite… we set about sourcing a play that helped us achieve our core company values:

  • To produce creative, engaging high quality theatrical productions in London and throughout the UK.
  • To build a strong company of diverse actors who are passionate about creating, producing and performing. 
  • To provide opportunities to talented actors who otherwise might not have the chance to perform.

With a prior knowledge of the play and after a successful rehearsed reading in a studio space in Waterloo, we were inspired to produce this comical gem in a leading London fringe venue. 

A brief synopsis: 

Henriette wishes to marry the man she adores. Is that so much to ask? 

Apparently so for this trio: her overbearing, matriarchal mother, her intellectual, sexless sister and her downright randy aunt. These “learned ladies” have quite the different suitor in mind in the shape of a pompous, bombastic and self-proclaimed 'genius' of poetry.

Set in a lavish Paris salon during the late 1980’s, 'The Sisterhood' is Ranjit Bolt’s adaptation of Molière’s classic satire, 'Les Femmes Savantes'. 

This fast-paced and intelligent comedy, satirising a family of pseudo-intellectual pontificating women, will keep you laughing throughout! 

What do you want? 

We are asking for £2000 to help fund hiring the theatre space for a run of six shows in a Central London venue. The money from this fundraiser will also help us to hire rehearsal space, purchase the set, costume and props.

We know it is a lot of money - but producing theatre is expensive.

Why Central London? Why not out of town in a cheaper venue?

We feel it is very important to premiere our production in a location that will allow industry professionals to attend; with the potential to have a positive impact on both individual actor's careers and the production's future life.

So what are we going to spend all that money on? 

  1. Venue Hire: £600 (£100 per show) 
  2. Professional Performance Rights: £390 (£65 per show)
  3. Rehearsal Space Hire: £450 (This is using the cheapest suitable spaces)
  4. Costume, Set and Props: £250
  5. Marketing: £200 (Programmes, Posters, Digital Advertising) 
  6. Contingency: £110  (The best budgets always need a little wiggle room, this is for any 'emergencies' that may arise)
The Crunch

Without forming the fundraiser this production is unlikely to make enough money to cover all of the costs outlined above. Although everyone in the company is well aware of this, we do not wish to operate as a profit-share production without any real prospect of profit (many other companies do). 

If we are able to cover production costs with this fundraiser, we can then share fairly the net box-office profit with the actors on an equal profit-share basis.

The Future

We aim to find a future for the production during this run by inviting producers, venue managers and reviewers along to the shows. Possible futures for the show could include;
A 2017 Edinburgh Festival Production, site specific performances, a further London production or a small-scale tour.
Finally...

We would be very grateful for any donation you are able to make big or small; we are aware these are testing times but please help us to get this project off the ground and give our production company a kick in the right direction. 

Thank you for your interest in our project,

Richard & Jamie
Co-Founders of Not Quite...

Show your support further by following us on social media:

Twitter: twitter.com/NotQuite_ 
Facebook: facebook.com/notquiteaproductioncompany/ 
Web: notquite.co.uk 
Tickets: www.notquite.co.uk/book
story_txt:
Who are you?We are Not Quite... a London-based production company co-founded by Richard Swann & Jamie Scott-Smith. For those who know 'the industry' well (and even for those of you who don't) there is a saying that floats around quite regularly:"You must create your own opportunities!!"So with that said, that is what we intend to do... we have taken a play text we love and we have decided to take it to the masses in a short run at the Leicester Square Theatre this summer.Why did you decide to produce The Sisterhood? 
After forming Not Quite… we set about sourcing a play that helped us achieve our core company values:

To produce creative, engaging high quality theatrical productions in London and throughout the UK.
To build a strong company of diverse actors who are passionate about creating, producing and performing. 
To provide opportunities to talented actors who otherwise might not have the chance to perform.

With a prior knowledge of the play and after a successful rehearsed reading in a studio space in Waterloo, we were inspired to produce this comical gem in a leading London fringe venue. A brief synopsis: Henriette wishes to marry the man she adores. Is that so much to ask? 
Apparently so for this trio: her overbearing, matriarchal mother, her intellectual, sexless sister and her downright randy aunt. These “learned ladies” have quite the different suitor in mind in the shape of a pompous, bombastic and self-proclaimed 'genius' of poetry.
Set in a lavish Paris salon during the late 1980’s, 'The Sisterhood' is Ranjit Bolt’s adaptation of Molière’s classic satire, 'Les Femmes Savantes'. 
This fast-paced and intelligent comedy, satirising a family of pseudo-intellectual pontificating women, will keep you laughing throughout! What do you want? We are asking for £2000 to help fund hiring the theatre space for a run of six shows in a Central London venue. The money from this fundraiser will also help us to hire rehearsal space, purchase the set, costume and props.We know it is a lot of money - but producing theatre is expensive.Why Central London? Why not out of town in a cheaper venue?We feel it is very important to premiere our production in a location that will allow industry professionals to attend; with the potential to have a positive impact on both individual actor's careers and the production's future life.So what are we going to spend all that money on? 

Venue Hire: £600 (£100 per show) 


Professional Performance Rights: £390 (£65 per show)


Rehearsal Space Hire: £450 (This is using the cheapest suitable spaces)


Costume, Set and Props: £250


Marketing: £200 (Programmes, Posters, Digital Advertising) 


Contingency: £110  (The best budgets always need a little wiggle room, this is for any 'emergencies' that may arise)

The Crunch
Without forming the fundraiser this production is unlikely to make enough money to cover all of the costs outlined above. Although everyone in the company is well aware of this, we do not wish to operate as a profit-share production without any real prospect of profit (many other companies do). 
If we are able to cover production costs with this fundraiser, we can then share fairly the net box-office profit with the actors on an equal profit-share basis.
The FutureWe aim to find a future for the production during this run by inviting producers, venue managers and reviewers along to the shows. Possible futures for the show could include; A 2017 Edinburgh Festival Production, site specific performances, a further London production or a small-scale tour.
Finally...
We would be very grateful for any donation you are able to make big or small; we are aware these are testing times but please help us to get this project off the ground and give our production company a kick in the right direction. Thank you for your interest in our project,Richard & Jamie Co-Founders of Not Quite...Show your support further by following us on social media:Twitter: twitter.com/NotQuite_ Facebook: facebook.com/notquiteaproductioncompany/  Web: notquite.co.uk Tickets: www.notquite.co.uk/book

story:
Help us grow.

Blue House Arts is the newest addition to the San Francisco Theatre scene aiming to diversify the audience’s experience by collaborating with artists of different backgrounds and disciplines. Our first show is about time and loneliness— love and acceptance. CLOUD TECTONICS sings with harmony and grit to show us miracles hidden in our every day lives. 

We have been extremely lucky to have many donors who have trusted us and helped us with our first season and our first show—from The Thick House in being incredibly generous and supportive, to the people who have helped us in making this campaign possible!


A good portion of our budget goes into paying our artists and we want to compensate them fairly for their endless energies, talents and time. That means equal stipends for every artist who has trusted us and joined us in meaningful, impactful and reflective art—regardless of their role in the production, gender, or age. BUT in the pursuit of positive communal change—and turn ideas into actions— we need YOUR help. 

Our community is like a forest. Bigger trees help smaller plants grow. Help us grow with each other and enrich our community.  No one tree can make a beautiful forest.

If you did not enjoy our first production as much as we hoped you would, we will gladly refund you your hard earned money.

When: January 21st - January 30th. (Thursday through Saturday).
Where: Thick House, 1695 18th St, San Francisco, CA 94107

We'll see you there!

story:
Short Summary

Stephanie Unger & Artists is an East Bay collaborative contemporary dance theatre project that focuses on telling stories of human emotions and experiences. After our recent show, “What Is She Doing?,” Stephanie Unger & Artists is hosting a festival to continue the conversation. We have asked “How do you experience society’s pressures upon womxn?” to a wide variety of artists and have selected a broad range of voices. This festival, entitled Broad Statements, will be March 6, 7, and 8, 2020 and will showcase a variety of artists from the Bay Area and beyond. Your support of this campaign will allow the artists the possibility of receiving a portion of the ticket sales.

What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking to cover the costs of the venue rental and marketing for the festival. Having these costs covered by this fundraising campaign will allow a portion of the ticket sales to be allocated to the presenting artists. 

In exchange for your support, we have a variety of exciting perks! From swag items to show tickets and VIP treatment, you won’t be disappointed with what you get for the money you donate.

This is a fundraiser has a flexible goal. While that means that Indiegogo will take a percentage of the funds we raise, it also means that it’s not “all or nothing.” All donations will go directly to support the artists of Broad Statements.

The Impact

“Broad Statements” is an excellent project to give dancers and choreographers of all gender expressions and backgrounds a public forum to embody and express their perspectives on womxnhood. With so much interest in the wider culture in women’s representation and increasing focus on gender politics, we think it’s important in 2020 for the arts to engage with the broad spectrum of pressure upon womxn and womxn’s experiences in society.

Risks & Challenges

Stephanie Unger & Artists, the host company for the festival, has successfully produced two evening-length shows. Both of those shows were fully funded by private donations, including Indiegogo campaigns.

If we are not able to reach our goal, we will not be able to fully allocate ticket sales to the presenting artists. The more support we can receive, the more the artists are paid for their valuable work.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this campaign! Email, social media, or even just tell a friend.

Buy a ticket to the show! Buy a ticket to multiple shows (each night is a different program).

Volunteer! We will need a few volunteers to help with lights and sound for the festival.

story:
Daniel Flores Dance will present ALAS PA' VOLAR (Wings to Fly): A Dance Tribute to Frida Kahlo. 
As one of the most recognizable cultural icons of Mexico, Frida Khalo's work and life has become a source of inspiration to many artists worldwide. In this evening of dance, we will reimagine some of Kahlo's paintings and life into dance (including The Wounded Deer, Girl with Death Mask, Self-portrait with Cropped Hair, among others).  DFD will intertwine modern dance and Mexican folk dance in celebration of the ever-present Mexicanity in Kahlo's work, as well as her continual influence on contemporary arts & culture. 

To make this evening possible, we are seeking your help to cover all basic production costs, including rehearsal studio rental, venue rental, costumes, photography, videography, props, and most importantly, to compensate the work of all collaborating artists.

Director by Daniel Flores

Choreographed by Daniel Flores in collaboration with the performers.

Performers: Hannah Kearny, Pilar Maez, Sashalie Rios, Wendy Caravantes.

Costume designer: Elizabeth Cervantes

We are offering a great set of perks in gratitude for your support!

If you are unable to contribute to our campaign but would still like to help us because you believe in the work we're creating, please share our campaign, or better yet... 

COME TO OUR SHOW!

Online, pre-sale tickets here.

March 16 & 16, 2019 8PM

Bridge for Dance Studios
2726 Broadway, 3rd FL 
New York, NY 10025

Thank you for your time!

Daniel Flores, Director & Choreographer (Daniel Flores Dance)

story:
Our Story

I have always been a fan of great stories that not only touched, scared, shocked, excited, or just made you feel but that also left you thinking; contemplating the ever reaching possibilities of imagined circumstances and the real world reactions in your own life. I have a passionate love affair with these types of stories and those who tell them. It is that passion that drives me to tell stories that are not only interesting, but that you hopefully take with you for some time after the show. My mission with IMAGINATIVE REALITY PRODUCTIONS is to give life to inspiring and thought-provoking creations of the highest standards of quality for print media, internet content, film & television, and the stage.

 

IRIS is no different. In a nutshell, it is basically about a young woman's journey through hell, but going deeper, it explores our life's decisions - the causes and the known/unforseen consequences of those decisions. Too many times we don't think about them until it's too late. I hope that this show gets people to think about the decisions they make, and how they might have a bigger consequence than just right now...

 

Now with Dan Martin set to direct the piece, we have a powerful opportunity to reach so many more people with this and it will help to springboard us into the new year and give us unique opportunities to help other deserving creative artists showcase their talents on film, the web, and on stage!

 

"I believe that true artists are touched by God to inspire and encourage His children; to reveal the very best and worst of ourselves, that we can move closer to what He dreams of us becoming. True artists are very often deemed crazy because they often don't think like the normal of society, but they're artists... who would want them to. Just sit back and enjoy the show, for to watch a true artist at work is to see a miracle happen before your very eyes. I am forever an artist and a fan of any artist in the never ending search of perfection in their craft."

 

~Jaimyon Parker, writer & producer

The Impact

This piece is one that I believe can truly help others and obviously I'm not alone! We've brought on board our team R.A.I.N.N. (Rape Abuse Incest National Network - http://www.rainn.org) and will be donating part of the proceeds from the show to this very worthwhile and much needed charity. Proceeds from the show will also be going to benefit OUR COMMITMENT, INC (www.ourcommitment.org), a non-profit organization whose myriad of projects and programs are constantly helping to change and impact our communities across the nation in a positive manner!

 

This will be my 4th stage production that I have written and produced, and with your help, the best one yet. IRIS will be the launching pad for me in this coming year to help me bring quality entertainment with a thought-provoking & inspiring message to as many people as possible. By helping us with a donation and spreading the word about the play, you become an integral part of this success story. Success garnered not from the amount of dollars earned (although, let's be real, that does count), but by the people who are touched and inspired and made to think and consider.

 

With a lot of hard work, perseverence, and dedication, we will start in Los Angeles and travel across the country and eventually the world, inpiring and challenging audiences all over to think, be better, and achieve more. The universal messages in any of my pieces are designed to resonate with anyone from anywhere. Life's universal truths speak to us all differently, but they always speak to us, and I believe that we can spur on that conversation between each other and make a positive impact in our neighborhood, society, country, and world.

Budgetary Needs & What You Get

IRIS BUDGET BREAKDOWN (4 week run of Fri - Sun):

 

Theater: $2400.00

Talent (5 person cast): $2400.00

Director: $600.00

Tech: $500.00

Set/Props: $500.00

Incidental Expenses: $200.00

 

TOTAL: $6600.00

 

As you can see this is a VERY modest budget but one that we feel will still allow us to put on a very high quality production.

All donations are tax deductible through our 501c-3 non-profit partner, OUR COMMITMENT, INC. (www.ourcommitment.org). Any and all donations, big and small, help get us closer to our goal! Your $10, $20, $100, or $1000 are so very important and we, the producers of IRIS, humbly thank you from the bottom of our hearts! PLUS: YOU GET VIP PERKS FOR DONATING! (see descriptions to the right)

Other Ways You Can Help

Your prayers and positive energy are ALWAYS welcomed and necessary! Please tell as many people as you know about our project. Direct everyone you know here and to our website! POST ABOUT US ON FACEBOOK, TWITTER, LINKED IN, ETC!

MOST IMPORTANTLY: COME SEE THE SHOW!!! Raising the money then spending the time and energy to put on an amazing production will be worth nothing at all with out YOU (that's right, YOU, sitting there reading this right now! I am actually talking to YOU specifically!!!)! This production will never be a success unless we have YOU involved! TOGETHER WE ALL ACHIEVE MORE!

I am actually talking to YOU specifically!!!)! This production will never be a success unless we have YOU involved! TOGETHER WE ALL ACHIEVE MORE!

story:
The Show

Conceived, scripted and performed by the spoken word artist Isadora Vibes, Intravenous is the performance poetry equivalent of a shot in the arterial main vein. Presenting intimately confessional material, this is a compelling one woman show capturing all that it means to be female.

Heart rending, soul searching, gut wrenching - this is a tongue punching lick of a show.

The Ask

I am asking people to either

  • donate money to a specific requirement as above OR
  • pay for a perk - for a small amount you can get your own haiku, poem or adult flash fiction specifically written for you by me!

Getting a show together costs money. With your help I can pay for things like

  • production
  • audio & visual technical support
  • costumes, lighting, staging
  • travel & accommodation

Other Ways You Can Help

Tell everyone about me, the show, me, the show, me, the show! Every tweet, Facebook like, sharing of promotional materials helps.
 
This is my time and I'm thrilled about it. I can promise that every penny you donate will be intravenously inserted into the coffers and spent wisely!

story:
Hello, my name is Nikalas Chappell. I'm currently a freshman dance major attending The University of the Arts located in Philadelphia, PA. I am now in the process of organizing a week long dance based trip to Brussels, Belgium in order to study with various teachers, network, meet new artists, and learn about European culture. I am thinking of relocating to a city in Europe to enhance my dance career at some point in the future.

I have been dancing for 7 years starting in the 5th grade, auditioning and attending Bak Middle School of the Arts, Dreyfoos School of the Arts for high school, and The University of the Arts. My main focus in dance is hip hop, but I am inclined to learn all styles in order to diversify myself to become more applicable to the contemporary art culture.

Your contributions will cover an airline ticket to Brussels, Belgium costing approximately $1,300, cost of food, transportation, dance classes, and visits to cultural events. I am looking for any donations that you could give to help with this journey. Please pass this along! Who knows, maybe this trip will create a European link for professional work for the future. Thank you!!

story:
Stories are the currency of human contact.

- Robert McKee

Seven League Boots is an innovative new theatre company dedicated to breaking down traditional barriers between audience and performance. We create theatre that actively engages audiences and invites them to engage with us in return. We have spent the past year building a strong foundation for our company and we are excited to launch our inaugural season.

WHY INTERACTIVE THEATRE?

Theatre is too often a passive experience. Whether watching Hamlet recite his famous soliloquy or Spiderman swing from the rafters, audience members are frequently disconnected from the art happening directly in front of them.

But what if you could ask Hamlet why he is so depressed? What if he answered? What if Spiderman asked for your help to find his nemesis and save the day? What if he couldn’t do it without you?

We at Seven League Boots believe in the transformative power of live performance. There is magic in that unique relationship between audience member and performer; it is there that theatre can nurture the exchange of ideas, promote positive human interaction, and foster engagement in a community.

Everything we do will strengthen that relationship. Our audiences will know that their actions and ideas matter.

HOW ARE WE GOING TO DO THAT?

We are currently in the process of building our first season, which will include experiences in three categories:

For Audiences

Interactive productions of both original and existing works that invite audiences to experience live performance in new and exciting ways. At a Seven League Boots show, you’ll be so involved, you may even influence the outcome.

For Artists

Professional development workshops in varied disciplines made available and affordable to our fellow artists.

For Students

Performances and master classes that bring our unique brand of theatre into schools and make learning come alive for students of all ages.

Check out a sneak peek of our first project, Robin Hood in a Box, in our Gallery!

WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP 

We are committed to breaking down barriers not only between the audience and the performance, but also the traditional barriers to seeing theatre in the first place. In New York City in particular, theatre ticket prices are prohibitively expensive. 

We can’t change the price of existing Broadway shows, but we will offer our own theatrical experiences at an affordable price.

In order to share our vision and bring accessible interactive theatre to our community, we need your help to build a modest operating budget for the year.

We can’t do it alone, so let’s do it together! (hey, like our mission!)

WHERE DOES YOUR DONATION GO?

Your generous donations contribute to our mission in many ways, for example:

As little as $5 creates handcrafted bracelets for 25 children at our shows and workshops – these bracelets are an integral part of our Robin Hood in a Box show, a symbol that each child is now part of Robin Hood’s merry band and a token for them to remember the show and their role in the story.

$50 covers minimum transportation costs for our entire company to and from a single school show or workshop in the NYC area, potentially reaching up to 500 children.

$500 allows us to rent rehearsal space to create and polish a full production.

$2000 buys us costumes and props for a period-specific show, such as those focused on Robin Hood, the Victorian era, or one of the Shakespeare productions we are currently planning. 

$5000 rents a theater space for the entire production run of a single show.

Finally, $10,000 can bring our company and our mission to theaters and festivals across the country, allowing us to reach a whole new audience.

We know you work hard for your money, and your choice to donate to our cause humbles us and drives our ambition to create theatre of the highest attainable quality. We promise to use every penny you donate in the most efficient, effective manner possible. 

ABOUT OUR NAME

Seven League Boots have existed in folklore for centuries, allowing the wearer to travel incredible distances in a single step. Like our mythical counterparts, we will take you on a journey someplace new, to experience theatre as you never have before. 

Together, we’ll go farther. With each step, we’ll take you seven leagues...

PLEASE HELP IF YOU CAN 

We invite you to be part of the change, helping us bring art to audiences in a whole new way and thereby changing their perception of and interaction with art in the world around them.

If you are unable to donate, that is perfectly fine. We appreciate your support in simply reading this far! You can also help us by sharing this Indiegogo campaign, Liking us on Facebook, following us on Twitter, and telling your friends about “this exciting new company I heard about....” 

Thank you so much for your support.

 

Find us on Facebook – www.facebook.com/7LBoots

Follow us on Twitter – @7_leagueboots
story_txt:
Stories are the currency of human contact. 
- Robert McKee
Seven League Boots is an innovative new theatre company dedicated to breaking down traditional barriers between audience and performance. We create theatre that actively engages audiences and invites them to engage with us in return. We have spent the past year building a strong foundation for our company and we are excited to launch our inaugural season.
WHY INTERACTIVE THEATRE?
Theatre is too often a passive experience. Whether watching Hamlet recite his famous soliloquy or Spiderman swing from the rafters, audience members are frequently disconnected from the art happening directly in front of them.
But what if you could ask Hamlet why he is so depressed? What if he answered? What if Spiderman asked for your help to find his nemesis and save the day? What if he couldn’t do it without you?
We at Seven League Boots believe in the transformative power of live performance. There is magic in that unique relationship between audience member and performer; it is there that theatre can nurture the exchange of ideas, promote positive human interaction, and foster engagement in a community.
Everything we do will strengthen that relationship. Our audiences will know that their actions and ideas matter.
HOW ARE WE GOING TO DO THAT?
We are currently in the process of building our first season, which will include experiences in three categories:
For Audiences
Interactive productions of both original and existing works that invite audiences to experience live performance in new and exciting ways. At a Seven League Boots show, you’ll be so involved, you may even influence the outcome.
For Artists
Professional development workshops in varied disciplines made available and affordable to our fellow artists.
For Students
Performances and master classes that bring our unique brand of theatre into schools and make learning come alive for students of all ages.
Check out a sneak peek of our first project, Robin Hood in a Box, in our Gallery!
WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP 
We are committed to breaking down barriers not only between the audience and the performance, but also the traditional barriers to seeing theatre in the first place. In New York City in particular, theatre ticket prices are prohibitively expensive. 
We can’t change the price of existing Broadway shows, but we will offer our own theatrical experiences at an affordable price.
In order to share our vision and bring accessible interactive theatre to our community, we need your help to build a modest operating budget for the year.
We can’t do it alone, so let’s do it together! (hey, like our mission!)
WHERE DOES YOUR DONATION GO?
Your generous donations contribute to our mission in many ways, for example:
As little as $5 creates handcrafted bracelets for 25 children at our shows and workshops – these bracelets are an integral part of our Robin Hood in a Box show, a symbol that each child is now part of Robin Hood’s merry band and a token for them to remember the show and their role in the story.
$50 covers minimum transportation costs for our entire company to and from a single school show or workshop in the NYC area, potentially reaching up to 500 children.
$500 allows us to rent rehearsal space to create and polish a full production.
$2000 buys us costumes and props for a period-specific show, such as those focused on Robin Hood, the Victorian era, or one of the Shakespeare productions we are currently planning. 
$5000 rents a theater space for the entire production run of a single show.
Finally, $10,000 can bring our company and our mission to theaters and festivals across the country, allowing us to reach a whole new audience.
We know you work hard for your money, and your choice to donate to our cause humbles us and drives our ambition to create theatre of the highest attainable quality. We promise to use every penny you donate in the most efficient, effective manner possible. 
ABOUT OUR NAME
Seven League Boots have existed in folklore for centuries, allowing the wearer to travel incredible distances in a single step. Like our mythical counterparts, we will take you on a journey someplace new, to experience theatre as you never have before. 
Together, we’ll go farther. With each step, we’ll take you seven leagues...
PLEASE HELP IF YOU CAN 
We invite you to be part of the change, helping us bring art to audiences in a whole new way and thereby changing their perception of and interaction with art in the world around them.
If you are unable to donate, that is perfectly fine. We appreciate your support in simply reading this far! You can also help us by sharing this Indiegogo campaign, Liking us on Facebook, following us on Twitter, and telling your friends about “this exciting new company I heard about....” 
Thank you so much for your support.
 
Find us on Facebook – www.facebook.com/7LBoots
Follow us on Twitter – @7_leagueboots

story:
THE FINAL FILMS:

The REWARD Movie

The PUNISHMENT Movie

 

PAST EPISODES:

Guest Artists - Taylor Bibat & The Noah Ginex Puppet Company - Name That Movie

Artist #6 - Quinten - Poetic Exercise

Artist #5 - Sam - Juggling Leprosy

Artist #4 - Ellen - Art Car

Artist #3 - Jennie - Fever Dance

Artist #2 - Chloe - Makeup Blindfold

Artist #1 - Freddie - Cold Shower

 

WHAT IS GOOD TIME TORTURE?

The Good Time Torture Campaign is a competitive fundraiser to support The Island Theatre Company's 2nd producing season in 2013. 

Every week, a new contestant will be assigned a challenge by the GOOD TIME TORTURE band.  This challenge is based on special creative skills each contestant submits prior to participating.  Video footage of each challenge will be posted to Facebook.com/IslandTheatreCo every Monday throughout the campaign.  You, the audience, will then have 7 days to vote whether each contestant is rewarded or punished for their effort.

 

WHAT DO YOU MEAN - REWARDED OR PUNISHED?

Prior to competing, each contestant also submits a list of their wishes and fears.  THE GOOD TIME TORTURE band uses this information to create a musical video, with the contestant, for your enjoyment.  Reward videos will feature the contestant's wishes, while punishment videos will exploit their fears. 

Each video will also be released at Facebook.com/IslandTheatreCo, during our GOOD TIME TORTURE GRAND FINALE, towards the final days of our campaign.  So, once you donate to reward or punish a contestant, stay tuned to see their wildest dreams or deepest fears come true!

 

HOW DO I VOTE?

To reward this week's contestant, you may donate any amount ending in $8.

To punish this week's contestant, you may donate any amount ending in $9.

 

IS THERE ANY OTHER WAY TO VOTE?  I REALLY WANT TO PUNISH THAT GUY!

Every Facebook "like" that we earn at Facebook.com/IslandTheatreCo will count as 1 vote for this week's contestant.  So, if you've already donated, but really wanna stick it to this week's contestant, send our video to a few friends and ask them for their support.  After you like The Island, you can send us a message, a wall post, or tag us in a comment indicating "REWARD" or "PUNISHMENT".

 

OKAY.  BUT WHAT IS "THE ISLAND THEATRE COMPANY"?

The Island is a theatre collective based in Chicago, Illinois.  Our mission is to immerse audiences in theatrical events that examine what it means to be alive - here, now, and next to each other. 

2012 marked the first producing season of The Island Theatre Company, but it was actually founded in 2009.  Since then, The Island has grown into 12 versatile ensemble members, 2 Artistic Associates, and a full executive staff.  It is with terrific momentum and enthusiasm that we greet 2013.

To learn more about The Island, visit us at: TheIslandTheatreCo.org.

 

WHAT SHOWS WILL THE ISLAND BE PRODUCING IN 2013?

The Island's 2013 Mainstage Season

The Fever

Written by Wallace Shawn                                                                                       

Performed by Quinten Quintero* and Derek Van Barham

March 7 - April 7, 2013

In our first production of 2013, two actors will be going on a tour of Chicago livng rooms performing Wallace Shawn's Obie Award-winning play, The Fever.  While visiting a poverty-stricken country far from home, the unnamed narrator of The Fever is forced to witness the political persecution occuring just beyond his hotel window.  In examining a life of comfort and relative privilege, the narrator reveals, "I always say to my friends, we should be glad to be alive.  We should celebrate life.  We should understand that life is wonderful."  But how does one understand life - take pleasure in beauty, for instance - while slowly becoming aware that the poverty and oppression of other human beings are a direct consequence of one's own pleasureable life?  Audiences have the option of booking the performer of their choice for a date and time convenient to them for a private, in-home viewing of the play especially for them and whoever they choose to invite!                                                                                                 

Book Your Own Performance: TheIslandTheatreCo.org/Creations/Happening-Now

Watch The Fever Trailer: vimeo.com/islandtheatreco/thefever

 

The Glass Inward

Directed by Anna Henson** and Mike Steele*

Featuring Shawn Escarciga, Ellen Kirk*, Quinten Quintero*, and Jennie Winston*

August 2013

Inspired by the novel Orlando by Virginia Woolf, this walk-through performance installation gives viewers an immersive look at one of the most unique protagonists ever to appear in modern literature.  Utilizing live performance, film, photography, projection, and installation design, this event brings us up close and personal with the main character's many affairs and tribulations, which are encountered first as a man and later as a woman following a mysterious transformation.  This sweeping, surreal story takes the audience across landscapes, through centuries, and deep into the heart of a wayward soul.  

 

The Patient

Written by Sam Hicks*

October - November 2013

This noir retelling of the French horror story Le Horla by Guy de Maupassant has been translated from the French and adapted for the stage by Island Ensemble Member Sam Hicks.  The claustrophobic play tests the boundaries of truth and memory as its characters are forced to face a terrifying question: what will succeed humanity as the master of our planet? This suspense-filled thriller will premiere just in time for Halloween. 

 

The Island's Second Helping Series

These theatrical oddities will also be produced during 2013 as special limited-run events. 

 

A Simple Lesson in Baking with Marie Antoinette

Written and Performed by Elizabeth Lovelady*

March 29, April 6, & 14

Learn to bake with Marie Antoinette in this interactive, historical soiree!  Doors will open at 10:15 in case you'd like to mingle with Her Majesty.  $15 buys you entrance as a peasant, while $30 admits you as a member of the aristocracy.

 

SHARK/MAN

 

Written by Frederick Ford Beckley*

August 2013

An interactive musical adventure based on both My Fair Lady and Frankenstein, this piece utilizes sight, sound, taste, touch, and smell.  Audience members can hope to encounter sailors, sea monsters, and snacks. 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                    

An End of Season Surprise

T.B.A.

(We'd like to tell you, but it's a surprise.)  

 

WHAT IS THE ISLAND THEATRE COMPANY USING MY DONATION TO DO?

Our goal is to raise $6,000 to improve our marketing resources, pay venue rental fees, and employ the highest quality artists we can find.  Your generous donations, combined with ticket revenue, touring revenue, grants, and the proceeds from our special events, will fuel our growth into 2014.

Your contribution will go towards:

  • Performance Space for our 2013 Productions
  • Production Expenses for Costumes, Props, and Set Materials
  • Marketing Material such as Posters, Magnets, and Merchandise
  • Application Fee for our Independent 501(c)3 Status
  • Maintenance for our Brand New Rehearsal and Office Space in Logan Square
  • Every Artist who makes this season possible

 

If you prefer to support The Island via mail-in donation, please address your check as payable to FRACTURED ATLAS.  You may mail your donation to:

The Island Theatre Company

 2456 N. Hamlin Ave, Unit G

       Chicago, IL 60647


We are so appreciative of any support you are able to give, be it financially, in the online world, or by word of mouth.  Our reason for being is to enthrall, mystify, and entertain people like you.  When you help us out, you are making that possible.

 

 

*denotes Island Ensemble Member

**denotes Island Artistic Associate

story:
Our Story

Drive Theatre Company is a brand new Los Angeles-based theatre company that's dedicated to producing bold American plays.  Co-artistic directors Timothy Koch and Doug Oliphant founded Drive Theatre in late 2011 over several milkshakes, slices of pie, and beer.  With Drive Theatre, we're paving a road for us to gain valuable experience as directors and provide the same opportunity for other emerging artists--actors, playwrights, designers, etc.--so that we may one day emerge as nationally working theatre artists.


In pursuit of connecting with the national theatre community, we've secured performance rights for our inaugural production, 44 Plays for 44 Presidents by Andy Bayiates, et al.  Our production will be part of a national festival whose hope is to have 44 separate productions of the play happen concurrently around the country on the night of the 2012 presidential election.  Major players already a part of the festival include Chicago's Neo-Futurists and Atlanta's Dad's Garage.  Drive Theatre Company is the sole company representing Los Angeles.


On a more immediate level, we're producing a monthly new play development series where we work with a new playwright each month.  The process will culminate in two or three workshop performances of the play put up in various spaces around Los Angeles.  For the month of March, recent New York City transplant Steve Sherman will be our featured playwright.  His play Stained Glass Windows will receive its workshop production with us before going on to its world premiere this September at Orlando Shakespeare Theater in Orlando, Florida.  


The Impact

This fundraising campaign is dedicated to helping Drive Theatre Company get started and establish a base-budget.  By donating, you will be enabling us to carry out our monthly new play development series, benefiting new playwrights, directors and actors in Los Angeles.  Your contributions will also go toward funding 44 Plays for 44 Presidents, set to open October 11th, 2012 and run for 13 performances, closing on election night.


Without your help, such ambitions would not be possible.  We would not represent Los Angeles in the national Plays for Presidents festival, we would not develop new plays each month, and we and our peers would not grow as theatre artists through this company.  Your donation matters.


What We Need & What You Get

We need $7,000 to produce 44 Plays for 44 Presidents alone.  We're only hoping to raise $2,500 through this initial campaign, much of which will go toward expenses accrued from the new play development series and our basic start-up costs.  Over the next 6 months, we'll be raising additional funds through our monthly new play development series, specialty workshops and various fun, carnival-style events at local establishments. Here's how that $2500 is being distributed:


  • 44 Plays for 44 Presidents - Reimbursing us for performance rights and scripts purchased ($1042.81) and covering a small portion of upcoming production expenses ($500)
  • Start-Up Costs - Reimbursing us for website domain/hosting/template/design software, business cards, meeting expenses and the 7% fee IndieGoGo and credit cards deduct from total raised in this campaign (approx. $400)
  • New Play Development Series - Over the next 6 months, we'll be paying for copies of scripts, ink, basic props, set pieces, and potential rehearsal/performance fees (approx. $600)

 

Here's what you get when you donate:


Lilâ€™ Bit - $10

Profile on our Website

Personalized Stage Direction from Tim & Doug


Sister Aloysius - $15

Hand Written Thank You Card

Profile on our Website

Personalized Stage Direction from Tim & Doug


Joe & Edna - $25

Promotional Space on the Drive Theatre Website for your business, blog, show or service!

James Tyrone Sr.  - $1000

Executive Producer Credit for the 2012 Season

Complimentary Tickets to  all productions in Drive Theatreâ€™s 2012 Season

Private Dinner with Tim & Doug

Promotional Space on the Drive Theatre Website for your business, blog, show or service!

Stylish â€œDrive Theatre Companyâ€ Pin

Exclusive â€œDrive Theatre Companyâ€ Sticker

Hand Written Thank You Card

Profile on our Website

Personalized Stage Direction from Tim & Doug


Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word!  Word-of-mouth is the best way to get people interested, but utilizing social media is pretty great too.  Share this on Facebook, Tweet about it on Twitter, even email someone you think may be interested in helping.  Through your help, we'll reach far more people and you become a vital force behind our success.

Spread the word!  Word-of-mouth is the best way to get people interested, but utilizing social media is pretty great too.  Share this on Facebook, Tweet about it on Twitter, even email someone you think may be interested in helping.  Through your help, we'll reach far more people and you become a vital force behind our success.

story:
Hi my name is Carlos Milan, I have been an actor on and off for over 30 years. I am trying to bring the fabulous and very timely play "Men On The Verge Of A His-Panic Breakdown" by Guillermo Reyes (Produced by special arrangement with The Dramatic Publishing Company of Woodstock, Illinois) to the stage for one final performance, mine, before I am too old to play Federico!

I performed this show in the past and was very well received by the audience. Reading the script recently I realized how timely and topical the issues covered in it are. Twenty years and we are still talking about immigration, gay marriage, what it means to be American, war, terror, and our endless search for love and a community to belong to.

By contributing to this campaign you will help me bring to the audience, in a funny and insightful way, the vicissitudes of being gay, hispanic and an immigrant in America, although some of the themes are universal and cross gender and ethnic lines. (Produced by special arrangement with The Dramatic Publishing Company of Woodstock, Illinois)

Dates

Nov. 2, 3, 9, 10, 16, 17 @ 8 pm

 

At The L-Train, 900 Central Avenue, St. Petersburg.

For more information, please call 727-265-5898

Synopsis

"Men On The Verge Of A His-Panic Breakdown" by Guillermo Reyes. is a series of comedic monologues, which the New York Times called "Glorious," chronicling the lives of various Latino immigrants dealing with transcultural shock of race and gender identity known as the "Hispanic breakdown." The play is bracketed by the misadventures of the naive Frederico or "The Gay Little Immigrant That Could" who arrives in Los Angeles during the first day of the 1992 riots and culminates with his assimilation into the American fabric. He is here to stay! Other characters include Vinnie, a kept boy being asked to leave the home of his wealthy sugar daddy because he's turned 30 and sees himself forced to find a new place and identity; Edward, a Latino actor passing for Anglo who gets a Latino part and has to come to terms with his real identity; the Demon Roommate, a lonely young man, the son of Chile's leading torturer and the impact of that upbringing while living a little too close to the airport; Paco, a Cuban restauranteur who was imprisoned by the Communists in Cuba for being gay and has now been exiled by his right-wing Miami family for the same reason; the Teacher, a stuffy, sexually repressed English-language instructor who abuses his Latino students when they can't learn properly the "language of Princess Di"; and La Gitana, a drag Flamenco dancer struggling with AIDS as he stages his final performance. The play ends with Federico's final misadventure as he tells of his newly found romance, a better job and his acquisition of citizenship in a grand, positive finale. "Some of the characters seem to be hanging onto their American existence by a thread, but make no mistake, these are tough, tenacious men."

Where will your funds go to:

All funds will go toward paying for the venue, royalties, costumes, props, advertising materials. The actor, the stage manager, lighting, photographer, etc. are doing this because of their passion for theatre. Once all costs associated with the production are met, we hope to provide a stipend to the wonderful cast and crew that will be working on the show. If our goal is not met by the deadline, I am not sure how we'll do it, but we will put on the show regardless. Who knows, maybe if it's a rousing success we can take it on tour. These guys need their voices heard. Thanks Guillermo Reyes, for given them the chance.

To those who are unable to make a contribution, please consider coming to see the show or spread the word about it. Shout it from rooftops if necessary. Ok, that last thing may be a bit too much. But please support us and support local theatre in your communities. And always keep on keeping on!

With my utmost gratitude,

Carlos Milan and the Little Players that Could.
