story:
Who is Sarah Sparkles?

My name is Sarah Marsh, or Sarah Sparkles when I am performing (because I love glitter, sequins, sparkles, etc!). My dream, since I was a little girl, has been to join the circus and now I have a chance to train with the best! Only 10 were selected to join the 3-week boot camp at The New England Center for Circus Arts and I made the cut!

As an aerialist and performer in Austin, Texas, I would like to boost my skills in order to make performing my full time gig. I LOVE IT!!! Dancing is my passion and hanging from my lyra is even better. :-)

As of recent, I have been nominated for Best Aerial Hoop Choreographer and Best Aerial Hoop Instructor at the 5th Annual Miss Texas Polestar Competition!!! I've also been chosen as a finalist in the Professional Lyra (aerial hoop) category at the same competition, which will be October 10th & 11th, 2014 in Dallas, TX.

What I Need & What You Get

Here's why I need the money:

  • Tuition is expensive, $1,000 to be exact.
  • Lodging is also expensive, $300 (not as expensive as a hotel for 3 weeks).
  • Food & Flight cost a good chunk of change too!
  • By helping me you will receive my gratitude as well as a few gifts of my appreciation.

If I don't reach my goal, the money donated will still go towards my tuition and/ or room and board. Every little bit helps.

The Impact

This training will help me refine my skills and help me create more dynamic and exciting movement, I could be in the next Cirque production!!! ;-)

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share this with your friends and on Facebook!
  • Send me good vibes and prayers!
  • Donate Southwest Airlines flight points
  • Vote for me as "Best Lyra Instructor" and/or "Best Lyra Choreographer" at MissTexasPolestar.com

story:
In a Lower East Side bar combine:
4 parts downtown theatre 
3 parts live music 
2 parts love story 
1 part farce 
3 dashes of opera
Shake vigorously and garnish with a flight of cocktails designed by award-winning mixologist Marlo Gamora (head mixologist at Trix in Willamsburg

In just a few days, Stolen Chair will present the world premiere of its 15th original work, Potion: A Play in 3 Cocktails.  Charley sells potions, handcrafted and custom made. From potions that can make the forgetful remember to potions that will stop a compulsive liar from fibbing, Charley’s concoctions satisfy a diverse clientele. But the one potion Charley hasn’t been able to master is that one she wants for herself: a love potion. Potion, a “spoken word opera” immerses its audience in the giddy world of Charley’s bar and her regular (and irregular) customers, with Gamora’s flight of 3 original “potions” served by the actors as the play unfolds.

To create the uniquely rhythmic text for Potion, Stolen Chair’s playwright Kiran Rikhye dug deeply into the Italian libretti of the operas by Mozart, Verdi, Donazetti, and more. For each scene of Potion, Rikhye mapped out the meter, rhymes, repetitions, and simultaneity of an aria, duet, trio, or quartet to create a template for her own original text. The result is an intoxicating and incantatory verse play unlike any other, set to a genre-bending original score performed live by multi-instrumentalist Sean Cronin. The ensemble performs this “opera” in spoken voice that is every bit as virtuosic, dizzying, and delightful as operatic song in a site-specific staging by Jon Stancato that explores every nook and cranny of PEOPLE’s bar and makes the audience feel they are VIP guests at Charley’s magical speakeasy. 

Why we are asking for your help...

As an 11 year old company, we've gotten pretty darn good at managing our limited resources to create challenging and delightful original works of theatre.  Through in-kind donations of materials and labor and a little old-fashioned ingenuity (American Theater Magazine called us "Scrappy"), we've found a way to reduce our overall budget to a mere fraction of its original size.  The good news?  We've already secured enough through past box office returns, generous donations, and support from the New York State Council on the Arts to pay for the personnel, materials, and space needed to create this show out of thin air and run it for 9 weeks in NYC.  The bad news?  Each performance of the show costs us so much that even if we play to sold-out houses every night, we won't have enough money to keep the show going after that.

But, with your help, we can:

  • Put butts in seats: our marketing will be able to reach people who've never heard of us, bringing a new audience to this very special show ($1000) 
  • Keep our actors looking hot and smelling fresh: we'll be able to keep the makeup supplies well-stocked and the show's costumes can get cleaned every week ($2000)
  • Comply with the union: we'll be able to pay the payroll processing fees that  kick in after 9 performances, allowing us to pay our performers in compliance with Actors' Equity requirements ($1200)
  • Print your reading material: believe it or not, printing these little booklets add up to become one of our biggest weekly costs ($400)
  • Serve our "potions" in custom glassware: we want the audience to be transported into the magical world of Charley's bar ($250)
  • Keep the lights on: we'll ensure that our light fixture have more than hope in their sockets ($150)

That comes to just $5000, and with that sum we'll be able to run the show for at least 2 more full months after that, giving the ork the exposure it needs for press, producers, and consideration come awards season.

What you get...

Our heartfelt gratitude AND...

Happy Hour Shot ($10): Your name on our list of Indiegogo supporters

Screwdriver ($25): All the above AND a selection of audio highlights from Potion.

Tiki Drink ($50): All the above AND the recipes for the signature cocktails Gamora created for the show so you can make them at home.

Gin & Tonic ($100): All the above AND 1 free ticket to Potion (does not include required cocktail prix fixe)

Martini ($250): All the above AND 2 (in total) free tickets to Potion (does not include required cocktail prix fixe) AND a flask emblazoned with the show's promotional art.

Negroni ($500): All the above AND 2 (in total) free tickets to Potion (admission and cocktail prix fixe both included) 

Sazerac ($1000): All the above AND 4 (in total) free tickets to Potion (admission and cocktail prix fixe both included) 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please SPREAD THE WORD:

Follow Stolen Chair on Facebook (http://www.facebook.com/StolenChair), then share with all of your closest Facebook friends. 

Follow @StolenChairTC on Twitter and tweet to your followers about how far their $10, $25, or $100 can go for #Potion.

Reblog our behind the scenes snapshots from our Tumblr blog: stolenchair.tumblr.com

Sign up for Stolen Chair's  e-newsletter: http://stolenchair.org/contact

Oh, and come to the show! Bring your friends!  Bring your family! Bring everyone!  TICKETS: http://tickets.stolenchair.org

THANK YOU!

And thank you to our fabulous cast and crew who continually inspire us to make this show even better: 

Written by Kiran Rikhye | Directed by Jon Stancato | Music by Sean Cronin | Costume Design by Beth Goldenberg | Makeup by Jaclyn Schaefer | Lighting Installation by Daniel Winters | Stage Management by Brooke Bell | Props & Graphic Design by Aviva Meyer | Promotional Art by Zelda Devon | Photos by Carrie Leonard | Publicity by Emily Owens

Featuring Raife Baker, Liz Eckert, Jon Froehlich, Natalie Hegg, Molly O'Neill, Noah Schultz, and David Skeist

Sincerely, 

The Chairs

story:
So What is "No Visible Scars" all about anyways?

Writer/director Deon Denton wrote this original production drawn from the files of her own experiences with depression and mental health.  The topic of suicide is center stage in this play and we are not afraid to talk about it. No we are not! Just ask Myranda...wait, who is Myranda? Glad you asked...Just continue reading...

From Myranda's Box

Hi, my Name is Myranda, I've been standing on a ledge my entire life. I'm fighting demons from my past while battling with a mental health problem. Apparently I have "daddy issues" (go figure). I have to admit I do walk with a "suspiciously" large black box, I measure my life by dying things and I've already set the date for my next suicide attempt.

Please help me tell my story.

What We Need & What You Get

The New York Fringe Festival is one of the largest multi-arts events in North America and the only juried Fringe Festival in the world.

Our cast/crew of 4 has set a goal to raise $10,000.00 to assist with our travel, accommodation and victuals (sure I could have just said food but victuals seems more dramatic).  We are staying outside the city (cheaper accommodations) so we will be travelling by subway and bus to the festival.

We have some wonderful perks for all supporters (we really do) Check them out below.  

The Impact

Believe it or not, this project didn't start at the FringeNYC. Writer Deon Denton wrote this play as a personal therapy then hosted a read-through in her basement with a few friends and industry professionals. The response was overwhelming. What began as a read-through for a play turned into a group therapy session with much tears and healing. The overall consensus was that  we haven't been talking enough about mental illness and we need to remove the stigma attached to it. 

Other Ways You Can Donate

Not a fan of credit cards or PayPall?

  • Send us an email money transfer to accounting@promiseproductions.ca we will manually enter the donation for you with your email address and voila!!! you get the credit as deserved!

Please share this with someone you know!

story:
Who we are...

Founded in 2015, Atlanta Dance Collective is a group of artists with a similar vision to create engaging contemporary work in the Atlanta dance scene.  Dance Canvas 2015 served as the catalyst for Atlanta Dance Collective through the mutual involvement of Britt Fishel (formerly Whitmoyer) and Sarah Stokes. "site." choreographed by Britt Fishel, funded through INDIEGOGO and commissioned through Dance Canvas, premiered at the Rialto Center for the Arts and featured Sarah Stokes as one of the dancers. Fishel and Stokes share an interest in creating and performing work and wanted to build a collaborative group of choreographers, dancers, and artists to make dance in the city of Atlanta, thus Atlanta Dance Collective was born. Their latest work, "too far...thanks a lot jim," choreographed by Sarah Stokes, was featured as part of Breaking Ground's New Dance at the Decatur Arts Festival.

What we're up to...

Atlanta Dance Collective strives to connect people through dance within the city of Atlanta. We provide opportunities for dance artists to create new work and engage with audiences in Atlanta, in order to build the community of contemporary dance. 

We have many new projects on the horizon! One, Atlanta Dance Collective will be producing new work in the spring. The concert is entitled Time + Itinerant, and will feature two new works from the members of ADC along with two from emerging choreographers. Our show will run for two consecutive evenings. The end of each night will conclude with the Opine Dance Film Festival, a brand new Screendance festival in Atlanta, featuring both a student and professional adjudicated program! 

Want to know more about us? 

Check us out at www.AtlantaDanceCollective.com

What we need and How you can help!

We are asking for $1,000 for this project. This will cover multiple startup costs for this upcoming season, helping to get these exciting new projects up and running! Your generous donation will go toward:

  • Space rental (performance and rehearsal) deposits and fees
  • Technical costs for filming and editing
  • Travel costs for out of town projects and festivals

We understand that not everyone can help us monetarily. There are other ways you can help us get the funding we need to be a great success!

  • Spread the word! Share this page! Email it, post it on social media- get the word out!
  • Support us with your patronage and stay up to date on what we are doing!    Like us on Facebook, or Follow us on Instagram! 
To contact us with questions or comments, send an email to AtlantaDanceCollective@gmail.com

   We understand that not everyone can help us monetarily. There are other ways you can help us get the funding we need to be a great success!
Spread the word! Share this page! Email it, post it on social media- get the word out!
Support us with your patronage and stay up to date on what we are doing!    Like us on Facebook, or Follow us on Instagram! 

To contact us with questions or comments, send an email to AtlantaDanceCollective@gmail.com

story:
My name is Stefanie Batten Bland, Artistic Director - Choreographic Artist of Company SBB.

Our fall season at the Gatehouse, Harlem Stage, on October 22, 23, 24 2015 premieres Batten Bland’s newest piece “Patient(ce)”.  This work examines the structure of jazz—that of the eternal present.  Through a collaboration with futuristic jazz ensemble Burnt Sugar the Arkestra Chamber and visual installation by myself and Alaric Hahn, PATIENT(CE) will examine the critical relationship that the musical, physical and visual arts share with time. 

I am a recipient of the Kevin Spacey Foundation Artists Choice Award for $10,000. This award is directly supporting performer salaries.  Additional funding is needed to complete the rich visual installation component, costuming and lighting of the new work.  Company SBB’s goal is to match this generous gift.

Additionally “Patient(ce)” is a special piece as it is a physical requiem to Ed Bland, contemporary jazz composer and film maker my father. 

Please consider a donation to our Indiegogo campaign.

 Thank you.

Stefanie Batten Bland.


photo by Beowulf Sheehan

story:
What is miR theater?

Almost four years ago, while on a camping trip outside Chicago, my husband, Joseph Lark-Riley, and I became ignited by an idea that would become miR theater.   From that moment to this we have been creating the foundation for this company and for our first production, Cereus Moonlight.  

Joseph and I have worked as theater artists both together and separately in New Orleans, Chicago, and New York for the past 15 years.  On that camping trip we realized that we wanted to keep making theater, but we wanted to do it in a beautiful small town surrounded by people we love.   Three years and a Master’s Degree in arts administration later, we are in Rockledge, Florida, Joseph’s hometown and the home of miR, made in Rockledge.  It’s a theater company devoted to the creation, production, and presentation of original work.  We’re here to be a part of a movement that tells rich regional stories of smaller places that often get lost in the New York-centric theater world.  Our ultimate goal is to create an artistic hub here in Rockledge.  We want miR to be a place where community members can gather and find art, music, films or theater any night of the week.  All of it made in Rockledge.

Our first production, Cereus Moonlight, is a kind of love song to Rockledge and to all of those out of the way but utterly fascinating small towns in this country.  Through original story-telling, music, live performance, scenography and puppetry this play attempts to capture the essence of Rockledge while celebrating universal themes and questions that connect humans all over the world.

The premiere of Cereus Moonlight is scheduled for January 17th through the 26th at the Historic Rockledge Municipal Building, which we will be transforming into a theater for two weekends.  Your contribution is essential to the success of this project and to the launch of miR theater.

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal with this campaign is to raise $16,000.  These funds will cover costs for space rental, costumes, lighting, musicians fees, actors stipends, as well as travel and creator fees for our two artists-in-residence: Sarah Shotland, our playwright, and Jessica Fogle, our composer.  Additionally we’ll need to purchase materials to construct our spectacular transformable set and 11 hand-crafted puppets.  Finally, miR has been invited to present Cereus Moonlight at the Rhinoceros Theater Festival in Chicago and we are seeking funds to transport the entire production to the Windy City following the premiere here in Rockledge.

To express our gratitude for your generous contributions, we have created some very special perks including limited edition postcard-sized prints of Joseph’s original sketches for the set and puppets, as well as a beautifully bound book containing the original script and images, an art piece in and of itself.

It is important that we reach our entire funding goal in order to complete this project the way we have envisioned it and to share this story with as wide an audience as possible.

The Impact

miR theater is the first theater company dedicated to original theater in Brevard County.  It will be the only theater company based in the City of Rockledge.  By contributing to this campaign, you are not only funding an exciting and brand new piece of theater but you are helping to lay the foundation for a company that will be bringing something entirely new to Central Florida.  In a larger sense (for our friends and colleagues outside of Florida) you are helping to fund a movement to create unique cultural outlets in places where they have been absent.  You are helping to ensure that theater artists have more choices than just heading for the big cities to make their careers, and you are becoming a part of a call to uncover the rich and beautiful stories of unsung places.

Other Ways You Can Help

We are incredibly grateful for any and all contributions, no matter how small. Every donation will have an impact on this project.  However, we understand that some of you will not be able to contribute.  But you can still help!  Please spread the word, tell your friends and family about this unique project and what it will mean to this county and to the movement for cultural organizations in small towns.  There are tools to easily share this campaign on your social media outlet of choice.  The more people who know about this campaign, the greater chance we have of being successfully funded!

Thank you so much for your time and consideration.  We are so thankful for you!

story:
If you've made it past watching the longest fundrasing video since Ben-Hur, we commend and thank you....

What we're at 

Collapsing Horse Theatre Company is Eoghan Quinn, Jack Gleeson, Aaron Heffernan and Matthew Smyth and we're in need, once more, of your love and support!

Collapsing Horse are dedicated to creating entertaining, audience focused, philosophically provocative theatre that merges as many artistic disciplines as we can fit! Our recent shows include MONSTER/CLOCK: A Play on Time and Bears in Space - now we hope to bring you two very different prospects with HUMAN CHILD and especially Distance from the Event which will be part of the Dublin Fringe Festival 2013.

As a company of only a year old we're still unfunded and anything you guys can give to us whether it's €5 or €50 we'd be absolutely over the moon. We're even grateful that you've read down this far.

With HUMAN CHILD costing €5000 and Distance from the Event costing €20,000 (*tug collar nervously) we have figured out that between MONSTER/CLOCK savings; ticket sales, fundrasing dinners, a big night out and with a bit of a dent in it from you guys - we can get money together. With the money we're gonna create the usual: sets, puppets and a whole load of materials. We're also very much building these shows to tour nationally and internationally so hopefully you can then watch, lovingly, as the 'thing' you helped create goes on to reach more and more delighted audiences around Ireland (and hopefully further afield).

________________________________________________________________________

The Collapsing Horse Team

Our Family has gone and grown!

HUMAN CHILD

Written by Dan Colley
Composed by Tom Lane
Directed by Dan Colley
Assistant Directed by Stephen Quinn
Dramaturg: Eoghan Quinn
Puppet Master: Aaron Heffernan
Performed by Manus Halligan, John Doran, Megan Riordan, Aoife Leonard
Design by Zia Holly
Costume by Liadain Kaminska
Co-Produced by Jack Gleeson and Matt Smyth
Images by Jody Barker-Rockett

Distance from the Event

Writer: Eoghan Quinn
Director: Dan Colley
Sound Design/composer: Simon Bird
Puppetry and Materials Design: Aaron Heffernan
Set Design: Colm McNally
Lighting Designer: Sarah Jane Sheils
Costume: Emma Gleeson
Production Manager: Adam Fitzsimons
Assistant Director: Stephen Quinn
Assistant Producer: Jack Gleeson
Producer: Matthew Smyth
Cast: Will be announced in the coming week....
 

________________________________________________________________________

The shows!

Human Child

Lelia is a bold child. She doesn’t eat her dinner. She never goes to bed when she’s told. Her parents say she’s a worry. Her teacher says she’s a pain. She’s the kid who stands on the table, she’s the kid who won’t wash her hands, she’s the kid who has lots of friends but everyone is in her head.

She’s the kid who, from the end of her garden, hears a song that takes her on a wondrous journey to a place where she’s understood.

Distance from the Event

We can't really tell you what 'it' is just yet for 1000 reasons.... just think: Sci-fi; Film Noir; Flann O Brien and a whole load (or lack of) paper.... We can tell you that 'it's' honoured to be part of the Dublin Fringe Festival 2013 and that it's going to be brilliant!
__________________________________________________________________________

Other Ways You Can Help...

If you can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help!

  • Spread the love about the campaign!
  • Come and see the shows!
  • Drag everyone you know and love to come and see the shows!

We will also be running a series of dinners and also one MAMMOTH night out in August so keep your ears, eyes and noses pealed for that!

__________________________________________________________________________

From the bottom of our clockwork and real hearts, we can't stress enough how much we appreciate all you support!

Love from Eoghan, Aaron, Dan, Jack, Colm, Matt and everyone at Collapsing Horse

story:
Short Summary

  My name is Sarah Cassell, and I’m producing Bat Boy, an independent student project at Syracuse University. The entire cast and creative team consists of SU Drama students, with the exception of our director, Rodney Hudson, who is a member of the musical theater faculty. This is an incredibly talented, dedicated, and passionate group of people. We have everything we need to put together a fantastic show – except the last leg of our funding.

We will be doing Bat Boy: The Musical, with music and lyrics by Lawrence O’Keefe and book by Brian Flemming and Keythe Farley. Based on the sci-fi news tabloid The Weekly World News, the show is about a part-boy, part-bat creature found in a cave outside a small farming town. As he begins to learn language, culture, and religion, all he wants is to be accepted by society. However, the more he tries to assimilate, the more he is rejected and turned into a scapegoat by the townspeople. This cult-hit tragicomedy has a unique, campy voice that uses humor to illuminate the cruelties of prejudice, revenge, and hypocrisy.

Above all, this is an amazing performance opportunity for the students involved. We have an INCREDIBLE cast and production team. 

Bat Boy cast:

Bat Boy – Ethan Saviet

Dr. Parker – Keith Caram

Meredith Parker – Sarah Cassell

Shelley Parker – Justine Rappaport

Rick Taylor / Lorraine / Doctor / Mr. Dillon – Danny Kornfeld

Sheriff Reynolds – Connor Saccal

Ron / Maggie / Clem – Chloe Miller

Ruthie / Daisy – Maggie Randolph

Reverend Billy Hightower / Roy / Institute Man – Jodi Snyder

Mrs. Taylor / Ned – Adam Seagrave

Pan / Bud – Brian Sandstrom

 

Production team:

Director – Rodney Hudson

Assistant Director – Taylor Chaskey

Stage Manager – Carmen Quiñones

Costume Designer – Simon Brett

Producer – Sarah Cassell

Casting Director – Rebecca Witt

Props Master – Jesse Roth

Marketing Designer – Shawn Martin

Production Assistants – Adam Coy, Bryn Dolan, Zeke Edmunds, Lisa Graye, Chirag Manohar, Mary McGowan, Richard Westfahl

Performances will be November 15-17 at Spark Contemporary Art Space in Syracuse, NY.

What We Need & What You Get

We’re hoping to raise $1,000 to cover the cost of props, lighting, marketing, costumes, and set pieces.

 We have been given grants from the Renee Crown University Honors Program and the Department of Drama to cover the cost of the venue, accompanist, and performance rights. Those are our biggest, most pressing expenses, but now we need your help to fund the fun and creative stuff. Here are a few of the most interesting expenses your donation would go towards:

·      Human-sized cage

·      Paper mache cow head

·      Prosthetic ears and fangs

·      Stage blood

·      Wheelchair

·      Bowie knife

·      And much, MUCH more**

The funding we have been given by the university has been incredibly generous, but in order to tell this story the way we want to tell it, we need more. We have raised the money to make this show possible; now we need to raise the money to make possible our artistic goals for this show.

Even the smallest donation would help. Any amount of money will bring us closer to our goal. If you can’t donate, we would appreciate it if you could pass it on to your friends and family! Spread the word – we are so close to our goal and we are passionate about making this show as amazing as it has the potential to be.

**Despite how sinister that list sounds, the show really is a comedy.

story:
HITFest presents The Tempest at Mulford Farm

For fourteen years HITFest has been a positive grassroots force in the community. We fulfill our non-profit mission of fostering theatre in all its forms. We've built our own black box theatre, raised money for worthy causes, produced excellent theatre, and most importantly, created a home for Shakespeare here in the Hamptons. 

For three weeks in August families and friends will be able to gather under the summer sky to enjoy Shakespeare. To witness the magic of his final and most spectacular play.

We are seeking funding to help pay our actors

All of our actors are paid. This is important because love does not pay bills. Paying actors keeps them acting. Keeps them telling stories and winning over new generations of theatre goers.

Our Tempest is true to Shakespeare's roots, honestly told, and kid-friendly. The next generation can only come to love Shakespeare if they see Shakespeare. Theatre enriches all of our lives, especially our children's lives.

We're asking for eleven thousand four hundred dollars because that's what the actors' salaries cost. We're optimistic that we'll reach our goal, but even if we don't we get to use all the money raised since we're doing a flexible funding campaign.

Theatre is magic

It is vitally important that we continue to create theatre. There is a lot to be said for what we get from our screens and devices, but live theatre, the territory of it, must not be forsaken. 

Theatre is where your soul gets to see other souls strive. Nothing in the world compares to the thrill of watching terrific actors performing terrific material. And we have both and we're ready to prove it this summer. 

The Tempest will be our sixth production since 2012 and our second outdoor Shakespeare. I love everything that we do, but Shakespeare has a special place in my heart because he speaks so eloquently about what it is to be human. 

If you don't have the means to contribute please volunteer

Your time, your expertise, your social media, your word of mouth... it all helps! Make some noise! Let's drown out the din of helicopters and summer traffic with Shakespeare's The Tempest!! Drop me a line at Josh@HITFest.org and let me know what you can do to help. Or call me at 516 725-5205. Thanks!

story:
We're performing in New York!

Our show "Boogie Of The Apes" got accepted to the 8th Annual FrigidNYC Festival!

What is "Boogie Of The Apes?"

It's a fast-paced parody recap of the first four Planet Of The Apes movies, done in less than an hour!

Boogie of the Apes is the second in a series of hilarious productions lip-synced to vintage children’s records of famous comic book, TV, and movie franchises. This raucous send-up of the 1970s Planet of the Apes franchise lampoons, critiques, and ever-so-gently mocks the first four movies in less than an hour. Help Taylor, Dr. Zira, Cornelius, Nova, and many more apes, humans, and mutants come full circle in their journey through time and space and, of course, boogie down a bit too. (Please note: no gorillas, orangutans or chimpanzees are harmed in this production.)


But we need your help to get us there.


(Here's what we did with a Superman record in Superhero Boogie. Imagine what we can do with Planet of the Apes!)

What We Need & What You Get

We're a fairly low-budget production, but we still need funds for the following:

  • Airfare
  • Lodging
  • Food
  • Transportation in New York
  • Rent for the performance space
All of this comes to roughly $9,000.00.

We're offering perks ranging from downloads of video of the performance all the way to performing the show at your home for you and your friends. (See our perks list for details!)

This is Broom Street Theater's first attempt to send a show to New York City. Broom Street is the longest-running experimental theater in the US. We've been around since 1969, and we're still going strong.



Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, that's cool, no worries. But you can always help us by linking to this page, as well as letting everyone know about our performance dates:

We'll be performing at the Kraine Theater (85 East 4th Street between 2nd & 3rd AVENUES in the Bowery).

Wed, Feb. 26, 5:30pm

Fri, Feb. 28, 7:05pm

Sat, Mar 1, 5:15pm

Sun, Mar 2, 2:05pm

Mon, Mar 3, 7:05pm

Who's Boogieing?

Our cast includes the talents of Jessica Jane Witham, Dan Myers, Grace Grindrod-Feeny, Benjamin Otto, Anthony Cary, Kathy Lynn Sliter, Alan Hart, and Luke Kokinos. Technical direction provided by Taylor Kokinos and choreographed by Katie Ramos.


This mayhem is written and directed by Rob Matsushita.
story_txt:
We're performing in New York!
Our show "Boogie Of The Apes" got accepted to the 8th Annual FrigidNYC Festival!What is "Boogie Of The Apes?"It's a fast-paced parody recap of the first four Planet Of The Apes movies, done in less than an hour!Boogie of the Apes is the second in a
series of hilarious productions lip-synced to vintage children’s records of
famous comic book, TV, and movie franchises. This raucous send-up of the 1970s Planet of the Apes franchise lampoons, critiques,
and ever-so-gently mocks the first four movies in less than an hour. Help
Taylor, Dr. Zira, Cornelius, Nova, and many more apes, humans, and mutants come
full circle in their journey through time and space and, of course, boogie down
a bit too. (Please note: no gorillas, orangutans or chimpanzees are harmed in
this production.)But we need your help to get us there.(Here's what we did with a Superman record in Superhero Boogie. Imagine what we can do with Planet of the Apes!)What We Need & What You GetWe're a fairly low-budget production, but we still need funds for the following:
Airfare
Lodging
Food
Transportation in New York
Rent for the performance space
All of this comes to roughly $9,000.00.We're offering perks ranging from downloads of video of the performance all the way to performing the show at your home for you and your friends. (See our perks list for details!)This is Broom Street Theater's first attempt to send a show to New York City. Broom Street is the longest-running experimental theater in the US. We've been around since 1969, and we're still going strong.Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't donate, that's cool, no worries. But you can always help us by linking to this page, as well as letting everyone know about our performance dates:We'll be performing at the Kraine Theater (85 East 4th Street between 2nd & 3rd AVENUES in the Bowery).Wed, Feb. 26, 5:30pmFri, Feb. 28, 7:05pmSat, Mar 1, 5:15pmSun, Mar 2, 2:05pmMon, Mar 3, 7:05pmWho's Boogieing?Our cast includes the talents of Jessica Jane Witham, Dan Myers, Grace Grindrod-Feeny, Benjamin Otto, Anthony Cary, Kathy Lynn Sliter, Alan Hart, and Luke Kokinos. Technical direction provided by Taylor Kokinos and choreographed by Katie Ramos.This mayhem is written and directed by Rob Matsushita.

story:
WHO ARE THE PURPLE CRAYON PLAYERS?

Purple Crayon Players is a student-run theatre company on the Northwestern University campus committed to creating high quality productions, events, and educational materials regarding all aspects of theatre for young audiences. Purple Crayon Players believes that audiences of all ages can appreciate, be inspired by, and grow through exposure to this unique art form.

We produce a mainstage season of professionally written works for young audiences, while also sponsoring high quality outreach events, educational events, and special projects for audiences of all ages both on campus and in the outlying community. These events support the mainstage season, as well as explore other aspects of theatre, community service, and learning.

WHAT IS "SHE KILLS MONSTERS" ABOUT?

When Agnes inherits Tilly’s old Dungeons & Dragons module, she enlists the aide of local Dungeon Master Chuck to enter the action-packed imaginary kingdom of Tilly’s refuge. As she delves deeper into New Landia—a world of murderous fairies, cheerleading succubae, and five-headed dragons— Agnes begins to discover secrets even she did not know about her sister. With only her wits, ‘90s pop culture, and untapped warrior skills to guide her, Agnes sets off to save her sister’s soul—and perhaps her own.

WHERE DOES THE MONEY GO?

Kicking off Purple Crayon Players' 11th season, SHE KILLS MONSTERS is a massive undertaking for the board. Here's a brief list of things we're budgeting for the show:
  • Outreach efforts into the greater Chicago area to bring kids from high schools and youth groups in to see the show
  • Design elements (costumes/makeup/sets/props) to bring the vibrant world of Dungeons and Dragons to life on the McCormick Auditorium stage
  • Technical elements (light/sound) to give the production atmosphere and feel professional in production.
  • Rights/space rental/etc.

WHY SHOULD I SUPPORT THIS?

SHE KILLS MONSTERS is part of an ongoing push by Purple Crayon Players to expand the field of Theatre for Young Audiences to include stories about high school age teens, as well as tackling more complex and vital issues for younger ages. SHE KILLS MONSTERS touches on subjects as varied as sexual identity, depression, grief from loss, outsiderism, disability, and alternate subcultures. Purple Crayon Players sees it as vital to educate youth about these issues as soon as possible, so that they grow into more open-minded, accepting, and understanding individuals.

    I WANT TO SUPPORT THIS, BUT I CAN'T DONATE ON INDIEGOGO FOR SOME REASON. HOW CAN I HELP OUT?

    There are plenty of ways to help out!

    • Come to a bakesale! There will be two bakesales, both from 9am to 5pm, on October 5 and 21 in the Torso Lobby at Northwestern's Wirtz Center for the Performing Arts.
    • Come to the Children's Book Bash event! On October 9th in Harris 107 (near the Rock) we will be hosting an evening of readings from books we've read from our childhoods. No cover charge, though donations are accepted!
    • Send your donations directly though the mail! Cash, as well as checks made out to "NORTHWESTERN UNIVERSITY" can be sent to Zach Barr at the following address: 641 Library Pl., Apt. 1, Evanston, IL 60201
    • Come see the show! Performances are October 29-31 at McCormick Auditorium at Norris University Center at Northwestern University. Tickets are $5 for students and $10 for general admission.


    Thanks, everyone.

story:
Short Summary

I have been given the opportunity to serve as the Music Direction Intern at the Pittsburgh Civic Light Opera this summer. The organization is one that is widely respected in the world of musical theatre. It functions as a Summer Stock job for aspiring actors and they often times hire big names for the leading roles.
 
During the internship I will work alongside the music director to make sure everything music-wise goes according to plan. While interning I will be working on 42ND STREET, MAURY YESTON'S PHANTOM OF THE OPERA, and SEVEN BRIDES FOR SEVEN BROTHERS. I am sure this will be a very informitive and amazing summer and could not be more excited!
 
The one downside to this internship is that it only helps offset the cost of living a small ammount. Because I currently pay rent for an appartment in Cincinnati and will now be taking on a sublet for the summer in Pittsburgh, I have decided to ask you for any help you may be willing to give!
 
This internship will allow me to work with professional and very established actors and musicians but it will also provide my resume for music direction with more credibility and "WOW" factor so getting a job in the real world will be a little easier! I thank you in advance for any dollar amount that you are able to contribute!

What We Need & What You Get

My goal for this fundraiser is $500 for the time I will be an intern. I must be in Pittsburgh for the first rehearsal on May 22, 2013 and will be done with the internship on June 22, 2013. The research I have done in regards to housing has shown me that the cheapest apartments near where I am working are in the $350 to $400 range and do not include utilities. In addition to the rent, I will also need to buy a bus pass so I am able to get to work in downtown Pittsburgh every day. If the goal is not met, anything will help offset the cost of this experience and I will be thankful for any amount I raise!

The Impact

By donating to this fundraiser you are helping me realize my dreams of becoming a Music Director for shows on Broadway. Pittsburgh CLO is a very well respected organization that has a reputation of producing large, Broadway scale productions and I have been fortunate enough to be chosen for this prestigous internship. Helping me with the cost of housing will mean advancing my career after college and I believe that is worth investing in.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not in the financial position to donate, DON'T WORRY! Please just help me spread the word by posting the link to this page on Facebook and sharing with family and friends!

story:
What's This All About, You Say?

     Ever since I saw my older sister Kristen in her first high school play, I knew I wanted to be a performer. I can remember sitting in that audience in total awe of those kids up there making me laugh and cry, teaching me how to relate to people outside of my own experience. I performed in plays and was a dancer all throughout high school and into college. I graduated from University of Oregon in 2012, and since then I have been working as a receptionist at a retirement community to save money, auditioning for shows and theatre programs, and doing a small amount of film work to bulk up my resume. 

     I was very recently accepted to the innovative and highly selective graduate acting program at Birmingham School of Acting, a branch of Birmingham City University in England. My course is focused on giving international students a deeper understanding of the long tradition of British theatre, from Shakespeare to Tom Stoppard. I will be studying with 12 other actors from all over the world in a 9 month program. It's extremely intensive, and in the end, I'll come out with a master's degree in art. Having BSA on my resume could open a lot of doors for me and would undoubtedly help me to be a stronger artist. It would truly be a dream come true to study what I love, what I intend to do until I'm 85, in a place that has such a rich history in theatre.

     The hard part is getting there. The cost of the program itself and the cost of living in England makes this whole experience very expensive, and I'm already working on paying off my loans from UofO, so I'm applying for aid through the school, searching for independent scholarships and will use all of the money I've saved, but it won't be enough, so I'm asking for all the help I can get.  

 

What your donation will go to:

I've set my goal to $5,000, because it is the most I feel I can realistically ask for, though it won't cover the total cost of what I need. Combined with the money I have saved, it would give me about half of my tuition. In other words, it would help me tremendously. Here's a more detailed breakdown of what the money will go to:

    Tuition

    Travel Costs

    Housing

    Books/Supplies

 

If you have any more questions about the program or the cost, feel free to leave a comment or email me. I'd love to tell you more about it. Also, if you donate, please let me know your address so you can receive your perks! 

Thank you so much for even taking the time to read this. I know people don't have a lot of money laying around these days, so if you are unable to donate, good thoughts are greatly appreciated as well.

story:
Lend a Hand

Philadelphia's upcoming production of Into the Clear Blue Sky by JC Lee is in need of funding! The University of the Arts has generously supplied director Rae Labadie with $400 toward her senior thesis production, putting the team at nearly half of our budget goal! Designs are in process, rehearsals are starting up soon and we need your help to make our production as epic as we're all expecting it to be.

We are asking for your help in raising $500 to be used specifically towards set, costumes and marketing/ advertisement. Any and all donations are very greatly appreciated! Take a look at the perks of donating and become a key contributor to the success of this project that means so much to us.

Your generosity is helping to build a cultured community, opening doors for these young artists, eager to share their craft with Philadelphia. Thank you, from the bottom of the ocean to the surface of the moon.


A Word from the Director

As an artist and director, I am interested in collaborating with young artists to create magical worlds no audience has been taken to before. I care deeply about my community and strive to create an environment in which art informs our intelligence and mends barriers between social class and varying personalities rather than accentuating them. Into the Clear Blue Sky takes place in the future, on the moon, and in the ocean, where a girl has a chemical stain that blackened her hands, a mother scrubs endlessly in an attempt to erase, and a Mighty Seahorse wreaks havoc on the shore. This play is nailing the ‘other worldly’ aspect I’m after, but at a closer look, this is a story of ordinary people under extraordinary circumstances, struggling with being accepted and accepting themselves, running away and running after, and, in the end, forgiving and coping. I am drawn to the motives of these characters and the bare human connection they seek when everything they know is stripped away.

-Rae Labadie, Director Into the Clear Blue Sky


Meet the Team

Director: Rae Labadie
Stage Manager: Nicole Labadie-Bartz

Set Design: Raven Buck
Lighting Design: Michael Lambui
Costume Design: Joseph Orsini

Cast:
Emma Arrick, Anthony Mustafa Adair, Evan Gallagher-Frace, Shelvy Paredes, Chris Garofalo

story:
Atlanta’s finest will compete for the coveted title of Fenuxe Magazine’s Best Bachelor all in the name of raising funds to benefit AID Atlanta.  The year, AID Atlanta is expanding their services in an effort  to more than double the number of clients they can see in their clinic, as well as service expansion to include OB/GYN, Pediatric and Chiropractic services .  Our nominees look forward to some good old fashioned fundraising to help support AID Atlanta’s service expansion.

When it comes to Atlanta’s most eligible bachelors and bachelorettes, you sure know what you want. Once again we present to you some of the city’s hottest hunks for Fenuxe’s Fourth Annual Best Bachelors of Atlanta.

As nominations rolled in, you offered sincere reasons why your nominees should make the cut. But, in the end, only ten men or women could be named as finalists. Thousands of votes poured in during the final round of voting, and it was certainly a tight race.

Now comes the time to unveil your top bachelors. With good looks and plenty of charisma, these guys and gals no doubt will someday make a someone genuinely happy. In an effort to know them better, we asked them a variety of questions, including turn-ons and relationship deal-breakers. Although their interests and personalities vary, they do share a few commonalities. Many of them just can’t get enough of Adele, and nearly all of them want someone who can make them laugh. Several said loyalty and a value of family were essential traits in a potential companion.

Needless to say our array of finalists should pique just about anyone’s interest. Find out more about them here and then meet them up close and personal…

story:
Short Summary

We are Happy Dance Studio and our dream is to develop a new performing art technique and to become the first shadow dance theatre in Latvia. Shadow dance theatre is a way of art that creates a magical performance by combining dance, theatre and specific use of technology. As you will read further, it is a great adventure for performers, producers and the audience. However, to bring our spectacle to a large scale audience we need your support in order to buy and rent necessary attributes.   

At the Beginning

Happy Dance Studio is a dance studio that focuses not only on teaching various dance styles but also on creating exciting stage performances. During the creation process the choreographers have experimented a lot by mixing together different art styles and collaborating with various art professionals. However, special audience sympathies were often earned by performances based on shadow dance theatre - the combination of dance, theatre and installations of lights, video and multimedia. So, we started to dig deeper. 

Shadow Dance Theatre

Shadow dance theatre is something we hadn't heard about before and something we have found to be very exciting to ourselves and audiences. It is an art style which offers new techniques of expressing the storyline to people, producing magical dance routines and applying technology as a crucial element of the show.

To set up the stage we use a screen which creates two environments. Behind the screen we put a light source that introduces the "shadow world". Various video, photo, multimedia installations are projected on the screen to be incorporated in the choreographies or the story. 

                                  

The dancers are taught different performance techniques to be applied in both of the environments - in front of the screen and in the "shadow part". For instance, behind the screen choreographers can play around contrasts of dancers' sizes, multimedia elements and interesting silhouettes. 

All in all, shadow dance theatre is a great empowerment for performers to meet new techniques, choreographers and producers to meet new ways of expression and the audience to meet new impressions.

What We Need & What You Get

During the past year we have generated many combinations of dance and shadow, rehearsed with different props and handmade constructions. Thus a performance of 16 unique shadow dance routines has been created. And as a non-profit organization we need your support and faith in our dream to bring our creation to a wider audience.

To realize our vision of the first Shadow Dance theatre we want to start with a large show in Riga at the end of January, 2015. Therefore, we need to acquire special equipment and prepare the stage. Our own funding (approximately 50 %) covers the costs of the rehearsals, some of the equipment and promotion materials. However, we still need funding for approximately 5000 EUR to buy and rent all the necessary attributes: 

- the costs of the theater; 

- technical equipment  suitable for a large stage; 

- stage props; 

- costumes. 

With your suport we will have the opportunity to put in all our talents, skills, heart and creativity in order to set up a unique show "Meet the Shadows!", to launch the first Shadow Dance theatre in Latvia.

For your support we offer a variety of appreciations starting with posters and access to a live stream of the concert to special performances and meeting with the studio. Some of the largest contributors will also get a video of a shadow dance uniquely produced for them by Happy Dance Studio.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are intrigued by our ideas and performance or if you know anyone who could help us achieving our dream, please follow, like and share us on Facebook and Youtube, as well as visit or contact us from the webpage.
P.S. And remember - sharing is caring.

many combinations of dance and shadow, rehearsed with different props and handmade

created. And as a non-profit organization we need your support and faith in our
dream to bring our creation to a wider audience.
To realize our vision of the
first Shadow Dance theatre we want to start with a large show in Riga at the
end of January, 2015. Therefore, we need to acquire special equipment and prepare
the stage. Our own funding (approximately 50 %) covers the costs of the rehearsals,
some of the equipment and promotion materials. However, we still need funding
for approximately 5000 EUR to buy and rent all
the necessary attributes: 
- the costs of the
theater; 
-
technical equipment  suitable for a large stage; 
-
stage props; 
-
costumes. 
With
your suport we will have the opportunity to put in all our talents,
skills, heart and creativity in order to set up a unique show
"Meet the Shadows!", to launch the first Shadow Dance theatre in
Latvia.
For your support we offer a variety of appreciations
starting with posters and access to a live stream of the concert to special
performances and meeting with the studio. Some of the largest contributors will
also get a video of a shadow dance uniquely produced for them by Happy Dance
Studio.

Other Ways You Can Help
If you are intrigued by our ideas and performance or if you know anyone who could help us achieving our dream, please follow, like and share us on Facebook and Youtube, as well as visit or contact us from the webpage.

P.S. And remember - sharing is caring.

story:
About New Room Theatre and Blackout

New Room Theatre are an Edinburgh based theatre company bringing socially aware, often unheard, yet entertaining stories to the stage. You can find more information on what we do at www.newroomtheatre.co.uk

Blackout is a new play which looks at the lives of five recovering alcoholics and is coming to London after a critically acclaimed run in Edinburgh and Glasgow. We think it's an important, entertaining piece of theatre and are delighted that The Hope Theatre in Islington agrees. Here is some more information on the play, and how to book. www.thehopetheatre.com/productions/blackout

The Hope Theatre is the only off-West end theatre to have an agreement with the actors union, Equity, to pay all of it's creative team a wage. Actors are all too often unpaid and undervalued. Actors are trained professionals and as such deserve to be paid for what they do.

New Room Theatre wholeheartedly welcomes this approach and we believe it is the way forward for all Fringe theatre.

We have already received amazing local support, from Blenheim Community Drug Project, and the Hope Theatre by giving us free rehearsal space.

We are a large cast of five, plus two creatives. Therefore there is no way we can make a profit on this production, regardless of ticket sales. However, to have the best change to break even we are looking to fund two of our actors. Each will be paid £609, in line with the Equity agreement. This would ensure New Room Theatre could continue to produce new, challenging, entertaining theatre in the future. You can really make a difference.

Over half of all actors live under the poverty line:

http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/theatre/theatre-news/10574735/More-than-half-of-actors-are-under-poverty-line.html

About the Equity/ Hope agreement:

http://www.equity.org.uk/news-and-events/equity-news/hope-theatre-signs-new-fringe-pay-deal/


  • We are looking for £1218 to pay two actors National Minimum Wage for the run of Blackout. We believe that everyone has a right to a living wage. Actors are trained, skilled professionals and this isn't a hobby- it's their job!
  • By making a donation, you are contributing to making Fringe theatre better for everyone- from audiences to actors. Productions will improve as the actors are happier!
  • Any contribution you make will go towards wages. Should we exceed our target, then that will go towards the next production.


    Other Ways You Can Help
     Please come to see the show. It runs from 18th November to 6th December at The Hope Theatre, 207 Upper Street, Islington (above the Hope and Anchor pub). Tickets are £14/12 concessions (plus booking fees) from www.thehopetheatre.com/productions/blackout

story:
Fund our Actors

  • Hi! I'm Aiyana Cunningham, the director and producer of this project. I've brought together an ensemble of deeply generous actors to create a new piece of theater for the Fertile Ground Festival of new works in Portland, OR!
  • All funds raised will go directly to paying the five actors for their rehearsal and performance time.
  • With this project we are stopping in our tracks, digging in our heals and facing the terrifying face of who we are, who we were and who we should be.  Our goal is to uplift by revealing our inherent strengths.

How much and how we'll spend it

  • We need $40 from you to meet our goal. (Yes, we'll take more or less!)
  • ALL of the funds go directly to the actors! The project is co-produced by the Multnomah Arts Center, which is providing for all of our other needs.
  • We'll get to keep all of the money contributed to this campaign, even if we don't reach our goal! (Indiegogo takes a teeny-tiny pinch).

Risks 

  • Theater is all risk. We put ourselves out there so that you can sit comfortable and live vicariously. We might fail, and will do so gloriously. But we'll work hard and bring the best show to life that we are able. 

Other Ways To Help

  • Come see the show! We run 1/22/15 - 2/1/15
  • Buy your Fertile Ground pass from the Multnomah Arts Center - they get a cut of each sale!
  • Ticket Link

Cast

  • Aime Kelly
  • Amy Katrina Bryan
  • Ashleigh Bragg
  • Jana Crenshaw
  • Sarah McGregor

Director/Producer: Aiyana Cunningham

Producer: Amy Jo McCarville, Theatre Program Coordinator, Multnomah Arts Center

story: Our daughter Catilynn, has worked so hard to compete in the dance competitions. Her team is raising money to go to Tampa in December in to January to dance at the half time in the Outback Bowl. They are doing a wonderful job. As a family, we would love to be there and expericence this dream with her. To be able to share a dream as a family is Priceless!! If any of you would like to help my family and I make this trip possible, I am setting up this fundraising account. Any amount you wish to donate would be helpful, AND greatly appreciated!

story:
What Is Country Gravy and Other Obsessions

Is a musical comedy where Mavis Applebee and Myrtle McGillicurdle will come to your hometown rec center, hotel, church or bar to present the most valuable seminar of your life. That's right ... The only one you'll ever need.... A relationship seminar!

These two special ladies will fix relationships with husbands, wives, cars, food, bosses, relatives, can openers ... You name it! And yes, sometimes they'll show you how to dole out the tough love, like squirting your husband with a bottle of water if he goes to the fridge for one more hot dog.

Listen and learn as Myrtle explains how to deal with difficult feelings in that chart topper, Stuff It. Then commiserate with Mavis while she sings about her favorite obsession in French Fry on the Floorboard!

Now, once in a while, Myrtle's insane boss, DeeAndra Joneford stalks them and tries to take over the seminar in a drunken stupor, but she is expertly handled by Myrtle, proving once again that the best way to have a great relationship is to control the other person.

Thru the course of the seminar, Mavis and Myrtle do a lot of healing (mostly on themselves) when they work thru the trauma of their childhoods with neglectful, druggie parents. Be amazed as they channel their opera diva mothers in a show stopping operatic fight scene!

This delightful romp can be molded to fit any venue and any group from church goers to barfies alike!

What is the Country Gravy Plan

 With all the great response we received in Texas, we decided it would be great to share what we created in Houston with the rest of the country.  In 2015/16 we are launching a National Tour of Country Gravy and Other Obsessions.  

In preparation of the National Tour, we are setting out on a small Developmental Tour in the Summer and Fall of 2014.  The purpose of the tour is to perform in a variety of cities and use those audiences to really focus on creating the best show.  Between June and November of 2014, we are in the process of booking 6 different cities through out the southern states.  We will have 5 to 20 performances in front of their audiences to really focus on developing the show.  

When we finish the Developmental Tour in November 2014, we will be fully prepared to take our show to the APAP conference in New York City and begin booking the 2015/16 tour.

How you can help Country Gravy 

The reality is that this costs money, even with a bare bones budget.  Because we are attempting to revamp the production during this developmental phase, there are expenses that we need to cover that will not be covered by the individual productions of the tour:

  • Total Fundraising Need: $10,800
    • Pre-production/Technical $3600
    • Administrative $7200
  • Some specific needs (included in the above costs):
  • Technical
    • Lighting Design and Equipment - $1000
    • Scenic Design and Scenic Build - $1000
    • Costume Design and Wardrobe - $700
    • Sound Equipment/Microphones - $900
  • Administrative
    • Insurance - $3000 ($500 per city)
    • Transportation/Production Vehicle - $1200 ($200 per city)
    • Marketing - $3000 ($500 per city)

What is in it for you?

While the greatest thing you come away with is the feeling of being a part of the theatrical experience and knowing you helped make it possible, we want to show our appreciation by offering you something more.  Please refer to the contribution levels on the right.

We also look forward to the possibility of meeting up with you as we travel across the country.  Keep on the look out for our touring schedule for both the Developmental Tour of 2014 and the National Tour of 2015/16.

Other Ways You Can Help

Along with your monetary support, we would love to have you spread the word about Country Gravy and Other Obsessions with your friends.

story:
ABOUT THE TEAM

My name is Phil Rainford. I am an Edinburgh-based writer and performer. I have written quite a few monologues and sketches over the last couple of years. 

THE WEE ONE is my first full length stage play. Director Adam Tomkins and a cast of five talented local performers have come on board to stage the play's first ever performance. The play will be performed in Edinburgh's newest licensed studio theatre DISCOVER 21 for an exclusive run of THREE NIGHTS ONLY in MAY 2015 (see dates and times below). 

Tickets are available in advance. Please follow the link below to reserve seats:

theweeone.brownpapertickets.com

ABOUT THE PLAY

The play focuses on an older couple Marie and John and their grown up son, Danny, who persists in living with them. It is a heart-warming and original story about the tragi-comic circumstances of their situation.

ABOUT THE VENUE

Click here for the DISCOVER 21 website

DISCOVER 21 is a small studio theatre with a maximum capacity of 35, run by David MacFarlane and Jen Macgregor.  It is a producing and receiving space, home to BLACK DINGO PRODUCTIONS and TIGHTLACED THEATRE, run by Macfarlane and Macgregor respectively. They have created a permanent space for producing their own plays, hosting play readings and developing the works of new practitioners. They also invite companies to bring in small scale productions, of which this is one!  The ticket price is fixed at £5 . This makes the theatre experience affordable to all. 

ABOUT THE COSTS (CLEARS THROAT)

As I mentioned, the ticket price is set at £5 per person. From our revenue, we need to cover the cost of the following to make this production the success it deserves to be:

1. Venue hire.

2. Artists' fees.

3. Publicity - this includes online presence, flyers and posters.

4. Technical hire.

5. Production essentials - props, costumes and scenery.

6. Rehearsal space.

With an entirely Edinburgh-based cast and crew, this hilarious play will have you howling with laughter and is guaranteed to make you dash out and spend all your hard-earned savings at the bookies! Don't forget to wear your Fascinator!

LADIES DAY hopes to bring together a cast and crew of imaginative and experienced theatre artists to create a funny, lighthearted, memorable show for the people of Leith. The show will premiere at the Leith Festival in June 2017, produced by new writing company THEATRE IMPERATIVE.

It is crucial that we can raise sufficient funds to cover everyone's fees and all the other bits and pieces necessary to bring a new play to life fresh from the script and make it brilliant. Investments will also be used to benefit volunteers and participants from the Dry Dock and Dry Dock Womens' Group.

story:
“I'm interested in language. This play is curious about language and statelessness as forms, particularly displacement as a formal structure for a play. Displacement feels like America to me. The play is also very personal.  It draws upon different experiences I've had living both here and abroad. I believe the work brings forward some of the challenges to human dignity many people are facing right now. But ultimately I wanted to tell a theatrical story about life. Indeed a larger-than-life story that can only be told in a theater.” -- Phillip Howze, playwright

FRONTIÉRES SANS FRONTIÈRES is a world-premiere play about friendship and holding on to your identity while outside forces try to pull you apart. 

Our team of designers (Mariana Sanchez Hernandez, Seth Bodie, Masha Tsimring, Pornchanok Kanchanabanca), director Dustin Wills, and producers (Libby Peterson, Sally Shen, Alyssa Simmons) need your help to ensure audiences share in the spectacle that is FRONTIÉRES SANS FRONTIÈRES. 

The Bushwick Starr has supported the development of this play since 2015, and we're asking you to help us reach opening night. Whatever you are able to contribute, your gifts will go to supporting the artists working on the show. We can't make this happen without your help. Every gift, at any size, is helpful!

Please share the love and let others know about our campaign and come see us at the Bushwick Starr March 1 - 18. We can't wait to share this production with you.

Thank you so much for your help, for your support, for your enthusiasm! 

 

 

By: Phillip Howze

Directed by: Dustin Wills

Scenic Design: Mariana Sanchez Hernandez

Costume Design: Seth Bodie

Lighting Design: Masha Tsimring

Sound Design: Pornchanok Kanchanabanca

Stage Manager: Alyssa K. Howard*

Starring: Ceci Fernandez*, Rachel Leslie*, Emma Ramos*, Mirirai Sithole*, Sathya Sridharan*, Tony Vo*, Reggie D. White*, Mitchell Winter

*These actors and stage manager are appearing courtesy of Actors' Equity Association. 

Equity Approved Showcase

story:
About Us

Hello!  Our names are John Heagy and Tom England and we are writers and performers from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.  Growing up in respective small town upbringings we have always had a love of theater.  The ultimate goal for us is to make an impact on people's lives through the medium of theater, and we are fortunate enough to have been accepted into Take Ten Festival run by Between Us Productions in New York City.   We wrote our play,"Mr. Lockhardt," in an effort to re-conceptualize how inherent it is to fear. 

Creating "Mr. Lockhardt"

"Mr. Lockhardt" was written as a challenge to place ourselves in the shoes of person whose life has turned tragic in an instant.  We want to bring the emotions and experience of sudden tragedy to life on stage.  "Mr. Lockhardt" tells the story of a high school class whose lives become vulnerable and uncertain. The decisions these students make impact everyone around them and will ultimately reveal their true character. "Mr. Lockhardt" juxtaposes the image we have of ourselves against who we really are in times of crisis. 

Challenges

The biggest challenge facing the production of "Mr. Lockhardt" is having sufficient funds to create a realistic scene.  Another challenge is physically bringing a show from Philadelphia to New York.  This is increasingly difficult because have not established a name for ourselves as this is our first production.  We have to bring our show to New York which requires fundraising. We are hopeful that this is our first step towards solidifying a name for ourselves in both Philadelphia and New York City. 

Where Does My Donation Go?

In order for "Mr. Lockhardt" to succeed in New York we have to raise $3,200.  This $3,200 will purchase a set that includes:

  • Set and lighting equipment:  $1,200
  • Transport of the set from Philadelphia to New York: $200
  • Rehearsal space for a full month:  $200
  • Compensation for our cast and crew:  $1,600

For Me?

As a thank you for your generous contribution to our production we have "Mr. Lockhardt" giveaways that we will be updating as the campaign progresses.  To start off, we will be giving away free "Mr. Lockhardt" t-shirts for any donation of at least $100!  We cannot express enough how grateful we are for your generosity, and we want to thank you for helping making our dream a reality.  

Are There Other Ways I Can Help?

Absolutely!  Now, while any size donation, either $1 or $1,000 is greatly appreciated, we understand that not everyone is able to contribute financially.  So how can you still help?  Talking about it!  Word of mouth will go just as far as a donation!  Tell your friends, family, post about the campaign on Facebook, share it, retweet it,  and help us get the story of "Mr. Lockhardt" to as many people as possible!  Follow us on Facebook: Lambert Strong Productions. Twitter @LambertStrong, and on instagram: @lamberstrongprod for updates and more information about our process!

"Mr. Lockhardt" juxtaposes the image we have of ourselves against who we really are in times of crisis. 
Challenges
The biggest challenge facing the production of "Mr. Lockhardt" is having sufficient funds to create a realistic scene.  Another challenge is physically bringing a show from Philadelphia to New York.  This is increasingly difficult because have not established a name for ourselves as this is our first production.  We have to bring our show to New York which requires fundraising. We are hopeful that this is our first step towards solidifying a name for ourselves in both Philadelphia and New York City. 
Where Does My Donation Go?
In order for "Mr. Lockhardt" to succeed in New York we have to raise $3,200.  This $3,200 will purchase a set that includes:

Set and lighting equipment:  $1,200
Transport of the set from Philadelphia to New York: $200
Rehearsal space for a full month:  $200
Compensation for our cast and crew:  $1,600

For Me?
As a thank you for your generous contribution to our production we have "Mr. Lockhardt" giveaways that we will be updating as the campaign progresses.  To start off, we will be giving away free "Mr. Lockhardt" t-shirts for any donation of at least $100!  We cannot express enough how grateful we are for your generosity, and we want to thank you for helping making our dream a reality.  

Are There Other Ways I Can Help?
Absolutely!  Now, while any size donation, either $1 or $1,000 is greatly appreciated, we understand that not everyone is able to contribute financially.  So how can you still help?  Talking about it!  Word of mouth will go just as far as a donation!  Tell your friends, family, post about the campaign on Facebook, share it, retweet it,  and help us get the story of "Mr. Lockhardt" to as many people as possible!  Follow us on Facebook: Lambert Strong Productions. Twitter @LambertStrong, and on instagram: @lamberstrongprod for updates and more information about our process!

story:
"Hey Jonte is a young theatre company whose mission is to give women a place to roar and an outlet for everyone to "man up." Breaking the Shakespeare Code is a venture that succeeds delightfully on both counts."

-FRINGEREVIEW.CO.UK

A Powder Keg of a Play

Hey Jonte! Productions is teaming up with Boston-based playwright John Minigan for a THIRD TIME to present his gorgeously explosive piece, EASTER AT THE ENTREE GOLD, in New York at the Sam French Off Off Broadway Festival this August.  

Last year's THE MALTESE WALTER was, thanks to YOU, a smash hit, and the audience favorite. We'd like to continue bringing great theater to folks, and showcasing this playwright's work. 'Cause it's good, folks. It's really, really good.

But we're going to need your help!

"... a tour-de-force"
John Farrell, presstelegram.com

"...John Minigan’s brilliant and demanding new play"
David Roberts and Joseph Verlezza, Theatre Reviews Limited

US! (Or, who we are): 

We are a New York production company that produces new works: Stephen Brotebeck (director) hails from Michigan, Miranda Jonte (playwright, producer & actor) is a Bay Area girl, and John Minigan (playwright) lives in Framingham , Mass. We've brought premieres to both Chicago and New York, and we love what we do. Our last production of a Minigan play, the audience went nuts. Like our other productions, we got raves across the board!!

-Cast & crew of last year's MALTESE WALTER, Sam French OOB, NYC, 2015

Where does the moolah go?

We're working with Creative Women New York (CWNY), a 501(c)3. Their goal is to support women in the arts; they are our fiscal sponsor, which means your donations are TAX DEDUCTIBLE. Indiegogo will send your donation directly to CWNY.

Here's why we need the money:

• We've got a cast and crew to costume and feed: stage manager extraordinaire Kyrie McCormick, our cast, and the captain of the ship, our director.

• Rehearsal space: This is where we figure out who goes where and who says 'what' how. It's where we make the magic happen!

Costumes: As a prep school teacher, we've got to smarten Noah up in the role of Peter. And...for John in the role of Spence...let's just say we need to find a gown that fits him. Yes, a gown. And did we mention a blonde wig?

• Printed Materials: We've got to let the world know we're coming! Postcards and posters help to make this happen.

*Insurance: In the event of worst-case scenario, we're required (and we agree!) to provide accident insurance for our cast and crew.

The Impact

When you contribute to this project, you are helping to get our production on its feet. Over 1500 plays were submitted for this year’s 40th annual festival and EASTER AT THE ENTREE GOLD was one of only 30 selected to perform--but it can’t make it without your support. Your contribution will put the play, Hey Jonte!, and the playwright on stage in New York’s most important venue for short plays, in a festival sponsored by America’s premier publisher of new work!

And by supporting us through Creative Women New York, you are ensuring companies like Hey Jonte!, which employs a wide range of folks, can continue to build shows, create theater, and foster relationships in the arts. 

Repeat: it's tax deductible.

Risks & Challenges

It can be daunting to raise money--to donate money--for a project when you're unsure of the team's track record. We totally get it. Here's a glimpse of our past doings:

St. Francis. Full length play, had its world premiere at FringeNYC, Aug 2015. Selected for publishing in Applause Books' Best American Festival Plays of 2015, out this December

The Maltese Walter. Sam French OOB Fest, Aug. 2015. Selected for publication in the Best 10-Minute Plays Anthology

Breaking the Shakespeare Code. NYC premiere, FringeNYC, Aug 2014

Breaking the Shakespeare Code. Full-length play, professional premiere, Chicago, June 2014

Greasemonkey. Full length play, NYC premiere, 2013


Other Ways You Can Help

We just want to create outstanding theater. And bring it to everybody in the world. You don't have to give us money to help us out. You can tell your friends and family. If you can spread the word through social media, word of mouth, chatting with your favorite barista, passing out postcards, we'll be very grateful. Everything helps!

And if you DO contribute, Indiegogo will provide links to help you spread the word on social media. Don't be shy about it!

story:
About Cardboard Playhouse Theatre Company

Cardboard Playhouse Theatre Company, created by Doug Montoya and Kristin Berg in December 2004, prides itself on being one of the only children's theatre companies in Albuquerque that casts children on their ability to perform, not on their ability to pay. CPTC keeps itself viable by generating revenue through ticket sales and grants. CPTC was formed by a love of both improv and children, and fosters self expression, self confidence, and creativity through the use of an improv-based theatrical program. CPTC asks children to think for themselves and to take a sense of ownership in the show. To date Cardboard Playhouse has produced over 52 productions casting over a thousand local adult and child actors.

We are now at a point where we want to continue working with some of our alumni who have “aged out” to produce shows that are family friendly and fun! We have produced “Little Shop of Horrors,” “You’re a Good Man, Charlie Brown,” and “The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee” with our alumni actors. “Peter and the Starcatcher” is the next in this exciting series of alumni productions.

We are very excited to be doing this show with alumni actors and guest artists from the Albuquerque community.

About Peter and the Starcatcher

Tony-winning Peter and the Starcatcher upends the century-old story of how a miserable orphan comes to be The Boy Who Would Not Grow Up (a.k.a. Peter Pan). A wildly theatrical adaptation of Dave Barry and Ridley Pearson’s best-selling novels, the play was conceived for the stage by directors, Roger Rees and Alex Timbers, and written by Rick Elice, with music by Wayne Barker. From marauding pirates and jungle tyrants to unwilling comrades and unlikely heroes, Peter and the Starcatcher playfully explores the depths of greed and despair... and the bonds of friendship, duty and love.

What We Need

Here are some of the many costs associated with mounting a production:

  • Performance rights
  • Pay for actors
  • Pay for Stage Manager
  • Marketing / Advertising
  • Sets
  • Props
  • Costumes
  • Rehearsal space
  • Production photos
  • Lighting/Sound

All funds raised will go directly to producing Peter and the Starcatcher. Any profit in ticket sales will go to fund future Cardboard Playhouse shows.

What You Get

We have put together some awesome perks for the many levels of donations, but first and foremost, this is a great place to pre-purchase your tickets for Peter and the Starcatcher!!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute anything at all (we get it, really!), please:

Share our campaign! Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, MySpace, screaming the URL on the Railrunner to Santa Fe…anything helps!

Use the IndieGoGo share tools at the top!

Thank you for helping us share this story of growing up!
