story:
Meet the Cast Videos - Recap & Revisit!

Take a moment to get to know each cast member by watching personal videos they made! 

  • Ep 1 - Angels City 4 (Jesse Alvarez, Thomas King, Lindsay Warnock, Janet Gigliotti)
  • Ep 2 - Michelle Harrison
  • Ep 3 - Crystal Balint
  • Ep 4 - Callum Gunn & Miranda MacDougall
  • Ep 5 - Tim Perez
  • Ep 6 - Miranda MacDougall
  • Ep 7 - Ken Overbey
  • Ep 8 - Jennifer Copping

Angel Endorsements -- What The Stars Say

Check out all the big names who think you should contribute to our campaign! 

  • Tom Cavanagh & Carlos Valdes
  • Jesse L Martin - "A Cappella Serenade”
  • Rukiya Bernard
  • Aleks Paunovic

 

Join the PIT Collective on this grassroots theatrical venture, as we bring the Tony Award-winning musical "City of Angels," to Vancouver. this July!  We’ve assembled a diverse cast of industry professionals and fresh faces eager to introduce you to this glamorous show -- an homage to old Hollywood and film noir motion pictures.

Our production will mark the premier production of "City of Angels" in Vancouver!  But we need your help to make this happen. Our show is produced by it's performers and independently funded, so to make our dream a reality, we’re turning to our friends, families, and the robust, vibrant arts community to reach OUR GOAL of $40,000. 

But first...

The show is a musical comedy and an homage to the film noir genre, with a story that delightfully satirizes the glamour and decadence of 1940s Hollywood.  It revolves around Stine, a New York crime novelist given the opportunity to adapt his book for the silver screen. He packs his bags, trading the grey skies of the Big Apple for LA’s sunshine, palm trees, and the promise of fame.  But nothing is as easy as it seems, and as Stine faces compromises and romantic failures,  the show divides into two storylines --the all too colourful "real" world of a writer trying to turn his book into a screenplay, and the monochrome world of the fictional film he imagines to write. 

We love this play and we know you will too! "City of Angels" is reminiscent of contemporary hits like HAIL, CAESAR! and LALA LAND, while maintaining the timeless nostalgia of SINGIN' IN THE RAIN. It’s exploration of celebrity and the cost of fame make it just as daring and perhaps more relevant now than when it was first performed!  

With some well-known faces and some fresh blood to stir the pot, we’ve searched high and low to put together an A-Team of actors and crew to bring this show to life.  Our team is an enthusiastic and diverse group hand-picked from the theatre, film & TV industries across North America. We are ready to wow the audiences in Vancouver this summer.

Our entire production budget is actually over $50k, but we hope that our campaign will raise $40k of it, with box office making up the remainder. Should we exceed our budget, funds will be allocated to miscellaneous expenses as well as ideally some stipend for each member of the cast and crew that is currently working (happily!) without renumeration

In our current economic and political climate, we believe it’s more important than ever to engage in local arts initiatives. With your support, our show will succeed in sending a poignant message to the powers that be that the theatre's place in the epicentre of community is still very much alive. 

With your generosity, the viability of our unique production model will serve as proof that self-started arts initiatives work and will further solidify Vancouver’s global reputation as a hub of first class talent and creativity.

We have some exclusive and exciting PERKS to offer our backers -- designed to fit any budget. All of which, are located to your right as you scroll down. 

Below are a number of perks that we're particularly excited about:

  • Project Limelight - is a program that provides free access to theatre experiences for kids ages 8-15 living on Vancouver's Downtown East Side. Through theatre, Project Limelight helps kids discover their inner strengths, explore their hidden talents, develop confidence, and form lasting friendships. Believe in the power of musical theatre, but can't make it to Vancouver for our show? We have the perfect perk -- you can sponsor two tickets that we'll give to kids from Project Limelight. 
  • Makeup Magic - This perk awards you a deluxe package of "consciously curated" Sappho goodies.  Makeup remover, cruelty-free brushes and contour powder set. Completely vegan - no artificial derivatives. Retail value of $280! But wait, there's more. You'll get everything in the $100 Van City of Angels perk! 
  • Custom Painting - Callum Gunn will create a custom piece of art tailored to your vision. The medium can include any combination of ACRYLIC, INDIA INK, OIL PENS and/or DIGITAL. From abstract portraiture to a personalized souvenir of “City of Angels,” I will provide you with a unique 11x14 image before the show opens on July 8th, 2017.
  • Celebrated filmmaker and playwright Neil Labute (In the Company of Men, Reasons to be Pretty, The Shape of Things) will read your entire script or your play and send back notes and advice!
  • Dennys Ilic's latest photography book MEN OF SCIENCE FICTION

And many many more!

Please make a contribution of any amount! Every penny helps.

And take a moment to tell your friends about our campaign by forwarding the link to others via email, or posting to your social media accounts.  We're on:

Facebook

Twitter 

Instagram

Follow us and spread the word in whatever way you can!

Thank you so much for your time, generosity, and support - we look forward to sharing "City of Angels" with the City of Vancouver and beyond!

 

FAQ #1 - I’m having some technical difficulties making my donation.  

When I'm on the page with my PERK selected and I've entered all my details, I continue to the payment button but the button goes blank and I can’t get any further with my donation.  What should I do?

Answer: When entering your address details, you must select the drop down option for the province.  Please don’t type it in.  If you've manually typed in “British Columbia” or “BC” (or your province of residence) for the province, the site will seem to accept it but will actually freeze the page and not allow you to continue. It's a minor change, but that should do the trick.
 

FAQ #2 - Do you have specific dates scheduled for the performance in July 2017?

Answer: You bet! Once our campaign is successful, we are targeting the following dates for our exciting show: July 8-17th, 2017! In the unlikely event that we fall a little short of our Indiegogo goal, it may impact what we're able to spend on venue and/or production which could in turn shift the dates slightly. We'll definitely keep everyone posted once dates are confirmed!

story:
VISITING HOURS

Decades of conflict has left the Stein family set in an unspoken state of war. But when the family’s crazy – though not insane -- matriarch lands in the ICU, the perpetual silence is permanently broken, uncovering old wounds and creating new ones. Visiting Hours follows the Steins as they attempt to navigate the present in the shadow of the past.

TEAM

Written by Joshua Kaplan

Directed by Dina Vovsi

Featuring Michael Grew, Amy Gaipa, Dan Grimaldi, Karen Tsen Lee, Joel Stigliano, Richarda Abrams, Adam Bemis, and Maureen Shannon

Lighting by Jason Fok

Sound by Emma Wilk

Scenic design by Frank Oliva

Stage Manager Ryan Keller


WHEN & WHERE

The world premiere of Visiting Hours will be presented at Theaterlab NYC from July 28-31. 


WHY SHOULD YOU HELP?

Because you know and/or love one of us.

Because you know and/or love someone else.

Because you have a complicated relationship with a parent/sibling/child/significant other.

Because a parent/sibling/child/significant other has a complicated relationship with you.

And most of all, because of this bit of wisdom, courtesy of Stella Adler:

The word theatre comes from the Greeks. It means the seeing place. It is the place people to come to see the truth about life and the social situation.

Support the truth. Our version of it, at least.


HOW CAN YOU HELP?

Your financial help will ensure that this production of Visiting Hours will be fully realized. Your contribution will help provide the necessary rehearsal space, costumes, sets, artistic stipends, lighting, participation fee and so many other elements that will bring this story to life. 

But there are other ways to show support as well!

- Spread the word about Visiting Hours. Share our campaign with your friends and family!

- Like us on Facebook!

- Contact us at visitinghourstheplay@gmail.com regarding volunteer opportunities. We will need helping hands throughout the run!

- And of course, come see it! Tickets available at Ovation Tix!

Written by Joshua Kaplan
Directed by Dina Vovsi
Featuring Michael Grew, Amy Gaipa, Dan Grimaldi, Karen Tsen Lee, Joel Stigliano, Richarda Abrams, Adam Bemis, and Maureen Shannon
Lighting by Jason Fok
Sound by Emma Wilk
Scenic design by Frank Oliva
Stage Manager Ryan Keller

WHEN & WHERE
The world premiere of Visiting Hours will be presented at Theaterlab NYC from July 28-31. 


WHY SHOULD YOU HELP?
Because you know and/or love one of us.
Because you know and/or love someone else.
Because you have a complicated relationship with a parent/sibling/child/significant other.
Because a parent/sibling/child/significant other has a complicated relationship with you.
And most of all, because of this bit of wisdom, courtesy of Stella Adler:
The word theatre comes from the Greeks. It means the seeing place. It is the place people to come to see the truth about life and the social situation.
Support the truth. Our version of it, at least.

HOW CAN YOU HELP?
Your financial help will ensure that this production of Visiting Hours will be fully realized. Your contribution will help provide the necessary rehearsal space, costumes, sets, artistic stipends, lighting, participation fee and so many other elements that will bring this story to life. 
But there are other ways to show support as well!
- Spread the word about Visiting Hours. Share our campaign with your friends and family!
- Like us on Facebook!
- Contact us at visitinghourstheplay@gmail.com regarding volunteer opportunities. We will need helping hands throughout the run!
- And of course, come see it! Tickets available at Ovation Tix!

story:
The Gist

So finally after 11 years of working on my autobiographical bilingual (English-Polish) one-man play titled INTRUDER|INTRUZ, my dreams of putting the play on are coming to fruition. The play tells a story of a young Polish man who comes to Scotland to make his dreams come true and become an actor but is a victim of traumatic events. 

Remi's story ... 

Since I remember I've always wanted to be an actor. I actually never remember saying it but I remember my father replying 'Yes, you're going to be an actor  .......... after they burn down all the theatres'. Though, I always wanted to do it in English. After many disappointments in Poland and being told by quite a few professionals that I would never make it as an actor, I received an offer from the Royal Conservatoire of Scotland. Yes, but it took 14 years to get that offer.

At the drama school, I ran to my classes early morning to do my daily warm-ups but an incident in Edinburgh in March 2009 during the spring semester had a big impact on it. The same evening, I put it all on paper as a way of getting out my frustration. I wrote it 'being in the moment' and never thought I would ever make a play out of it. Actually, I never wanted to come back to the written account of the event and I put it in a drawer. It was that evening when the first 14 pages of INTRUDER were written. 

Intruder | Intruz ... and the influences

The account of the incident in Edinburgh became the foundation for my passion project. Originally, I wrote it in English with Polish elements and there is now a Polish version with English elements titled INTRUZ. I translated the piece into Polish as I wanted to share my story with so many Poles living in England. 

The play is non-linear because I wanted it to have a structure of some of my favourite films e.g. Paul Thomas Anderson's 'Magnolia' or Christopher Nolan's 'Inception'. But it was Tom Ford's 'Nocturnal Animals' that helped me with the final re-structuring of the piece.   

INTRUDER|INTRUZ is very dynamic with the plot shifting in a split-second. It's interactive and performed in intimate spaces for the audience to be inside the events. It’s a very touching, moving, brutal, and forgiving tale with the elements of black humour that would keep the audience rooted to see how it is played out.  Very original, important and timely and with its current themes, it deserves to be told.

Why is this play important?

 mental health

anxiety

 forgiveness

  restorative justice system

 what it's like to be an immigrant

what it's like to be a victim of violence

 finally, making your dreams come true

these themes of the play came up very organically and to be quite honest life wrote them. I found it very interesting and to some extent therapeutic to work on the play especially during the initial development of it in Glasgow in 2012. Looking at your own life and being told of certain patterns of behaviour is fascinating and made me think a lot about how I behave and what I do. Taking certain emotions e.g. feeling anxious, for granted and then being told, 'No, it's not ok, to feel this way' was very liberating especially when I met people who went through similar incidents and experienced similar emotions and feelings.

What added to the whole complexity of the story was the fact that my first language is Polish and I studied the English language and lived in Scotland when it all happened. Bilingualism is a key part of the whole story. 'In a crisis, does my mind think in English or in Polish?', 'Is it English or Polish I feel more comfortable with when anxious?', 'Is it Polish or English my brain goes automatically by default when anxious?' - I still keep asking myself.

On top of that, it all happened in Scotland, not Poland, and not having gone through similar experiences before, I wasn't aware of certain procedures and support that was available in Scotland. And since some of the procedures and regulations are non-existent in Poland, I thought, that's how it is in every country. That added an extra layer of confusion. 

I feel this play is important because all kinds of things happen to us, good or bad, and we still need to fulfil our potential and do things that we want to achieve. I feel watching the play will give the audience hope and motivation to overcome certain difficulties no matter what has happened to them.

Reactions

Feedback from the BBC Writersroom

This is an excellent and original monologue spoken straight from the heart. The storytelling is rapid and urgent – it is told like the narrator's life depends on it. In a story that jumps backwards and forwards in time, between countries and languages .[...]Though the story is often bleak the language used is buzzy, sparky, poetic and darkly funny. The writing of the monologue itself becomes a redemptive act. The writer has a great eye for detail. Unusual and bizarre details are honed in on. [...] This is a bold and original voice that throws an interesting and heartbreaking light on what it means to be an immigrant and what it means to be a victim of violence.

Peter Arnott, a leading Scottish playwright tweeted

This is a really interesting piece of work ... a comic and painful exploration of the differences between getting mugged in Edinburgh and Warsaw! Written and performed by Remi ... it's a really individual take on the 'Pole in Scotland' experience  ... and dramatically innovative too.

Feedback from rehearsed readings

' ... very powerful stuff; keep working on it; looking forward to seeing next stage...'

'... a very funny and accomplished performance, well done...'

'...well done on a powerful, deeply personal and funny piece of storytelling. I look forward to seeing a full staging, which will help illuminate some of the more nuanced aspects of the piece and make clearer definitions between scene changed + time shifts ...'

'I liked it; fantastic acting; plot keeps you engaged and in suspense; no time to think of anything else apart from the play; excellent dramatic storytelling; worked very well as a piece of theatre'

The journey so far ...

It was David Overend, an assistant director on a short film I was making in Glasgow in 2010, who when told about the incident in Edinburgh and my written account of it expressed an interest in reading the 14 pages. It was the first time I took the pages out of the drawer. We soon worked on it at the Arches in Glasgow. Initially, I found it very difficult to detach myself from all the events to make it a piece of theatre. It seemed to me I was reliving the whole incident again. Upon reflection, I conclude the 11 years that have passed from the incident in Edinburgh were probably the time I needed to put the play on. 

In 2012, Creative Scotland provided funding for an initial development, ran in Glasgow with my late friend and drama school classmate, director Amanda Gaughan, dramaturg Catherine Grosvenor and actor Mark Wood. The subsequent redraft was shortlisted for 2013 Adrian Pagan Playwrighting Competition at London’s King’s Head Theatre. The benefit of being shortlisted was a rehearsed reading of that draft at the Hope Theatre, London, directed by Oscar Toeman. Having received feedback from quite many literary managers after the reading, I began redrafting and redrafting. In 2017 I submitted a new and restructured draft to BBC Writersroom Drama and I couldn't believe that it got to the final shortlist, selected out of nearly 3800 scripts.

In 2018, when the play was getting more momentum, my director friend Amanda Gaughan died tragically. Fortunately, a director friend from a year below at the Conservatoire, Marcus Montgomery Roche, expressed an interest in working on it and between September-December 2018, we held a few rehearsed sharings/readings in London e.g. Dragon's Cafe, Hope Theatre, King's Head Theatre, and in Scotland e.g. North Edinburgh Arts. We collaborated on these readings with Edinburgh-based Asylon Theatre and its Artistic Director, Marta Mari.

 

Soon after I assembled the following

TEAM

Remi Rachuba (actor/writer/co-producer)  - www.remirachuba.com

Remi, a native Pole, having initially studied teaching English, settled in Scotland and graduated from the Royal Conservatoire of Scotland. His first professional job was performing in a dreamthinkspeak’s site-specific production titled Before I Sleep at 2010 Brighton Theatre Festival, awarded with Peter Brook Best Ensemble Award and subsequently presented at the Holland Festival in 2011. He has also performed in dreamthinkspeak’s The Rest is Silence, In the Beginning was the End and Absent. Remi was a Scottish servant in a Katie Mitchell's production of Lucia di Lammermoor at the Royal Opera House in 2016 and is coming back to the 3rd revival of the opera in May 2020. Additionally, since graduating he has participated in a production at the Traverse Theatre titled ‘The Builders’ with Plutot La Vie, toured with a T.I.E production of Pinocchio. He also participated in the Berlinale Talent Campus at the Berlin International Film Festival.

Marcus Montgomery Roche (director) - http://marcusroche.strikingly.com

Marcus Roche is currently assistant director to Declan Donnellan at Cheek by Jowl and is touring with their new production of Pericles by William Shakespeare. In 2015 he toured with their production of The Winter's Tale. He studied at the Royal Scottish Academy of Music and Drama and École Philippe Gaulier in Paris. In 2012 he directed The Agony and Ecstasy of Steve Jobs by Mike Daisey which received critical acclaim was nominated for a CATS award and the Amnesty International Freedom of Speech Award. For Taganrog Opera and Drama Theatre (Russia) he directed a contemporary movement version of Romeo and Juliet. In 2014 he created Vote For Me which was part of the Early Days Festival at the Arches. He has directed The Night before the Trial a couple of Chekhov's short stories as a curtain-raiser to the Tron Theatre’s production of Three Sisters. He has directed for the Tron Theatre, the Arches, Play, Pie and a Pint, Wee Theatres, Royal Conservatoire of Scotland and Theatre 503.  He has worked closely with Rachel O’Riorda on Macbeth.

Basia Bińkowska (set/costume designer) - www.basiabinkowska.com

Basia is a performance designer based in London. Before completing a theatre design course in the UK, she trained in fine arts in her native Poland. She is the overall winner of the Linbury Prize for Stage Design 2017 with the winning design for Lyric Hammersmith's production of Othellomacbeth. She was nominated for the Best Designer at the Stage Debut Awards 2018 and has been recently nominated for an Offie for Best Set Design for Blood Knot at Orange Tree. Recent credits include Crooked Dances (Royal Shakespeare Company), Acts of Resistance (Headlong Theatre & Bristol Old Vic), Wolfie (Theatre503), Blood Knot (Orange Tree Theatre), Othellomacbeth (Lyric Hammersmith & Home Manchester), Cuckoo (Soho Theatre), Devil with a Blue Dress (Bunker Theatre), Ivan and the Dogs (Young Vic).

Charles Webber (lighting/sound designer) -  https://www.youtube.com/user/operaNCV

Charles Webber is an electronic artist who has worked in experimental performance for the past 30 years, working across the disciplines of electro-acoustic music, moving image and lighting design, installation, contemporary puppetry, opera, theatre, and dance. Such projects include; Dead Wedding at the 2007 Manchester International Festival and Barbican BITE, with puppeteers Faulty Optic (Lighting Designer / Sound Designer), Fevered Sleep's An Infinite Line at the 2008 Brighton Festival (Sound Designer / Film-maker) and Kanaval by Hubert Essakow in 2011 (Composer / Video Designer). His most recent collaboration has been with choreographer Gary Clarke, working on the 2016 multi-award winning COAL, for which he was nominated for the prestigious Knight of Illumination award for lighting design in the dance category, and most recently the critically acclaimed 2019 work Wasteland (Composer / Lighting Designer / Video Designer).

Cindy Derby (poster designer) - www.cindyderby.com

Cindy Derby is an illustrator and author based out of San Francisco.  How to Walk an Ant is her first picture book (Roaring Brook Press, March 2019). Other picture book titles (as illustrator) include: Climbing Shadows by Shannon Bramer (Groundwood Books, 2019); Outside by New York Times best selling author Deborah Underwood (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, 2020); The Boy and the 800-Pound Gorilla by Jackie Azua Kramer (Candlewick Press, 2020). Cindy's background is in puppetry and she has performed all over the world. She received her Master of Arts from The Royal Conservatoire of Scotland and was awarded grants from organizations such as The Jim Henson Foundation and Puppet Animation Scotland to assist in the creation of her shows.  In 2014 Cindy won the grand prize for her illustration portfolio at the international SCBWI conference in Los Angeles.

Ed Littlewood (general manager/financial authority) - www.edlittlewood.com

Ed Littlewood studied at the Royal Academy of Music and worked at the Royal Opera House, Young Vic and Theatre Cryptic, before producing productions independently and commercially. He is currently producing A Good Enough Girl? – a co-production with Greenwich Theatre and Nutshell Theatre, Handfast – a Nutshell Theatre and Byre Theatre co-production, At Your Leisure – with Room 2 Manoeuvre as part of VisitScotland’s Year of Young People 2018, and A Joke with Tony Cownie, Neil Murray and John Kielty. His production Hector successfully toured the UK with a London transfer (Ambassadors Theatre) and sell-out performances.

Past productions and partnerships include Théâtre Sans Frontières (two-year strategic tour of David Almond’s Heaven Eyes); Creation Theatre (Henry V, Lion, Witch, and the Wardrobe); Plutôt la Vie (By the Seat of Your Pants (national tour / IPAY – Philadelphia International Children’s Festival/ Imaginate Festival); Room 2 Manoeuvre (Watch iT! – Made in Scotland Programme / Almeida Theatre, Without a Hitch – Finland / Luxembourg / UK tour), Nutshell Theatre (Allotment – Fringe First winner – UK tour, 106 performances / Thread – Fringe First winner – UK tour, co-production with Assembly / ONFife). 

Already supported

We've already had amazing support from Polish weekly magazines in London e.g. 'Cooltura','Tydzień Polski', and londynek.net, the most popular website for the Poles in the United Kingdom.

 

1 condition - Why do I need your help?

We have received funding from Arts Council England but one of the conditions of receiving the funding is raising £3600 towards the tour. Without the money, we wouldn't be able to do it. We are planning 14 performances in total (10 performances of the Polish version and 4 performances of the English version) with 4 platform productions in London in April (1,2,3,4) then Bedford, Slough, Bognor Regis, Croydon, Wandsworth,  Manchester.

The money will go towards

  • accommodation and transport
  • venue hire costs
  • set and costumes
  • printing of posters 

 

By supporting INTRUDER|INTRUZ, you would be joining a very prestigious group of mentors supporting the arts, the play with its themes and me, a young artist, emerging, promising artist and helping to make his dreams come true. 

Extra

An additional £4400 would help present the piece in Scotland (as for me this piece belongs to Scotland), Poland e.g. in my home-town Kudowa Zdrój. We have already had an invitation to perform at United Solo Festival in New York but because of financial reasons, we needed to postpone that trip. This money would go towards

  • transport of the team to these places and housing them
  • generating and printing publicity materials and hiring a PR company

 

These efforts are pricy but worth it!  These resources will help get the outreach it deserves.  If we use it well, the tour of England will be a fantastic launching platform to finally bring this play to wider audiences. I can't wait to share the play with audiences.

Keep in touch

Website: www.intruderplay.com

Facebook: @intruderplay

Twitter: @intruderplay

 

Bardzo serdecznie dziękuję

 in advance for supporting INTRUDER|INTRUZ and spreading the word to your network!

We have received funding from Arts Council England but one of the conditions of receiving the funding is raising £3600 towards the tour. Without the money, we wouldn't be able to do it. We are planning 14 performances in total (10 performances of the Polish version and 4 performances of the English version) with 4 platform productions in London in April (1,2,3,4) then Bedford, Slough, Bognor Regis, Croydon, Wandsworth,  Manchester.
The money will go towards

accommodation and transport
venue hire costs
set and costumes
printing of posters 

 
By supporting INTRUDER|INTRUZ, you would be joining a very prestigious group of mentors supporting the arts, the play with its themes and me, a young artist, emerging, promising artist and helping to make his dreams come true. 
Extra
An additional £4400 would help present the piece in Scotland (as for me this piece belongs to Scotland), Poland e.g. in my home-town Kudowa Zdrój. We have already had an invitation to perform at United Solo Festival in New York but because of financial reasons, we needed to postpone that trip. This money would go towards

transport of the team to these places and housing them
generating and printing publicity materials and hiring a PR company

 
These efforts are pricy but worth it!  These resources will help get the outreach it deserves.  If we use it well, the tour of England will be a fantastic launching platform to finally bring this play to wider audiences. I can't wait to share the play with audiences.


Keep in touch
Website: www.intruderplay.com
Facebook: @intruderplay
Twitter: @intruderplay
 
Bardzo serdecznie dziękuję
 in advance for supporting INTRUDER|INTRUZ and spreading the word to your network!

story:
Formed in 2008 by Cheek by Jowl's associate director Owen Horsley, Eyestrings Theatre Company is committed to producing courageous and bold interpretations of the classics. We aim to convey an experience provisional and lived, in which our actors inhabit a precarious present, never simply expressing an emotion but always reacting to the audience and trying to control the rapid propulsion of the narrative.

We are devoted to our audience by creating work that is always informed by the specific contours of each space we perform in, a space that our audience inhabit also. We believe the stories we perform still play a crucial part in understanding our society and we strive to create images that encourage the audience to re-open their eyes. 

Eyestrings' goal is to begin touring, sharing the classics presented with the company’s unique stamp. The work which we have chosen to begin our touring life, is The Duchess of Malfi, which originated from a workshop and showing in 2011 at the Soho Theatre, and has now been confirmed for a run at the Oxford Playhouse Burton Taylor Studio and at The White Bear in London in September.

The production, which had an incredible response when we presented it to an audience at the Soho Theatre, exposes the play in a way that many of our audience have never seen before. The brutality of the play is matched by the starkness of the space – six chairs occupied by smiling figures confront the audience as they enter the space. A gramophone record bounces along as it plays an uplifting ditty in the corner – the voices from the dead providing the up beat soundtrack to this tragic tale. 

 

"The clarity of this version of The Duchess of Malfi made this compelling and dark tale all the more powerful and hard hitting. Images from this stylish and highly charged piece of theatre still live, hauntingly, in my mind" - Griselda Yorke, Executive Producer, Punchdrunk

 

We are looking to raise £1,500 to go towards funding a week of touring at the Oxford Playhouse and three weeks at The White Bear in London. We are also seeking funding from individuals and from Arts Council England. If you feel you can support this production in any other way and would like to find out more, please contact owenhorsley@gmail.com

story:
We Are Going To Europe!

ManyTracks produced the premiere of Shooter during March 2018 in NYC. Shooter has now become committed for a European cultural tour spanning three countries over 6 performances in 12 days during January 2019.

Shooter is a play which explores a uniquely American problem; mass shootings, almost all committed by men. With each violent shooter-massacre carried out by a man, Shooter questions the relationship of not just our gun culture to the male identity but also of how men fail each other when they need each other most.

“Skillfully written … Katrin Hilbe directs the show meticulously… Ean Sheehy gives a terrific performance… exposing the character’s journey with focus and clarity” --New York Critic

Why We Need

  • 12-day tour, Jan 12-24, 2019
  • TAK Theater (Liechtenstein), Theater Konstanz (Germany), The American Theater Festival in Rome (Italy)

Europe is asking for this production. This is why we are going.

We will not have our gun violence stand for America. We are American artists going to tell the world we are not alone, and that we are all consequences of one society's trauma.

“Director Hilbe masterfully weaves dramatic moments together…riveting drama focuses attention on an issue of crucial importance in our world.” --Berkshire Fine Arts

This is the theater we're performing at in Rome, Jan 22-23.

What We Need

We have already received $20,000 from various grants and institutions -- Kulturstiftung Liechtenstein, Migros Kulturprozent, Karl Mayer Stiftung -- among others.

Let us repeat: we already got $20,000.

We need the final $10,000 to complete our tour budget.

  • Airfare! Actors gotta fly!
  • Lodging! Actors gotta sleep!
  • Food! Actors gotta eat!

Obviously, touring 9 people around Europe is complicated. We have a tour manager, director and technical support accompanying our 6 incredible actors. We have a detailed and no-holds-barred itinerary.

We thought we were going to have serious problems raising money. But Europe stepped up. They got us two-thirds of the way to our goal. We need America to help us now.

“Shooter makes a lot of smart choices when it comes to dealing with its subject.” --Exeunt

This is where we're performing at in Germany, Jan 16-17.

Your Trust

This is not some wild theater expedition.

Katrin Hilbe, director, secured the European dates based on her being a Liechtenstein-US citizen. Katrin has worked consistently in the US and her home region and is dedicated to continuing her successful, lifelong work of establishing creative connections and collaborations between American and European audiences.

The people going are lifelong artists and career theater practitioners.

You can see at ShooterThePlay.com the full list of cast and crew, plus all pictures from the original production. You can see the reviews and the impact.

“Interrogates both liberal and conservative points of view in earnest by focusing on the humanity of the issue…" -- Clyde Fitch Report

We've Done All The Work

We have booked everything. We are going. Now we just need to finish paying for it.

  • Contribute!
  • Contribute!
  • Contribute!

That's all there is to it.

story:
|||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||
 
Inspired by the early pioneers of manned-flight as well as the psychological tolls of ambition and dreams, Kill Devil Hills will be developed for a workshop production in Summer 2012 at Collaboraction in the Wicker Park area of Chicago. The goal is to present a fully realized version of the live performance at Burning Man in Nevada in Summer 2013.
 
A Collaborative effort of Ryan Dorin (sound), Casey Wimpee (text), Adam Laten Willson, Isaac Byrne, Christopher Baker, Zoe Metcalfe-Klaw, Will Neuman, Michael Mason, Lucy Kaminsky, Adam Belvo (performers), Kalli Newman (producer), Marilyn Mithra-Stone (producer), Tricia Bastian (costumes), Kari Giron (documentary), & Cole Wimpee (actions).
 
This project involves collaborative artists coming together in Chicago from NYC, Iceland, California, and Texas.
 
|||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||
 
 
                   |||||||||||||||   Early Character Sketches by Michael Mason    |||||||||||||||
||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||| 
The motivation for Kill Devil Hills project can be traced back to Summer 2008 in Brooklyn, when early sketches and thematic ideas were tossed around about creating a new live theatre show combining the ideas of the Wright Brothers with a Steampunk-like aesthetic. Always aware that the type of performance we'd want to do would require an unusual setting, cast-size and design requirements, we kept it 'on the shelf' as we stayed busy telling other stories in NYC, Washington D.C., and New Orleans.
 
In the summer of 2011, we were approached by an investor who had an interest to going to BURNING MAN. After some thoughtful consideration, we determined this was the perfect opportunity to finally realize the vision of Kill Devil Hills. We spent Autumn 2011 working with designers and an architect with NYC's Foster + Partners to create visualization CAD drafts of a vessel in the desert. Due to an unexpected event in January of 2012, our initial source of financing had fallen through. We quickly decided to strike out on our own and combine whatever innovation and invention we could muster to tell the story we've set out to tell.
 
 
Collaboraction - one of the new pioneers of Chicago alternative/ensemble theatre will be hosting us for a workshop presentation in September 2012. The objective is to further develop the show for a Burning Man / NYC production in Summer 2013.
 
 
|||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||
 

AZTEC ECONOMY is a Brooklyn-based non-profit arts company initiated in Spring 2008 to bring new performances to a live public. Our work seeks to provide a fresh perspective on American culture and its relationship to ritual, mythology, madness, dreams, and deliverance. Previous projects have been featured in the Obie Award Winning Ice Factory, at P.S.122, Dixon Place, The Tank, Onboard the Steamship Lilac, The Brick Theater, Bushwick Open Studios, Brooklyn Fireproof, House of Yes, Big Sky Works, the New Orleans Fringe Festival, The Fridge in Washington D.C., and bars, backyards, rooftops, and churches all over NYC, AZTEC ECONOMY is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas.

Our mission to bring this distinctly new vision to life requires travel expenses for our group, costume design, venue rental, and insurance. Every contribution helps!

|||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||

                              What We Need & What You Get

Funding for the following aspects of the project are needed:

                                  Venue Rental: $1,000

                                 Venue Deposit: $1,000

                     Costume Design & Production: $2,000

                             Group Travel Fares: $2,000

                        Lodging & Misc Expenses: $2,000

 

PERKS for contribution include: Free Admission to our upcoming show in Brooklyn, a hand-drawn thank you design by Michael Mason, a song-of-your-choice tribute Youtube video by Adam Laten Willson, Free Admission to all Aztec shows for a full calendar year, Listing of thanks and support on our website, co-producing credit for Kill Devil Hills, a custom-written poem or text by our writer-in-residence Casey Wimpee, and an invitation to be a key part in our discussions on the Burning Man 2013 endeavor. For the 2,000 level we'll also throw in a 'CHOOSE YOUR OWN PERK' option...as long as it is within our capability*......and within reason**!

*If it involves chocolate fudge + a dildo...count US IN!

*If it involves chocolate fudge + a dildo + your mother's dog..gotta PASS!

|||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||

Our founding members and collaborating artists hail from as diverse locations as Texas, Florida, California, Iceland, Saudi Arabia, and Australia. Additionally, AZTEC ECONOMY and friends have been actively and consistently doing art in NYC for 6+ years and have within the last year travelled to D.C. and New Orleans to show our work as well as been featured at the Obie-Award winning Ice Factory festival at 3LD in Lower Manhattan. It is important for us to keep raising the bar for ourselves --not only in the quality of work we do and the craft of the stories we aim to tell -- but also in the exposure and ambition in scope of our endeavors. Your contribution will help AZTEC ECONOMY continue growing together and advancing our opportunities to develop a unique voice and community in live theatre. We feel this project in partiuclar, KILL DEVIL HILLS is especially potent in this new American century and we're real damn excited to get finally get it off the ground.

|||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||

And If you like all you've read but are unable to contribute now, please feel free to subscribe to our email list (www.newyorkisdead.net) for notifications on all upcoming shows. Also, you can help by spreading this campaign to any friends you think might have an interest in supporting. In these upstart artistic projects, ANYTHING helps...not only direct financial assistance...but word of mouth and networking assistance. Feel free to contact us at aztececonomy@gmail.com with any questions!

story:
Coast City Ballet's The Nutcracker

Since 2004, Coast City Ballet [CCB] has built the foundation and has become a leading Southern California area dance company. 

With endless energy, the leaders and members of Coast City Ballet work to meet the financial challenges of a growing dance company. We aim to continue to be a vital part of the dance community, but we can't do this alone.

 

Our history:

In 2004, with a modest legacy left by Mr. Joseph D’Autilia, who wanted to see his daughter’s dream of training dancers in a professional, caring, and safe environment come true.  Alicia and Clara D’Autilia purchased Pacific Dance Center in Huntington Beach. 

Clara has been dancing since she was three-years-old, and teaching for over 20 years. She studied dance locally, in New York and in Argentina. 

The mother-daughter duo founded Coast City Ballet and received non-profit status in April 2005. They immediately set out to promote the art of dance, to make ballet accessible to all, offer a bridge between training and performing, and to provide dancers and choreographers of all ages with the opportunities to dance, perform, and create.

Since March 2005, CCB has won numerous national and international dance awards and participated in community outreach programs. They performed in various Southland venues, and presented dozens of CCB members' choreographed works. 

This year marks CCB’s 10th Anniversary full-length production of The Nutcracker Ballet. Based on the original choreography by Marius Petipa and Leon Ivanov, CCB's The Nutcracker (choreographed and directed by Clara D'Autilia) features Company resident dancers, invited guest performers and a cast ranging from three-year-old pre-dance students to professional adults.  The Company has also proudly featured three generations of dancers in the same production. 

Our Outreach Programs:

  • The Nutcracker Preview Night for Children and Teens: A presentation specifically designed to introduce children and teens to the beauty of classical ballet in a professional theater setting.
  • In-studio choreography and dance workshops.
  • Lecture demonstrations on the art form of ballet at area schools and libraries.

Our Needs:

Funding will be used for the following

  • Production costs
  • Backdrop /scenery rental and construction 
  • Costumes,  designers & seamstress 
  • Compensation for guest artists
  • Compensation for technical production staff
  • Performance Venue

Your reward: 

  • Recognition in Nutcracker program, website and Facebook
  • Membership to CCB’s Circle of Friends
  • Priority Seating
  • Tickets to The Nutcracker
  • Advanced ordering privileges
  • Recognition certificate
  • CCB T-shirt

 Delegation of funds:

In the event that CCB does not reach its entire fundraising goal for this campaign, funds will be used first for theater costs, production of Preview night, compensation for guest artists and technical staff.

Spread the Word!

Please help us promote this campaign by posting the link to your Facebook, Twitter or other social media accounts. Tell your friends and family about the campaign, and e-mail them the link or share via Indiegogo tools at the bottom of the page.

Photos by c.FranciscoPhotography

Video by Jerry Irving
story_txt:
Coast City Ballet's The Nutcracker
Since 2004, Coast City Ballet [CCB] has built the foundation and has become a leading Southern California area dance company. 
With endless energy, the leaders and members of Coast City Ballet work to meet the financial challenges of a growing dance company. We aim to continue to be a vital part of the dance community, but we can't do this alone.
 
Our history:
In 2004, with a modest legacy left by Mr. Joseph D’Autilia, who wanted to see his daughter’s dream of training dancers in a professional, caring, and safe environment come true.  Alicia and Clara D’Autilia purchased Pacific Dance Center in Huntington Beach. 
Clara has been dancing since she was three-years-old, and teaching for over 20 years. She studied dance locally, in New York and in Argentina. 
The mother-daughter duo founded Coast City Ballet and received non-profit status in April 2005. They immediately set out to promote the art of dance, to make ballet accessible to all, offer a bridge between training and performing, and to provide dancers and choreographers of all ages with the opportunities to dance, perform, and create.
Since March 2005, CCB has won numerous national and international dance awards and participated in community outreach programs. They performed in various Southland venues, and presented dozens of CCB members' choreographed works. 
This year marks CCB’s 10th Anniversary full-length production of The Nutcracker Ballet. Based on the original choreography by Marius Petipa and Leon Ivanov, CCB's The Nutcracker (choreographed and directed by Clara D'Autilia) features Company resident dancers, invited guest performers and a cast ranging from three-year-old pre-dance students to professional adults.  The Company has also proudly featured three generations of dancers in the same production. 

Our Outreach Programs: 

The Nutcracker Preview Night for Children and Teens: A presentation specifically designed to introduce children and teens to the beauty of classical ballet in a professional theater setting.
In-studio choreography and dance workshops.
Lecture demonstrations on the art form of ballet at area schools and libraries.

Our Needs:
Funding will be used for the following

Production costs
Backdrop /scenery rental and construction 
Costumes,  designers & seamstress 
Compensation for guest artists
Compensation for technical production staff
Performance Venue

Your reward:  

Recognition in Nutcracker program, website and Facebook
Membership to CCB’s Circle of Friends
Priority Seating
Tickets to The Nutcracker
Advanced ordering privileges
Recognition certificate
CCB T-shirt


 Delegation of funds:
In the event that CCB does not reach its entire fundraising goal for this campaign, funds will be used first for theater costs, production of Preview night, compensation for guest artists and technical staff. 

Spread the Word!
Please help us promote this campaign by posting the link to your Facebook, Twitter or other social media accounts. Tell your friends and family about the campaign, and e-mail them the link or share via Indiegogo tools at the bottom of the page.
Photos by c.FranciscoPhotography
Video by Jerry Irving

story:
My name is Samantha Goodman and I am the Artistic Director and Choreographer of DEPTH OF SURFACE, my new interdisciplinary dance work that will premier at the opening week of REDCAT's New Original Works Festival, July 25, 26 & 27!!! 

http://www.redcat.org/event/now-fest-2013-wk-1

http://www.redcat.org/festival/new-original-works-festival-2013

https://www.facebook.com/events/199614910194280/

DEPTH OF SURFACE explores the act of remembering as a continuous state of re-creating and re-imagining past lived experiences. Featuring an original score by jazz pianist Reggy Woods and cellist Isaac Takeuchi, costumes by Desiree Klein, and large scale video projections, five dancers explore the fluid boundary between the present moment and remembered past as they are submerged in rich visual and sonic landscapes.

My interests thrive in the sensory and emotional responses sparked by memory, and the ways in which they texture the body and layer the human experience. I am developing a unique movement style, which investigates the intersections of post-modern release based body mechanics with performance qualities and uses of the spine explored in traditional Afro-Brazilian dance. Over the past decade, I have been dedicated to movement research of both contemporary and traditional Afro-Brazilian dance abroad in Salvador, Brazil. I am currently pursuing my masters degree in Dance at UCLA’s World Arts and Cultures Department.

As an independent choreographer experimenting with the mediums of dance and video, it is quite an honor to be presenting my work at the New Original Works Festival alongside a handful of very talented multi disciplinary artists. While I am extremely grateful for the generous contributions from the REDCAT Theater to partially produce DEPTH OF SURFACE, I am still in need of additional funds to complete this project to its full potential in supporting our large cast of 9 artists, and to cover the costs of costume production, rehearsal space and transportation.

Our extremely talented cast is made up of: 

DANCERS: Sasha Rivero, Rande Dorn, Misha Vickroy, Michelle-Marie Gilkeson, Bridget Murano

COMPOSERS/MUSICIANS: Reggy Woods, Isaac Takeuchi

COSTUME DESIGNER: Desiree Klein

ARTISTIC DIRECTOR/CHOREOGRAPHER: Samantha Blake Goodman

Over the past month and a half, the cast has put in over 75 hours of their time and artistry to this project. ALL donations will go towards compensating the artists for their work and dedicated time in bringing DEPTH OF SURFACE to life, as well as production costs for the costumes, rehearsal space fees and transportation!!

We are extremely grateful for donations in any amount and thank you for supporting the independent artists that make up our cast. We hope to see you all at the show July 25, 26 and 27 and can not wait to share this this special work with you!!!!! 

With Love & Gratitude-

Samantha Goodman and the DEPTH OF SURFACE cast

story:
Pull some strings and support Rogue Artists Ensemble in 2013

It’s time for our yearly fundraiser drive and we need your help! We're expanding our community involvement, gussying up Shakespeare, finally completing our splintery passion project and more…. So read on, lend a hand… or a rod… or a shadow puppet light.

Premiering this summer, HYPERBOLE: bard remixes Shakespeare all over Los Angeles!

HYPERBOLE: bard is an original, family-friendly performance created by Rogue Artists Ensemble that recreates a collection of William Shakespeare’s most famous scenes through clowning, masked movement, puppets, and music.  We want to bring this whimsical, fun filled show to students! We want to provide free performances for the community! We want to give Shakespeare the makeover he never asked for! And we need your support to make that dream come true.

But that's not all the Rogues are up to...

This October, PINOCCHIO leaps to the stage like you've never imagined!

PINOCCHIO is one of the most complicated, thrilling and beautiful projects the Rogues have ever tackled. This is our unique adaptation of the beloved fairy tale centered around a hoarder, a dead blue girl, and a maniacal wooden boy as they discover just what it means to be alive.  Pinocchio can only survive by facing his fears… by facing the terrible Dog Fish.

Pinocchio can become real, but only with your help!

And remember since Rogue Artists Ensemble is a not for profit 501(C)3:
DONATIONS TO ROGUE ARTISTS ENSEMBLE ARE TAX DEDUCTIBLE!

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $12,000!

The money we raise here will help expand our education department, support our free HYPERBOLE: bard shows this summer in Los Angeles, and make a major dent in our production costs for October's production of PINOCCHIO.

In return for your gracious contribution to the Rogues, we are offering a plethora, nay, a cornucopia of Rogue-tastic rewards!  From cool, limited edition Rogue memorabilia, to personalized Rogue crafts, to intimate time with your favorite Rogues, we are committed to letting you know that we appreciate you!

Check out our list of sweet rewards and then contribute to the Rogue cause today!

Never will truer words be said than when you tell your friends that you brought to LA:  “…a feast for the senses.” –Variety

There are many ways to contribute.

The best way to help the Rogues is with a financial contribution. But we understand that that's not in the cards for everyone. If you can't donate, help get the word out to someone who can and you’ll be a Rogue Champion.

Share our campaign on Facebook or better yet send an email blast out to your friends and family! We’re also always looking for volunteers too (click here) Link - http://www.rogueartists.org/get-involved/volunteeringemployment/

Thank you so much.

Your support over the years and into the future means so much to us, it's hard to express in words. Words alone don't touch upon the immense feeling of gratitude that we have for you, our artistic community. The time, laughs and tears, and contributions that you have shared and will share with us throughout our continuing history has touched our hearts deeply, and inspired us to continue our mission:

To create Hyper-theater, an innovative hybrid of theater traditions, puppetry, mask work, dance, music, and modern technology. Through a collaborative development process, with an emphasis on design and storytelling, the Rogues create original, thought-provoking performances. We cultivate unique audience experiences that appeal to multiple generations of theatergoers in order to expand the boundaries of contemporary American theater.

Puppet on.

story:
Who We Are

TE San Pedro Rep offers the Southern California community a unique alternative to the typical L.A. theater experience. A wholehearted celebration of empowered artistic innovation - from every background and medium, TESPR strives to reawaken the creative spirit in each of us.

True to its name, TE San Pedro Rep is an artistic paradise - a caring, dedicated community fully invested in the work of every inspired craftsman. We joyfully embrace the interdisciplinary nature of performance, utilizing every aspect of human experience to delve further and further into the unknown. Through intelligent and fearless exploration, TESPR is committed to reexamining the fundamental works that have defined performance from Ancient Greece to Modern America. We knowingly stand on the shoulders of giants, casting our vision forward into a new era of American performance.

We remain committed to fueling the next generation of American art, creating visionary work that rattles the foundations of modern performance.


TESPR's HOME Campaign

The Goal: $5,000


*H*elp grow our home:  empowering our San Pedro home to match our artistic aspirations with updated sound and lighting equipment.

*O*rganization:  creating a dynamic, innovative administrative department -including office space! - that will nurture, expand and fuel TESPR's artistic and financial aspirations.

*M* ake Training Affordable: allowing us to give the very best developing artists full scholarships to train at The Acting Matrix Conservatory. Ensuring our school's begins with a reputation of artists who'll work harder and be more gracious than the next.

*E*nd The Year In The Black: driving our young company into full federal non-profit status including, grants, foundational support, tax-deductable donations, and more!


This is the most EXCITING and IMPORTANT time in TE's young history!


Will you help us SUCCEED ?


We cannot reach our goal without YOU - our community of devoted theatre-goers, supporters, and creators!

Will you add a gift to help us soar?


Other Ways You Can Help

The success of this project lies in the sense of community it inspires. We believe in the power of community. It is an ever increasing force, a will that can do things that no single person - no matter their talents - can achieve on their own. Put simply, we are Believers. Optimists. Enthusiasts. We invite you to share in our dream - that together we can build an artistic paradise of devoted, passionate, and FEARLESS artists, boldly pushing the boundaries of performance throughout the world!

story:
Well hi there! 

My name is Brynn Linsey, and I'm in my final year of education at Rosebud School of the Arts. In order to graduate, I have to produce and perform in a show of my choosing, called a final project. It's a lot of work but I'm learning so much already!

The show I’ve chosen to produce is called Holy Mo by Lucia Frangione, a noted playwright who is also an alumni of Rosebud School of the Arts. It’s the story of Moses told by three travelling clowns: Follie, Bufoona, and Guff. Their way of telling this classic Bible story is a bit unexpected and very hilarious! I just know that audiences will be delighted and moved by this fantastic musical.

We’ll be performing the show from July 23rd to July 26th at the Akokoniskway Gallery in beautiful Rosebud, Alberta. Rosebud Theatre’s summer show The Wizard of Oz will also be playing, so you’ll have the chance to see two great shows in one day!

Before any of that can happen though, we need to build the show!

It’s not an easy thing putting up a show, nor is it cheap! They don’t call us starving artists for nothing! But it’s all achievable with help from you.

I’m asking for $1000 to devote to all of the amazing things you’ll see in this production. Everything from the set, to the costumes, props, lights, and special effects. Every donation on Indiegogo will receive a unique PERK, created with love by us 3 clowns. There’s cool stuff like postcards, clown noses, or even tea and cake after the show with us!

If you can’t help with funding then you can always pray for strength and guidance as I go about producing this show! Cause I’ll need it!

Thank you so much for helping us make my little dreams come true! I can’t wait to see you at the show!

Love, Brynn
